Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Clarifying comments:
An article is a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity, (in)definiteness and information status (new or given status). Sometimes these notions of specificity, definiteness and information status are summed up in the term identifiability. Articles cannot occur independently, though they might be homophonous with pronouns or numerals that can. A language does not necessarily have both a non-specific/indefinite and a specific/definite marker. These markers often stem from very different sources (numerals and demonstratives) and need not to be similar in formal expression or position.

A formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone.
Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm where there are markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum making it hard to define discrete categories. Articles are more grammaticalized, i.e. are often obligatory in certain contexts that require definite or specific reference. Definite or specific articles can also grammaticalize from pronouns meaning 'a certain'. As articles necessarily accompany nouns, it is in these cases that it is necessary to investigate whether the marker can occur independently or not; if it can it is most likely a pronoun and not an article. Articles can be homophonous with pronouns and demonstratives, and also with classifiers.
wiki_summary: An article is a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity, (in)definiteness and information status (new or given status). Sometimes these notions of specificity, definiteness and information status are summed up in the term "identifiability". Articles cannot occur independently, though they might be homophonous with pronouns or numerals that can. A language does not necessarily have both a non-specific/indefinite and a specific/definite marker. These markers often stem from very different sources (numerals and demonstratives) and need not to be similar in formal expression or position.    A formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone.  Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm where there are markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum making it hard to define discrete categories. Articles are more grammaticalized, i.e. are often obligatory in certain contexts that require definite or specific reference. Definite or specific articles can also grammaticalize from pronouns meaning 'a certain'. As articles necessarily accompany nouns, it is in these cases that it is necessary to investigate whether the marker can occur independently or not; if it can it is most likely a pronoun and not an article. Articles can be homophonous with pronouns and demonstratives, and also with classifiers.       Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is a conventionalised way of marking definiteness or specificity without marking spatial location, and if there is evidence that the marker in question is different in form from the spatial deictic demonstratives (e.g. ‘the’ is different from ‘that’).    2. If no such marker is given, write ‘Not mentioned’ in the comment and code 0 if other demonstratives have been covered, otherwise code ‘?’.           Examples     **Aiton** (ISO 639-3: aio, Glottolog: aito1238)     Morey 2005:244-245, Coded 1:  ```   mə    nan    a māt     nɛ   wā   time  that   minister  DEF  say    ‘Then the minister said.’    ```  **Buwal**  (ISO 639-3: bhs, Glottocode: buwa1243)     Viljoen 2013:234-242, Coded 1:    There is an indefinite and definite determiner, the definite determiner acts like a definite article.  ```  Ma      ŋga     tekeɗ       anta         vayay ?  mā      ŋgā     tēkēɗ       āntā         vájáj  REL=    break   calabash  DEF.DET         who  ‘Who broke the calabash?’    ```    **Ganda** (ISO 639-3:lug, Glottocode: gand1255)     Crabtree 1902: 149, Coded 1:    If a noun is modified by a numeral lower than 5, definiteness can be marked by adding an initial vowel (IV) to the numeral. This initial vowel is omitted if noun phrase reference is indefinite.       Further reading  Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Definite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/37)   Related Features  * [GB021: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB021)  * [GB022: Are there prenominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB022)  * [GB023: Are there postnominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB023)

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Clarifying comments: In this question, we need explicit support that indefinite NPs do/do not commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Indefinite articles can be homophonous with demonstratives, the numeral 'one' or classifiers.
wiki_summary: In this question, we need explicit support that indefinite NPs do/do not commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Indefinite articles can be homophonous with demonstratives, the numeral 'one' or classifiers.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if indefinite NPs commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Three or more examples are sufficient.  2. If there is are sufficient amounts of examples of indefinite NPs occurring without an article, then give the page references and code 0.     Examples      **North Ambrym** (ISO 639-3: mmg, Glottolog: nort2839)    Franjieh 2012: 94,  Coded 1:    Indefinite specific is marked by the numeral one and indefinite non-specific is marked by the numeral one and a non-specific marker.  ```   Te   moro          sene   tiese   hu    byanen  conj  rec.pst.3dl   give   piglet  ind   go.tr.3sg  ‘And they gave a piglet to him’  ```    **Hupdë**  (ISO 639-3: jup,  Glottolog: hupd1244)    Epps 2008:292, 306, p.c. 2009 Coded 0:    However, Epps notes that "New participants and entities are frequently introduced into discourse with the   numeral for ‘one’.      **Guro** (ISO 639-3: goa, Glottolog: guro1248)    Kuznetsova p.c. 2013, Coded ?:    There is a marker, originating from the numeral one, that can be used as an indefinite article. It is however not known how grammaticalized this is and therefore not possible to answer for GB021.         Further reading  Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Indefinite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/38)     Related Features  * [GB020: Are there definite or specific articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB020)  * [GB022: Are there prenominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB022)  * [GB023: Are there postnominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB023)

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, prefixation
wiki_summary: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.     Procedure  1. If there are articles, code 1 if in the pragmatically unmarked order they can precede the noun.     Examples    **Ainu** (ISO 639-3: ain, Glottocode: ainu1240)    Tamura 2000:263, Coded ?:     Comes before the noun referring to the person or thing that is being discussed now. There is some resemblance to the use of definite articles in English. This word is the copula, converted to an adnominal and literally means 'the one that is'."'      **Standard Arabic** (ISO 639-3: arb, Glottocode: stan1318)     Ryding 2005:156, Coded 1:    The definite article is prenominal and prefixes to the noun, the indefinite article   is postnominal and marked by a suffixed /-n/ sound.  ```  al-xubz    [Definite article]  def bread    'The bread'    bayt-un    [Indefinite article]  house indef  'A house'  ```     Further reading  Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Definite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/37)    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Indefinite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/38)     Related Features  * [GB020: Are there definite or specific articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB020)  * [GB021: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB021)  * [GB023: Are there postnominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB023)

Feature: Are there postnominal articles?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, suffixation
wiki_summary: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.     Procedure  1. If there are articles, code 1 if in the pragmatically unmarked order they follow the noun.  		   Examples      **Standard Arabic** (ISO 639-3: arb, Glottocode: stan1318)    Ryding 2005: 156, Coded 1:    The definite article is prenominal and prefixes to the noun, the indefinite article is postnominal and marked by a suffixed /-n/ sound.  ```  al-xubz    [Definite article]  def bread    'The bread'    bayt-un    [Indefinite article]  house indef  'A house'  ```    **Lozi** (ISO 639-3: loz, Glottocode: lozi1239)     Fortune 2001: 6-105, Coded 0:    Not explicitly mentioned, but the example sentences never show articles and other demonstratives are covered in the grammar.     **Lunda** (ISO 639-3: lun, Glottocode: lund1266)     Kawasha 2003: 132, Coded ?:    Indefiniteness can be expressed with a quantifier, but it is not clear how far this marker has grammaticalized to be a dedicated or sufficiently obligatory indefiniteness marker.     Further reading  Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Definite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/37)    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Indefinite Articles. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/38)     Related Features  * [GB020: Are there definite or specific articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB020)  * [GB021: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB021)  * [GB022: Are there prenominal articles?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB022)

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Clarifying comments: Consider cardinal numerals only (i.e., not ordinal numerals). It does not matter what kind of construction is required (e.g., attributive 'two books' or relative 'books that are two') or what word class the root or modifying form of that the cardinal numerals belong to, i.e., 'two-ing books' (verb) or 'two-some books' (noun) apply to this question. If some numerals go before the noun and some go after, code 3 (both orders). If there is a free choice where to place the numeral, code 3 (both orders) as well. If the order depends on some other grammatical category which is neutral with respect to pragmaticality (e.g. definiteness), code 3. If the order depends on the noun consider the order(s) that applies to an open class of nouns.
wiki_summary: Consider cardinal numerals only (i.e., not ordinal numerals). It does not matter what kind of construction is required (e.g., attributive 'two books' or relative 'books that are two') or what word class the root or modifying form of that the cardinal numerals belong to, i.e., 'two-ing books' (verb) or 'two-some books' (noun) apply to this question. If some numerals go before the noun and some go after, code 3 (both orders). If there is a free choice where to place the numeral, code 3 (both orders) as well. If the order depends on some other grammatical category which is neutral with respect to pragmaticality (e.g. definiteness), code 3. If the order depends on the noun consider the order(s) that applies to an open class of nouns.     Procedure  1. Consider only phrases that X (numeral) units of Y (noun) in their pragmatically neutral form.  2. If the numeral always precedes the noun code 1, if the numeral always follows the noun, code 2.  3. If a closed class of nouns require a different order than an open class, disregard the closed class, but otherwise if both orders occur, that is if some numerals precede and some follow, or there is a free choice or there is a choice depending on some other factor (e.g., definiteness), then code 3.     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Mostly numeral-noun with a few exceptions	   * Mostly noun-numeral with a few exceptions	   * Either order occurs with any numeral			     Examples  The following is an example where both orders occur, depending on the numeral.    ‘[W]hereas adjectives postmodify nouns, numbers and quantifiers premodify the classifier, or, if its a noun that can be counted, the noun.  Therefore (60) is grammatical in Tai and (61) is not:  (60) two day  ‘two days’  (61) *day two ‘two days’  The only exception to this is ‘one’, which together with demonstratives postmodifies the classifier or noun.’ (Morey 2005:240-1).  Coded by Jeremy as 3, because both orderings occur.     Further reading  This feature is akin to WALS 89: http://wals.info/chapter/89. Matthew Dryer has written a paper remarking on  the distribution of noun-numeral order in Africa (among other nominal modifiers).     Dryer, Matthew S. 2011. Noun-Modifier Order in Africa. In Geographical Typology and Linguistic Areas. With special reference to Africa. Osamu Hieda, Christa König, and Hirosi Nakagawa (eds). 287-311. Amsterdam/Philadephia: John Benjamins     Related Features  GB193 What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Clarifying comments: Like all questions concerning the order of elements, only the pragmatically unmarked orders are targeted.
wiki_summary: Like all questions concerning the order of elements, only the pragmatically unmarked orders are targeted.     Procedure  1. In the pragmatically unmarked order, if the demonstrative precedes the noun, code 1.  2. In the pragmatically unmarked order, if the demonstrative follows the noun, code 2.  3. If both occur, for example, if some demonstratives precede and some follow, or there is a free choice, then code 3.         Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Different demonstratives take different orders	   * There is free variation	   * Demonstrative construction has a form both before and after the noun	   * Demonstratives are treated as suffixes	   * Demonstratives are treated as prefixes	   	     Examples    **Djeebbana** (ISO 639-3: djj, Glottocode: djee1236)    McKay 2000: 216-217, coded 1:  ```  Ma-ngudjeya-yiberra  barreya     barra-kkudja-nga   MlNIMP·tell-3AUGDAT  those3AUG   3AUGS-be.in.group-REM  You tell that mob sitting there.   ```   Further reading  Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Order of Demonstrative and Noun. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/88)     Related Features  * [GB024: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB024)    * [GB193: What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB193)

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Clarifying comments: This means that a restrictively interpreted adjective is separated from the noun by some element that is not part of the nominal. For example, can you say The man is running big and the like to mean The big man is running. Typically a language which allows this has extensive agreement systems so that you can still work out what modifies what in the NP without them being adjacent (i.e. the Australian type). NPs that are made up of several coordinated NPs that can be interpreted by the verb or other elements are not relevant here. This features aims to capture NPs where the head and modifiers can be separated. Examples of the type I painted the house red or I saw the boy big are not necessarily discontinuous, but most likely resultative or contrastive (I saw the boy big [as opposed to before when he was small]).
wiki_summary: This means that a restrictively interpreted adjective is separated from the noun by some element that is not part of the nominal. For example, can you say "The man is running big" and the like to mean "The big man is running". Typically a language which allows this has extensive agreement systems so that you can still work out what modifies what in the NP without them being adjacent (i.e. the "Australian type"). NPs that are made up of several coordinated NPs that can be interpreted by the verb or other elements are not relevant here. This features aims to capture NPs where the head and modifiers can be separated. Examples of the type "I painted the house red" or "I saw the boy big" are not necessarily discontinuous, but most likely resultative or contrastive ("I saw the boy big [as opposed to before when he was small]").     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there any sentences illustrating noun phrases where the modifier is separated from the noun that it modifies, such as ‘The man is running big’ to mean ‘The big man is running.’  2. Ignore sentences which may be resultatives such as ‘I painted the house red’ or contrastives such as ‘I saw the boy big’ (when he was an adult).  3. If this feature is not mentioned and there are no such sentences, code 0.  4. If there is an extensive agreement system, try to find out further whether these noun phrases exist even if they are not mentioned in the grammar.         Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned     Examples  Examples:  Maung  Coded in NTS as 1.  Coder’s comment: ‘(3-28)||Yungku marrik manga-niki-ng mata ma-lakpi.||firewood(VE) NEG 3GEN/3VE-carry-I1 VE VE-heavy||||She shouldn't carry heavy firewood.||HH Text 4:48’    Atampaya  ‘(89b) ulu           ana-n      ayparumpiwa            3sg-NOM go-PAST sparrowhawk-ABS            The sparrowhawk went along  [...] These should be regarded as stylistic variants about which the present writer is in position to say little.  Order changes appear to be a feature of narrative discourse when a speaker ‘recaps’ the participants in the previous clause.’  (Crowley 1983:369).  Coded in NTS as ‘?’.  Coder’s comment: ‘Well it is common for a free pronoun to be the first element of the clause and a coreferent nominal may follow the verb (see (89b), p.369). However, Crowley describes this construction as an afterthought construction in which case these are not discontinuous NPs. However, such cases seem so common in the data it is questionable whether they really are all afterthoughts.’  This is a possibly erroneous coding as the sentence in question does not contain a modifier.     Further reading  A classic re the Australian languages of this kind is Hale (1983). Discontinuous NP also occur in some classical IE languages (Greek, Sanskrit etc) and probably there are things written specifically about discontinuous NPs too.    Hale, Kenneth. (1983) Warlpiri and the Grammar of Non-Configurational Languages.  Natural Language and Linguistic Theory 1. 5-47.     Related Features    GB193: What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Clarifying comments: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John with Mary went to market')? This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this (to a certain extent). In some languages the only way to do nominal coordination is with a comitative phrase, i.e., the only way to say X and Y is to say X with Y. This feature aims to capture such languages (which, as they have no difference between coordination and comitatives for nouns, get a 0). To see whether an element is comitative or coordinating check for case marking, agreement etc. For example, if X is the element in question and in the dative you get 'John-DAT X Mary-DAT' then X is likely coordinating, while if you get John-DAT X Mary then X is likely comitative. Or with agreement, if you get 'John X Mary verb-PL' rather than 'John X Mary verb-SG' (just like 'John X suitcase verb-SG') then that suggests X is likely coordinating.
Function: argument marking, oblique, conjunction, coordination, case marking, comitative
wiki_summary: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John with Mary went to market')? This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this (to a certain extent). In some languages the only way to do nominal coordination is with a comitative phrase, i.e., the only way to say X and Y is to say X with Y. This feature aims to capture such languages (which, as they have no difference between coordination and comitatives for nouns, get a 0). To see whether an element is comitative or coordinating check for case marking, agreement etc. For example, if X is the element in question and in the dative you get 'John-DAT X Mary-DAT' then X is likely coordinating, while if you get John-DAT X Mary then X is likely comitative. Or with agreement, if you get 'John X Mary verb-PL' rather than 'John X Mary verb-SG' (just like 'John X suitcase verb-SG') then that suggests X is likely coordinating.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an example of NP coordination such as ‘John and Mary went to the market’ which uses an element that is distinct from ‘with’.    2. Look for this in example sentences and appendixed text as well.     Examples  **Turkish** used to be a language with only comitatives for NP coordination namely the -le/la marker as in 'Mary-le John' but Modern Turkish also has the borrowed ve 'and' so one can now also 'John ve Mary'. Thus modern Turkish gets a 1 while older forms, before the borrowing, would get a 0.    **Tai Phake**  ‘Two nouns of equal status can be linked with khaa [...], as in example (69):  69) day 22 February mother and father and travel Gaya  ‘May mother and father will go to Budhagaya on the 22nd of February.’’  ‘Banchob (1987) identified a number of prepositions in Phake, and these are presented in Table 8.14: ca ‘for, to, with’...’  (Morey 2005:245;240)  Coded by Jeremy as 1, as these are different.    **Maale** (Ta-Ne-Omotic, mdy/male1284)  Sometimes the same element is used for coordination and comitative but with a difference in the number of times the element appears (e.g., twice for coordination and once for comitative). In such cases, code as 0 because it is nevertheless the same element (thanks Alena for the example) of Maale.    Maale marks with an instrumental/comitative *-na* every conjoined noun within a coordinated NP but uses only one *-na* for comitative (Amha 2001: 79, further examples on p. 62–63)    ```  táání    suugg-atsí   laal-éll-ó-na    (ʔá-á-nte)       zag-é-ne  1SG:NOM  chief-M:NOM  woman-F-ABS-INST (exist-IPF-TEMP) see-PF-A:DCL  'I saw the chief with the woman.' (Amha 2001: 79)    táání    suugg-atsí-na     laal-éll-ó-na      zag-é-ne  1SG:NOM  chief-M:NOM-INST  woman-F-ABS-INST   see-PF-A:DCL  'I saw the chief and the woman.'(Amha 2001: 79)  ```     Further reading  Scott Drellishak. 2004. A Survey of Coordination Strategies in the World’s Languages. University of Washington MA thesis.

Feature: Is there a distinction between inclusive and exclusive?
Clarifying comments: Is there a pronoun or other marker that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor? This feature is not restricted to the pronominal system but includes person indexing as well. If inclusive is marked overtly in either the pronominal system or through verbal marking this is sufficient to trigger a (1) for this feature, even if exclusive has no overt morphological marking.
wiki_summary: Is there a pronoun or other marker that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor? This feature is not restricted to the pronominal system but includes person indexing as well. If inclusive is marked overtly in either the pronominal system or through verbal marking this is sufficient to trigger a (1) for this feature, even if exclusive has no overt morphological marking.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is a pronoun or other marker, such as a person index, that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor in the first person plural.       Examples    **Southern Sierra Miwok** (ISO 639-3: skd, Glottocode: sout2985)    Table 6: Personal Pronominal Suffixes:    |   | Series 1 | Series 2 | Series 3 | Series 4 |  | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |  | 1Dinc. |   |   | -ti: | -ti: |  | 1P | -tti-/-mahhi: | -me- |   |   |  | 1Pinc. |   |   | -ticci: | -ticci: |  | 1Pexcl. |   |   | -mahhi: | -mahhi: |    (Broadbent 1964: 43)     Southern Sierra Miwok would be coded as 1. The lack of a first person dual exclusive form does not affect this designation, nor does the fact that the language has first person plural markers in Series 1 and 2 that do not mark clusivity.    **Chalcatongo Mixtec** (ISO: mig, Glottocode: sanm1295)    Table 11: Pronouns    | PERS | GENDER | FREE | CLITIC |  | --- | --- | --- | --- |  | 1 | Familiar | rù&577;ù | =rí |  |  | Polite | na&577;a | =na |  |  | Inclusive (pl)  | &382;ó&577;ó | =&382;ó |    (Macaulay 1996: 81)    Chalcatongo Mixtec would be coded as 1. A plural pronoun that is unmarked for clusivity can be derived from the polite or familiar first person pronouns with a prefix, but the inclusive first person is inherently plural. There is no first person plural pro-form that is marked for exclusivity. The existence of an inclusive form is sufficient to trigger a (1) and the lack of an exclusive form has no impact on this.    **Yongbei Zhuang** (ISO 639-3: zyb, Glottocode: yong1276)    Table 9.3.5: First person    | Singular | Plural (excl.) | Plural (incl.) |  | --- | --- | --- |  |ku | tuo, po tu | lau’ |    (Luo 2008: 327)    Coded by Jeremy as 1.         Further reading  Cysouw, Michael. 2003. *The Paradigmatic Structure of Person Marking*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Filimonova, Elena. 2005. *Clusivity: Typology and case studies of the inclusive exclusive distinction*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing.     Related Features  NA

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This question targets the existence of a gender distinction in independent 3rd person anaphoric forms, which includes pronouns and also demonstratives. This distinction is often one of natural gender (masc./fem), but it could be animacy as well (see Corbett 1991 for further discussion of gender). For languages with no 3rd person independent pronouns a gender distinction in demonstratives would trigger a (1) here. If pronouns with inanimate referents agree with the gender/noun class of that inanimate noun that will also suffice for (1) here. If a language has a gender distinction for 3rd person pronouns but not for demonstratives, this is also sufficient for a (1) in this category.
wiki_summary: This question targets the existence of a gender distinction in independent 3rd person anaphoric forms, which includes pronouns and also demonstratives. This distinction is often one of natural gender (masc./fem), but it could be animacy as well (see Corbett 1991 for further discussion of gender). For languages with no 3rd person independent pronouns a gender distinction in demonstratives would trigger a (1) here. If pronouns with inanimate referents agree with the gender/noun class of that inanimate noun that will also suffice for (1) here. If a language has a gender distinction for 3rd person pronouns but not for demonstratives, this is also sufficient for a (1) in this category.     Procedure  1. If there are grammaticalised  independent pronouns which specify sex (masculine or feminine) or animacy, or agree with the gender/nounclass of the noun, code 1.  2. If there are no 3rd person demonstratives that specify sex/gender/nounclass but there are demonstratives that specify gender, code 1.  3. If neither independent 3rd person forms nor demonstratives are marked for gender, code 0.     Examples    **Kuot** (ISO 639-3: kto, Glottolog: kuot1243)    Kuot has no 3rd person pronouns (Lindstr&246;m 2002, 132). It does have demonstratives that can function as 3rd person pronouns, and these forms index masculine vs. feminine gender (Lindstr&246;m 2002: 134). Kuot would be coded 1.    **Biak** (ISO 639-3: bhw, Glottolog: biak1248)    Biak has independent 3rd person pronouns in several number categories: singular *i*, dual *su*, paucal *sko*. For only the 3rd person plural pronouns there is a distinction between animate (*si*) and inanimate (*na*) (van den Heuval 1996: 66). Biak is coded 1.    **Ingush** (ISO 639-3: inh, Glottolog: ingu1240)    Ingush 3rd person pronouns are historically related to demonstratives (Nichols 2011: 172). Neither singular nor plural 3rd person pronouns index gender (including animacy, noun class, etc.) (Nichols 2011: 174). Ingush is coded 0.       Further reading    Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB196: Male/female distinction in 2nd person pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB196)  * [GB197: Male/female distinction in 1st person pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB197)  * [GB051: Noun class/gender system: sex](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB052: Noun class/gender system: shape](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB053: Noun class/gender system: animacy](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB054: Noun class/gender system: plant status](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB192: Noun class/gender system: phonological properties of a noun](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)

Feature: Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Clarifying comments: A dual or unit augmented form must be present throughout the paradigm (i.e. for all person categories) for this feature to be coded as (1). Both bound and free person forms are to be considered in coding this feature. Inclusive and exclusive categories of 1st person are not considered separate person categories for the purposes of coding this feature (e.g. if a language has dual number in 3rd, 2nd, and any 1st person category it is sufficient for triggering a (1)). A dual or unit augmented form for a single person category in the paradigm is *not* sufficient for a (1) code.
wiki_summary: A dual or unit augmented form must be present throughout the paradigm (i.e. for all person categories) for this feature to be coded as (1). Both bound and free person forms are to be considered in coding this feature. Inclusive and exclusive categories of 1st person are not considered separate person categories for the purposes of coding this feature (e.g. if a language has dual number in 3rd, 2nd, and any 1st person category it is sufficient for triggering a (1)). A dual or unit augmented form for a single person category in the paradigm is *not* sufficient for a (1) code.     Procedure  1. If there is at least one grammaticalised pronoun in each person category in a language's independent or bound pronoun paradigm that specifies that the number of what is being referred to is two, then code 1.  2. Otherwise code 0.     Examples    **Kayardild** (ISO: gyd, Glottolog: kaya1319)    Basic pronominal stem forms (from Round 2009: 172, Table 3.49)    | Person | Singular | Dual | Plural |  | --- | --- | --- | --- |  | 1 | &331;at&810;- | &331;ar- | &331;al- |  | 2 | &626;i&331;- | kir- | kil- |  | 3 | &627;i- | pir- | pil- |    Kayardild has a dual form for each person category in its pronominal paradigm, so it is coded 1.    **Tai Phake** (ISO 639-3: phk, Glottolog: phak1238)    ‘The dual pronoun ha, the meaning of which in Shan is given as ‘we two’, also survives in some texts, as in example (18), although in this example the dual meaning has been bleached.'  Assam 1PL 1Dual disordered PRT PRT  ‘This Assam is very disturbed at present.’    Banchob (1987: 44) also points out that in Phake, the word khe ‘both’ can be added to the singular pronouns to form dual pronouns, as in hau khe ‘both of us’.  The marking of duality is not obligatory and only used if the speaker or writer has a specific reason for indicating it.’  (Morey 2005:219).    Coded by Jeremy as 0 as this marking is not obligatory and not conventionalised beyond the equivalent of the English ‘both of us’.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 2000. *Number*. (Cambridge Textbooks in Linguistics.) Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * GB043: Dual marking on nouns

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Clarifying comments: Demonstratives are markers of a small set. This doesn't have to be only Euclidean distance (meters, inches etc.), it could also be concerned with near or far in relation to the interlocutors (cf. Wolof). If the system of demonstratives includes a marker that is anaphoric this does not count as a third distance.
wiki_summary: Demonstratives are markers of a small set. This doesn't have to be only Euclidean distance (meters, inches etc.), it could also be concerned with near or far in relation to the interlocutors (cf. Wolof). If the system of demonstratives includes a marker that is anaphoric this does not count as a third distance.     Procedure  1. Find 'demonstratives', which are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position.  2.  Code 1 if there are three or more demonstratives marking different degrees of distance, including distinguishing distance from the speaker or interlocutor.       Examples    **Dupaningan** (ISO 639-3: duo, Glottocode: dupa1235)    Robinson 2011: 93-95, Coded 1:    Three-way contrast    | | Proximal (close) |  Medial (middle) | Distal (far) |   | -------- |-------------| -------------| -------------- |  |Specific | =aye ‘this’ | =aya ‘that’ | =ayo ‘that there’|  |Singular demonstrative (nominal)|ide ‘this (thing)’ | iday ‘that (thing)’ | idu ‘that (thing) over there’|   |Plural demonstrative (nominal)| daginde ‘these (things)’| daginday ‘those (things)’| daginto ‘those (things) over there’|  |Oblique (locative)| ihe ‘here’| ihay ‘there’| ihu ‘over there’|       **Cebuano** (ISO 639-3: ceb, Glottocode: cebu1242)     Bunye and Yap 1971; Payne 1994; Valkama 2000,  Coded 1:    Four-way contrast   ```  kiri 'nearest speaker'   kini 'near speaker'   kana 'near addressee'   kadto 'far from both'  ```    **Aghwan** (ISO 639-3: xag, Glottocode: aghw1237)     Gippert 2008: II-38, Coded 0:    There are relics of a complex system of distal differentiation, but it is not active in Caucasian Albanian any more.                       Further reading  Holger Diessel. 2013. Distance Contrasts in Demonstratives.   In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.   Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/41)     Related Features  * [GB036: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB036)    * [GB037: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB037)

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Clarifying comments: Elevation is concerned with how high up or low an object is (altitude).
wiki_summary: Elevation is concerned with how high up or low an object is (altitude).     Procedure  1. Find 'demonstratives', which are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position.  2. Code 1 if there are demonstratives marking high/low.     Examples  **Godoberi** (ISO 639-3: gdo Glottocode: ghod1238)     Kibrik 1996: 42, Coded 1:    'There is one demonstrative with the meaning “down there” opposed to the demonstratives with differences in horizontal distance.'    **Hatam** (ISO 639-3: had, Glottocode: hata1243)     Reesink 1999:60, Coded 1:  ```  near S. = ni           near A. = ma  away from S & A = mo   far away across = nu   far away down = mu     far up invisible = hu   far up visible = nyo'  ```   Further reading  Holger Diessel. 2013. Distance Contrasts in Demonstratives.   In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.   Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/41)     Related Features  * [GB035: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB035)    * [GB037: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB037)

Feature: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Clarifying comments: Is there a distinction visible-non-visible when referencing to items that are in the same relative distance, i.e. it is not relevant that demonstratives denoting far away reference often also imply non-visibility.
wiki_summary: Is there a distinction visible-non-visible when referencing to items that are in the same relative distance, i.e. it is not relevant that demonstratives denoting far away reference often also imply non-visibility.     Procedure  1. Find 'demonstratives', which are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position.  2. Code 1 if there are demonstratives that specifically communicate that something is invisible/visible to the speaker or interlocutor, rather than just distance.     Examples    **Southern Dong** (ISO 639-3: kmc, Glottocode: sout2741)     Yang and Edmondson 2008: 521, Coded 1:  ```  ‘nai this (able to touch)'  tca that (visible but far away)  ja that, where (invisible)’    ```    **Wunambal** (ISO 639-3: wub, Glottocode: wuna1249)     McGregor 2004: 126, Coded 0:    Unclear, the demonstratives are: 'this', 'that' and 'that way over there, usually out of sight'        Further reading  Holger Diessel. 2013. Distance Contrasts in Demonstratives.   In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.   Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/41)   Related Features  * [GB036: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB036)    * [GB037: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB037)

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns whether there exists a independent classifier system in demonstratives that is not related to the gender/noun class systems, and these elements appear with demonstratives to classify the noun. This classifier system can however be symmetrical with numeral, possessive or verbal classifiers.
Please note, this does NOT concern agreement with the noun class but a separate nominal classification system.
wiki_summary: This question concerns whether there exists a independent classifier system in demonstratives that is not related to the gender/noun class systems, and these elements appear with demonstratives to classify the noun. This classifier system can however be symmetrical with numeral, possessive or verbal classifiers.  Please note, this does NOT concern agreement with the noun class but a separate nominal classification system.     Procedure  1. Find 'demonstratives', which are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position.  2. Code 1 if there are elements which are required with demonstratives which depend on the category of the noun,  3. And if these elements are not used a fixed class such as a gender system.      Available standardised comments  * A There are no demonstrative classifiers mentioned.  * B They sometimes occur but they are not obligatory.   * C The demonstrative classifiers are the same as other classifiers such as numeral classifiers (‘B C’ if both B and C hold).     Examples    **Maonan** (ISO 639-3: mmd, Glottocode: maon1241)      Lu 2008: 171, Coded 1:  ```   dɔ  gwi    tsiŋ    da ȵa:u  ju   mɔ   na kjaŋ   ka  ‘CL:animal buffalo just at   top hill eat grass that   ‘The buffalo that is grazing on the hillside’    dɔ la:k    ᵐba:n  ȵa:u  ja :u  ja :n  ɕa      lɛ       ka  CL:animal   boy    at  inside  house  write character that  ‘The boy who is writing in the house’  ```    **Kharia** (ISO 639-3: khr, Glottocode: khar1287)     Peterson 2011: 124, Coded ?:    There is only one classifier that can appear with demonstratives but it's status and function is unclear.  ```  laʔ   atha jhelob, ikuɖ=ga jhelob  ro ho    mene=ga cakar arbo samudar=te=jo  then heavy long    very=FOC long  and that CLASS=FOC wide Arab ocean=OBL=ADD    oɖoʔ=ki   ho=ki  “bapre!” gam=oʔ=ki  other=PL  that=PL wow!    say=ACT.PST=PL  Then at that heavy, long, very long and so very wide Arabian Sea the others all said  “Wow!”.‟  ```     Further reading  [Noun Classes and Classifiers - Aikhenvald](https://research.jcu.edu.au/lcrc/people/director/selective-papers/2006.-classifiers-and-noun-classes-semantics-pp.-463-70-of-volume-1-article-1111-of-encyclopedia-of-language-and-linguistics-2nd-edition-edited-by-keith-brown.-elsevier-oxford/at_download/file)     Related Features  * [GB057: Are there numeral classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB057)    * [GB058: Are there possessive classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB058)

Feature: Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Clarifying comments: Are there different markings of plural number that do not correlate with different markings of singular, i.e. are there new groups in the plural that are not aligned with the singular groups? The marking does not need to be on the noun itself (it can be plural word for example). The elements can include a zero-marker.
wiki_summary: Are there different markings of plural number that do not correlate with different markings of singular, i.e. are there new groups in the plural that are not aligned with the singular groups? The marking does not need to be on the noun itself (it can be plural word for example). The elements can include a zero-marker.       Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are elements marking number on nouns (excluding pronouns), whether they are attached to the noun or not,  2. And these elements are different depending on the number of the noun,  3. And there is not a one-to-one mapping between the classes of nouns in the singular form and in the plural form.     Examples  **Dutch** (ISO 639-3: nld, Glottocode: dutc1256)      Booij & van Santen p.195, Coded 1:    ‘Nouns that take /-s/ - following an unstressed syllable; nouns that take /-en/, following a stressed syllable; and a small class show /-eren/, but that is really the result of stem allomorphy.'    **Bidyogo** (ISO 639-3: bjg, Glottocode: bidy1244)      Segerer 2002: 102-103 Coded 1:    ‘There isn't a one-to-one correspondence between singular classes and plural classes.’  ‘e-be / m-be leg/legs … pato/kopato duck/ducks’          Further reading  [to be added]     Related Features  * Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Clarifying comments:
Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is enough different to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group. Only so called strong suppletion counts here.

Only answer (1) if there are more than three examples of this. Body-parts and kinship terms are good place to start investigating.
wiki_summary: Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group. Only so called "strong suppletion" counts here.    Only answer (1) if there are more than three examples of this. Body-parts and kinship terms are good place to start investigating.      Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are four or more examples of nouns which are have a suppletive plural form.  2. If there are very few examples, less than 10, check in with Patron Hedvig just in case.  3. If unsure if the forms are "different enough" from each other, file GitHub-issue.  4. If the pattern is labeled as "weak suppletion", see step (3).     Examples  **Ket** (ISO 639-3: ket, Glottocode: kett1243)  George (2007) states that there are suppletive forms for number and gives the following examples. The descriptions implies that there exists more than these three, even if only three are given. Ket is coded as 1 for this feature.    | singular | plural | English translation|   | ---- |  ---- |----------- |    ke?d |   de?ŋ |  ”person/human being”|   ōks | a?q | ”tree”|   qo?d |  qɨ́neŋ | ”way/road”|      Further reading  * Corbett, Greville (2009). Suppletion: Typology, markedness, complexity. Berlin: On Inflection. Trends in Linguistics: Studies and Monographs, Berlin, Mouton de Gruyter. pp. 25–40.  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Georg, Stefan. 2007. A descriptive grammar of Ket: Part I: introduction, phonology and morphology. Kent, UK: Global Oriental. 328pp.     Related Features  * [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042)  * [GB043	Is Feature: Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns bound grammatical marking of singular number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking does not count for a 1 here (hence the emphasis on overt in the feature question). This feature is in contrast to [GB316 Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB316) which focuses on the non-bound marking of singular number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.
wiki_summary: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of singular number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking does not count for a 1 here (hence the emphasis on "overt" in the feature question). This feature is in contrast to [GB316 Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB316) which focuses on the non-bound marking of singular number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or nominal morphology  2. If the author describes a bound marker of singular number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the only marking of singular number are on nouns derived from other word classes (adjectives, verbs etc) or only a small subset of all nouns, code 0  4. If the grammar describes singular number as not marked productively or somewhere else but on the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Akan** (ISO 639-3: aka, Glottocode: akan1250)     Akan has a noun class system marked by prefixes on nouns that distinguishes between singular and plural number. There are 6 noun classes. These noun classes prefixes mark number as well as noun class and are bound to the noun. _o/ɔ-_ is the prefix for noun class 1 which is singular, and _a/e-_ for noun class 6 which is plural. Here is an example with the stem for angel -_bɔfo_  (Osam 1994:120). This is an example of code 1 for GB042.     | | singular | plural |   | ---- |  ---- |----------- |   |angel| _ɔ-bɔfo_ | _a-bɔfo_ |      **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Swedish has suffixes for plural number, but singular is not regularly marked. However, there are some instances where the possibility to analyse certain nouns as having a singular suffix arises. For example, the word for boy - _pojke_-    (Skirgård, p.c.)    | | singular | plural |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   | orange | _apelsin_ | _apelsiner_ |   | boy | _pojke_ | _pojkar_ |     However, Swedish is an example of code 0 for this feature. Even if there are some nouns that could be analysed as having singular marking, it is not a regular productive pattern. The productive marking of singular number in Swedish is by the absence of the plural-suffix - and that does not lead to a 1 in GB042.     Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Osam, Emmanuel Kweku Ahen. 1994. Aspects of Akan Grammar: A Functional Perspective. Ann Arbor: UMI. (Doctoral dissertation, Eugene: University of Oregon; 324pp.)     Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB041)  * [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042)  * [GB043	Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB043)  * [GB044	Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB044)  * [GB165	Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB165)  * [GB166	Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB166)  * [GB316	Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB316)  * [GB317	Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free Feature: Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
wiki_summary: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of dual number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB317 Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?  ](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB317) which focuses on the non-bound marking of dual number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or nominal morphology  2. If the author describes a bound marker of dual number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the only marking of dual number are on nouns derived from other word classes (adjectives, verbs etc) or only a small subset of all nouns, code 0  4. If the grammar describes dual number as not marked productively or somewhere else but on the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Garrwa** (ISO 639-3: wrk, Glottocode: gara1269)     Garrwa has a suffix for dual number on nouns (_-wiya_), this is an example of 1 for GB043.    Breen (2003:435)  ```  Nganinyi-wiya bula-ngka daba ngubungu-na  man-DU 3du-RECIP hit:R boomerang-LOC  ‘Those two men were fighting with boomerangs’    ```     Further reading  * Breen, Gavan 2003. Wanyi and Garrwa Comparative Data. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The non-Pama-Nyungan languages of northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the continent's most linguistically complex region, 425-462. Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University.  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)     Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB041)  * [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042)  * [GB043	Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB043)  * [GB044	Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB044)  * [GB165	Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB165)  * [GB166	Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB166)  * [GB316	Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically Feature: Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
wiki_summary: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of plural number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB318	Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?  ](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB318) which focusses on the non-bound marking of plural number.  For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1. Furthermore, for this feature reduplication only isn't enough.    Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or nominal morphology  2. If the author describes a bound marker of plural number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the only marking of plural number are on nouns derived from other word classes (adjectives, verbs etc) or only a small subset of all nouns, code 0  4. If the only marking of plural number is accomplished by reduplication, code 0.  5. If the grammar describes plural number as not marked productively or somewhere else but on the noun, code as 0  6. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  7. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  8. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples    **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Nouns in Swedish are regularly marked for plural number by a suffix, this would be an example of the coding 1 for GB044.    Swedish number and definiteness markers illustrated with the word for boat - _båt_ (Teleman et al 1999:62)    | | singular | plural |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   | indefinite | _båt_ | _båt-ar_ |   | definite | _båt-en_ | _båt-ar-na_ |     **Samoan** (ISO 639-3: smo, Glottocode: samo1305)    Nouns in Samoan do not take number marking on the nouns at all, number is instead expressed by articles. Articles differ for specificity and number. Plural number combined with specificity is in fact zero-marked, i.e. the absence of an article is the indicator of plural number for specific definiteness. Non-specific plural is overly marked though.    Here are articles in Samoan illustrated with the word for house - _fale_(Mosel & Hovdhaugen 1992:90). Samoan is an example of 0-coding for GB044.    | | singular | plural |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   |specific| _le fale_ | _fale_ |   |non-specific| _se fale_ | _ni fale_ |      Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. _Number_. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Mosel, Ulrike and Even Hovdhaugen. 1992. _Samoan Reference Grammar_. (Instituttet for sammenlignende kulturforskning 85.) Oslo: Scandinavian University Press. xxii+819pp.  * Teleman, Ulf and Staffan Hellberg and Erik Andersson. 1999. _Svenska Akademiens grammatik_. Stockholm: Svenska Akademien. 297+772+708+981pp. (4 vols.) Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature aims to cover markers or markings that instead of signalling additive plural - several instances of X marks that the reference contains entities associated with X - X and other people/things associated with X’. For example, the King-s went to the market means there were several of the type king that went. An associative plural interpretation of s would be the King and his entourage went to the market. This marker does not need to be bound to the noun. If the additive plural also has this function, this also counts.
wiki_summary: This feature aims to cover markers or markings that instead of signalling additive plural - "several instances of X" marks that the reference contains entities associated with X - "X and other people/things associated with X’. For example, "the King-s went to the market" means there were several of the type "king" that went. An associative plural interpretation of "s" would be "the King and his entourage went to the market". This marker does not need to be bound to the noun. If the additive plural also has this function, this also counts.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is a marker of the noun (bound or unbound) that instead of, or in addition to, marking additive plural ("several X") marks that the reference contains entities associated with X, "X and other people/things associated with X".  2. If this use is not mentioned, code ‘?’ and write ‘Not mentioned’ in the comment.  3. If a source explicitly says that this use does not exist, or a fieldworker explicitly says that they have not encountered it, then code 0.       Examples  **Zulu** (ISO 639-3: zul, Glottocode: zulu1248)  Zulu has like many Atlantic-Congo languages a noun class system of "singular" and "plural" classes. However, there are plural noun class markers that can also function as associative plurals, i.e. not denoting more of the same type but "x and things associated with x". Zulu is coded as a 1 for GB046. Poulus & Msimang (1998:36) writes:    _It may be noted here that a plural form such as oVelaphi could refer to either Velaphi and his companions or associates, or it could refer to two people who have the same name - these two types of plurals are some­ times referred to as the “associative” and “numerical” plurals respec­tively._     Further reading  * Daniel, Michael and Edith Moravcsik. 2013. The Associative Plural.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  (Available online at http://wals.info/chapter/36, Accessed on 2016-08-10.) [link](http://wals.info/chapter/36)  * Morey, Stephen. 2002. The Tai languages of Assam. (Doctoral dissertation, Monash University; 413pp.)  * Poulos, George and Msimang, Christian T. 1998. A Linguistic Analysis of Zulu. Cape Town: Pretoria: Via Afrika. 590pp.       Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB041)
