Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An action nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an action or state. In English, we can exemplify this with the enemy’s **destruction** of the city Arrive -arriving would also serves as an example, or 'La concentracio´n de Sherlock Holmes duro´ cinco horas' in Spanish (‘Sherlock Holmes’ concentration lasted five hours’). There needs to be productive derivation, but they can also refer to states or events - not just actions. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning action/state/event is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
wiki_summary: An action nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an action or state. In English, we can exemplify this with "the enemy’s **destruction** of the city" Arrive -arriving would also serves as an example, or 'La concentracio´n de Sherlock Holmes duro´ cinco horas' in Spanish (‘Sherlock Holmes’ concentration lasted five hours’). There needs to be productive derivation, but they can also refer to states or events - not just actions. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "action/state/event" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element which productively attaches to verbs which forms an action/state nominalization such as ‘arrival’, ‘concentration’ etc.    2. Do not code 1 if this element is stated to be a noun in its own right and not derived.     Examples     Examples  **Chukchii** (ISO 639-3: ckt, Glottocode: chuk1273)    The suffix _-ɣərɣ+VH_ in Chukchii derives an action noun from a verb. For example, the verb 'die' -_wʔi_- with iterative aspect and this suffix means 'plague/epidemic/death': _wʔe-tko-ɣərɣ-ə-n_ die-ITER-NMZ-E-3sgABS (Dunn 1999:144). Chukchii is coded as a 1 for this feature.     Further reading  * Dunn,  Michael J.  1999. A Grammar of Chukchi. Canberra: Australian National University. (Doctoral dissertation, Australian National University; xxiii+386pp.)  * Hazout, Ilan. 1995. Action Nominalizations and the Lexicalist Hypothesis. Natural Language & Linguistic Theory  Vol. 13, No. 3, Special Hebrew Issue (Aug., 1995), pp. 355-404 [link](http://www.jstor.org/stable/4047840?seq=1page_scan_tab_contents)  * Koptjevskaja-Tamm, Maria. 2013. Action Nominal Constructions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  [link](http://wals.info/chapter/62)  * Nikitina, Tatiana. 2009. The function and form of action nominalization in Wan. Mandenkan No. 45 pp. 17-28 [link](http://llacan.vjf.cnrs.fr/PDF/Mandenkan45/45nikitina.pdf)     Related Features  * [GB047	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB047)  * [GB048	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB048)  * [GB049	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB049)

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An agent nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an agent of an action. In English, we can exemplify this with the productive _-er_ suffix (_baker, fisher, gardener_ etc.). There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning person is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
wiki_summary: An agent nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an agent of an action. In English, we can exemplify this with the productive _-er_ suffix (_baker, fisher, gardener_ etc.). There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "person" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element which attaches to verbs or nouns to form an agentive nominalization such as ‘singer’ from ‘sing’, If it is not stated that the element is a noun meaning ‘person’.     Examples  **Chukchii** (ISO 639-3: ckt, Glottocode: chuk1273)    The suffix _-lʔ_ in Chukchii derives an agent noun from a verb, and is labeled "active particle" in the description. For example, the verb 'to go' -_təle_ -> _təle-lʔ-ə-n_ - go-PCPL-E-3sgABS 'the one who goes' (Dunn 1999:138-139). Chukchii is coded as a 1 for this feature.     Further reading  * Baker, Mark and Nadya Vinokurova. 2009.  On Agent Nominalizations and Why They are not Like Event Nominalizations.  Language 85:517-556.  (pre-publication version) [link](http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~mabaker/agent-nominals-web.pdf)       Related Features  * [GB047	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB047)  * [GB048	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB048)  * [GB049	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB049)

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An object nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes the object/result of an action. There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning thing is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
wiki_summary: An object nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes the object/result of an action. There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "thing" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element which attaches to verbs or nouns to form an object nominalization such as ‘song’ from ‘sing’, reduplication is also included here in "morphological pattern", as is change in tone or umlaut.     Examples  **Semelai** (ISO 639-3: sza, Glottocode: seme1247)    In Semelai the affix _pn_ derives object nominalisation. _reŋ_ ’ to seek’ -> _pn.ᵈreŋ_ ’thing sought’. Chukchii is coded as a 1 for this feature (Kruspe 2004:67).     Further reading  * Kruspe, Nicole. 2004. A Grammar of Semelai. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB047	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB047)  * [GB048	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB048)  * [GB049	Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB049)

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether biological sex is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their biological sex for this feature to be coded 1. That is, sex must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether biological sex is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their biological sex for this feature to be coded 1. That is, sex must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.     Procedure  1. If there is a noun class/gender system such that there are markers which attach to targets of agreement (e.g. adjectives), which vary according to the noun’s lexically assigned category ...  2. And if there seems to be a correlation between use of a particular gender marker and the sex of the noun, then code 1.  3. Code 0 if there is no class/gender system or the assignment of nouns to classes/genders does not involve sex.	     Examples    **Barein** (ISO 639-3: bva, Glottolog: bare1279)    'Nouns referring to animals or people can be grammatically masculine or feminine. Their grammatical gender is semantically linked to their natural (biological) gender. In some cases, the semantic link is lexically defined (sex-differentiable); thus the grammatical gender does not vary (e.g., boy, mother, rooster, etc.). However, for words like mòosó “cow” and námá “child”, the natural gender is understood to be male when a masculine direct object suffix is used, and female when the feminine direct object suffix is used, i.e., they are “common-gender nouns” (Corbett 1991:34, 181).' (Lovestrand 2012: 71)    The semantic association between nouns whose gender is invariant and whose referents are semantically associated with particular biological sexes (*mother*, *rooster*) is what triggers the 1 code for Barein. The "common-gender" nouns, for which gender agreement indicates the gender of the individual(s) being referred to (rather than a biological sex associated with the general semantics of the noun) are also an example of sex playing a role in the gender system, but this is not necessary for the 1 designation.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB052: Shape and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB053: Animacy and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB054: Plant status and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB192: Phonological properties and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)  * [GB321: Large, unpredictable gender/noun class](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB321)

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the shape of an object is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their shape for this feature to be coded 1. That is, shape must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the shape of an object is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their shape for this feature to be coded 1. That is, shape must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.     Procedure  1. If there is a noun class/gender system such that there are markers which attach to targets of agreement (e.g. adjectives), which vary according to the noun’s lexically assigned category ...  2. And if there seems to be a correlation between use of a particular gender marker and the shape of the referent, then code 1.  3. Code 0 if there is no class/gender system or the assignment of nouns to classes/genders does not involve shape.  			     Examples    **Miraña** (Glottolog: mira1254)    'There are 72 class markers in Miraña. The majority of these (66) belong to the set of specific class markers, which mainly encode shape distinctions. The 6 remaining class markers are general class markers, which encode animacy, natural gender, and number' (Seifart 2005: 77).     kátú:β&603;-ko &603;:-ko pihhú-ko    fall-SCM.1D.pointed DIST-SCM.1D.pointed fish.NMZ-SCM.1D.pointed    ‘It (pointed) fell, that (pointed) fishing rod’ (Seifart 2005: 80, ex. 81a)    kátú:β&603;-hE&616; &603;:-h&616; kú:mu-h&616;    fall-SCM.2D.round DIST-SCM.2D.round turtle-SCM.2D.round    ‘It (disc-shaped) fell, that (disc-shaped) turtle’ (Seifart 2005: 80, ex. 82a)    Although the noun class/gender system for Miraña involves several factors such as sex and animacy, one element involved in the classification of nouns into gender categories is the shape of the referent. Miraña would be coded 1.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB051: Sex and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB053: Animacy and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB054: Plant status and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB192: Phonological properties and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)  * [GB321: Large, unpredictable gender/noun class](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB321)

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the animacy of a noun is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their animacy for this feature to be coded 1. That is, animacy must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Note that while (biological) sex is generally associated with animate referents, a gender system that makes a distinction between male and female is not necessarily sufficient to trigger a 1 here. A gender system in which animacy is a relevant factor will often make a distinction between human or animal referents and non-living referents, and animate status may be extended to culturally important non-living entities (e.g. mythological figures) or objects (e.g. celestial bodies). A human/non-human distinction is sufficient for a 1 code.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the animacy of a noun is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their animacy for this feature to be coded 1. That is, animacy must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Note that while (biological) sex is generally associated with animate referents, a gender system that makes a distinction between male and female is not necessarily sufficient to trigger a 1 here. A gender system in which animacy is a relevant factor will often make a distinction between human or animal referents and non-living referents, and animate status may be extended to culturally important non-living entities (e.g. mythological figures) or objects (e.g. celestial bodies). A human/non-human distinction is sufficient for a 1 code.     Procedure  1. If there is a noun class/gender system such that there are markers which attach to targets of agreement (e.g. adjectives), which vary according to the noun’s lexically assigned category ...  2. And if there seems to be a correlation between use of a particular gender marker and the animacy of the noun, then code 1.  3. Code 0 if there is no class/gender system or the assignment of nouns to classes/genders does not involve animacy.     Examples    **Cheyenne** (ISO 639-3: chy, Glottolog: chey1247)    All Cheyenne nouns belong to either an animate or inanimate gender class. Animate nouns include semantically animate entities like humans and animals, but also 'sun', 'moon', 'star', 'rock', and certain body part, plant, and clothing item names.    | Animate | Singular Form | Plural Form |  | --- | --- | --- |  | man | hetane | hetaneo'o |  | rabbit | v&243;hkoehe | v&243;hkoeheho |  | tomato | henene | heneno |    |Inanimate | Singular Form | Plural Form |  | --- | --- | --- |  | bead | on&233;havo'ke | on&233;havo'k&279;stse |  | river | &243;'he'e | o'he'&279;stse |  | axe | hohk&x022F;xe | hohk&x022F;xeh&x022F;tse |    (Leman 2011: 5-7)    Cheyenne would be coded 1.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB051: Sex and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB052: Shape and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB054: Plant status and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB192: Phonological properties and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)  * [GB321: Large, unpredictable gender/noun class](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB321)

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether belonging to the kingdom of plants is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for nouns that refer to plants to be classified in certain gender categories for this feature to be coded 1. That is, plant status must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether belonging to the kingdom of plants is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for nouns that refer to plants to be classified in certain gender categories for this feature to be coded 1. That is, plant status must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.     Procedure  1. If there is a noun class/gender system such that there are markers which attach to targets of agreement (e.g. adjectives), which vary according to the noun’s lexically assigned category ...  2. And if there seems to be a correlation between use of a particular gender marker and nouns which refer to plants, then code 1.  3. Code 0 if there is no class/gender system or the assignment of nouns to classes/genders does not rely at all on plant status.			     Examples  **Bininj Kun-Wok** (ISO 639-3: gup, Glottocode: gunw1252)    The four semantic categories of gender assignment in this language are described as Masculine, Feminine, Vegetable, and Neuter. The vegetable class includes plants and their products, fire, food, some types of honey, as well as several categories like sexual and excretory body parts, song/ceremony/custom, and boats/planes/cars that are less obviously linked to plant status (Evans 2003: 200-207). Bininj Kun-Wok is coded 1.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB051: Sex and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB052: Shape and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB053: Animacy and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB192: Phonological properties and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)  * [GB321: Large, unpredictable gender/noun class](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB321)

Feature: Are there numeral classifiers?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns whether numerals take an element that varies depending on the noun used, and is not the same as a gender system used in the language (i.e. is not numeral agreement with gender).
wiki_summary: This question concerns whether numerals take an element that varies depending on the noun used, and is not the same as a gender system used in the language (i.e. is not numeral agreement with gender).     Procedure  1. Code 1 if numerals are obligatorily accompanied by an element which varies according to the semantic class of the noun.  2. and if these elements do not form a completely fixed class such as a gender system,  3. and if these elements are not required when the noun is used in the plural form without a numeral,  4. and if the nouns in question are of high countability, such as people/animals/objects, rather than low countability such as water/sand/smoke,       Examples    **Central Okinawan** (ISO 639-3: ryu, Glottocode: cent2126)    Loveless 1963: 109, coded 1:     "The numeral morphs combine with various enumerator morphs, indicating either things being counted (units of measure -- as people, trees, days, handfuls), or the class of things being counted (flat things, rod-shaped things, winged creatures). Most of the basic enumerators may be considered as bound forms of free alternants.   ```  túyi mi-fáni koóta ŋ       [-fáni = classifier 'fowls']  He brought three chickens    tamagu tu-kúu kwiree       [-kúu = classifier 'round obj]  Give me ten eggs  ```    **Hatam** (ISO 639-3: had, Glottocode: hata1243)      Reesink 1999: 57, coded 1:    "Hatam employs a few inalienable nouns as classifiers. These are normally only used with numerals, but they are not obligatory."     Further reading  Aikhenvald, Alexandra (2003) Classifiers: a typology of noun categorization devices. Oxford Studies in Typology and Linguistic Theory . Oxford University Press, New York, USA. [Link](https://research.jcu.edu.au/lcrc/people/director/selective-papers/2006.-classifiers-and-noun-classes-semantics-pp.-463-70-of-volume-1-article-1111-of-encyclopedia-of-language-and-linguistics-2nd-edition-edited-by-keith-brown.-elsevier-oxford/at_download/file)     Related Features  * [GB038: Are there demonstrative classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB038)    * [GB058: Are there possessive classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB058)

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns whether there exists an independent classifier system in possessive constructions that is not related to the other classifier systems such as the gender/noun class of the language or numeral classifiers.

We are concerned with markers that signal the nature of the possessor or the possessum (possessor classifiers/possessed classifiers). This feature applies to both pronominal/nominal possessors and markers which are bound or free. Possessive classifiers need not be obligatory, it can also be possible to construct possessive phrases without possessive classifiers.

Differences in the expression of individual, joint, separate and group possession is not relevant here.
wiki_summary:
This question concerns whether there exists an independent classifier system in possessive constructions that is not related to the other classifier systems such as the gender/noun class of the language or numeral classifiers. We are concerned with markers that signal the nature of the possessor or the possessum (possessor classifiers/possessed classifiers). This feature applies to both pronominal/nominal possessors and markers which are bound or free. Possessive classifiers need not be obligatory, it can also be possible to construct possessive phrases without possessive classifiers. Differences in the expression of individual, joint, separate and group possession is not relevant here. Procedure 1. Code 1 if there are elements which are used, but not necessarily obligatory, in possessive constructions which vary according to the semantic class of the noun being possessed. 2. And these elements are not the same as markers of the noun class/gender system, or other classifier systems such as numeral classifiers. 3. And these elements are not normally used when the noun is used in non-possessive constructions. Examples **Fijian** (ISO 639-3: fij, Glottocode: fiji1243) Pawley & Sayaba 1990: 148, coded 1: In Fijian there are possessive classifiers which agree with the characteristics of the possessed item. 
    1)    o    tama   i  Eroni          ART father CLF Eroni          ‘Eroni’s father’      2)    na  madrai    kei      Eroni          ART bread  CLF(food)   Eroni          ‘Eroni’s bread      3)    na   bia    mei        Eroni          ART beer   CLF(drink)  Eroni          ‘Eroni’s beer’      4)    na    vale     nei        Eroni          ART  house   CLF(general) Eroni                                                ‘Eroni’s house’
**Barain** (ISO 639-3: bva, Glottocode: bare1279) Lovestrand 2012: 76, coded 0: There are possessor agreement suffixes. However, "they follow the same pattern as the pronominal system, indexing person, gender, and number." They are not classifiers. 
     1)   gólmóɟù            sìŋ́gò            laàwiǵè        gólmó-ɟù           siɲ̀́ɟá -gò        laàwí -gè        house POSS:1.S     nose POSS:2.M    hair POSS:2.F         'my house'         'your nose'      'your hair'
Further reading Johanna Nichols, Balthasar Bickel. 2013. Possessive Classification. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. [Link](http://wals.info/chapter/59) Aikhenvald, Alexandra (2003) Classifiers: a typology of noun categorization devices. Oxford Studies in Typology and Linguistic Theory . Oxford University Press, New York, USA. [Link](https://research.jcu.edu.au/lcrc/people/director/selective-papers/2006.-classifiers-and-noun-classes-semantics-pp.-463-70-of-volume-1-article-1111-of-encyclopedia-of-language-and-linguistics-2nd-edition-edited-by-keith-brown.-elsevier-oxford/at_download/file) Related Features * [GB038: Are there demonstrative classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB038) * [GB057: Are there numeral classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB057)

Feature: Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Clarifying comments:
Is there a morpho-syntactic difference in attributive possession that can be ascribed to alienability?

This feature applies to constructions with both pronominal and nominal possessors.

Typically, inalienable possession applies to the semantic domains of body parts and kinship, but it is sometimes found in other categories that don't align perfectly with the canonical notion of 'alienability', such as part-whole relationships other than body parts, social relationships other than kinship, or things inherently linked to a person (e.g. a person's voice, mental states, or other attributes).

This feature targets splits in possessive marking strategy where different classes of possessum are associated with different constructions, and where one of those possessum classes includes body parts and/or kinship terms, and possibly other categories that have strong semantic associations with their owners, social relationships, or part-whole relationships.
wiki_summary: Is there a morpho-syntactic difference in attributive possession that can be ascribed to alienability?     This feature applies to constructions with both pronominal and nominal possessors.     Typically, inalienable possession applies to the semantic domains of body parts and kinship, but it is sometimes found in other categories that don't align perfectly with the canonical notion of 'alienability', such as part-whole relationships other than body parts, social relationships other than kinship, or things inherently linked to a person (e.g. a person's voice, mental states, or other attributes).    This feature targets splits in possessive marking strategy where different classes of possessum are associated with different constructions, and where one of those possessum classes includes body parts and/or kinship terms, and possibly other categories that have strong semantic associations with their owners, social relationships, or part-whole relationships.     Procedure  1. If there are two or more possessive constructions which vary according to the semantic class of the noun being possessed or the nature of the relationship between possessor and possessed ...  2. And the difference in the construction does not consist solely of a difference in noun class/gender markers, or other classifier systems such as numeral classifiers that also apply to these categories of nouns in the same way in non-possessive constructions ...  3. And the 'inalienable' semantic class associated with one of these strategies contains at least body part terms or at least kinship terms, then code 1.  4. If you code a 1 for this feature, please use the comment field to provide a very brief description of the morphosyntactic distinction between alienable and inalienable possession.     Examples    **Luise&241;o** (ISO 639-3: lui, Glottolog: luis1253)    Luise&241;o possessive constructions are formed by attaching a possessive pronominal prefix (e.g. meaning *my*, *your*, etc.) to the possessed noun. A suffix -ki is also attached to the possessed noun when the relationship between possessor and possessed is alienable: *my sinew* (in my body) = no-ta&817;; *my sinew* (for the bow I am making) = no-ta&817;-ki (Grune 1997: 4). Luise&241;o would be coded 1.     Further reading    Chappell, Hilary, and William MacGregor. 1996. *The grammar of inalienability: A typological perspective on body part terms and the part-whole relation.* Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Haspelmath, Martin. 2018. Explaining alienability contrasts in   adpossessive constructions: Predictability vs. iconicity. *Zeitschrift   Für Sprachwissenschaft* (to appear).    Nichols, Johanna. 1988. On alienable and inalienable possession. In William Shipley, ed. *In honor of Mary Haas: From the Haas Festival Conference on Native American Linguistics*. Berlin: Walter de Gruyter, 557-609.         Related Features    * [GB058: Possessive classifiers](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB058)  * [GB313: Possessive pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB313)  * [GB430: Possession marked by a prefix on the possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB430)  * [GB431: Possession marked by a prefix on the possessed noun](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB431)  * [GB432: Possession marked by a suffix on the possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB432)  * [GB433: Possession marked by a suffix on the possessed noun](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB433)

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature focuses on the relative order of possessor and possessum in an adnominal possession construction. Coding should take into consideration only those possession constructions that are pragmatically unmarked (i.e. not focus). This feature applies to both pronominal and nominal possessors.
wiki_summary: This feature focuses on the relative order of possessor and possessum in an adnominal possession construction. Coding should take into consideration only those possession constructions that are pragmatically unmarked (i.e. not focus). This feature applies to both pronominal and nominal possessors.       Procedure  1. In the pragmatically unmarked order, if the possessor precedes the possessum, code 1.  2. In the pragmatically unmarked order, if the possessor follows the possessum, code 2.  3. If both occur, for example if some possessed nouns precede and some follow, or there is a free choice, then code 3.    TO DO (from Jeremy) Please clarify whether suffixes on possessed nouns count.       Examples  **Nanti** (ISO 639-3: cox, Glottolog: nant1250)    i- banko Ihonira    3msg- house pers.name    *Ihonira's house*    irashi i- banko    3msg.poss 3msg- house    *his house*    Inalienable possession in Nanti is expressed by a prefix on the possessed noun, which indicates the person, number, gender of the possessor. A nominal possessor or possessive pronoun may also be included in the phrase. Nominal possessors follow the possessed noun in unmarked constructions, but may appear to the left of the possessum when they are in contrastive focus. Pronominal possessors occur to the left of possessed nouns. Alienable possession uses the same prefixes as inalienable possession, but also includes an alienable possession suffix on the possessed noun. Nanti would be coded 3. In pragmatically unmarked possessive constructions with nominal possessors, the possessor noun follows the possessed noun. The focus construction in which a possessor nominal occurs before the possessed noun does not trigger a 3 here. However, the fact that pronominal possessors precede possessed nouns in the relevant pragmatically unmarked construction (and, in fact, always when there is an independent possessive pronoun) means that both orders are present in unmarked constructions. This triggers a 3 code.    (Michael 2012: 151-152)    **Southeastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: pom, Glottolog: sout2982)    Both alienable and inalienable possession in Southeastern Pomo involve a construction where the possessor precedes the possessed noun.    hayut xin    hayu-it xin    dog-POSS name    *the dog's name*    bt&803;edit xal    bt&803;ed-it xal    woman-POSS arm    *the woman's arm*    hayutbaq ca    hayu-it-baq ca    dog-POSS-ALIEN house    *the dog's house*    &577;uyitbaq ca    &577;uyi-it-baq ca    3s-POSS-ALIEN house    *his house*    (Moshinsky 1974: 95)    Southeastern Pomo would be coded 1, since only this one order occurs.    **Nzadi** (Glottolog: nzad1234)    The possessor noun or possessive pronoun follows the possessed noun in Nzadi. For some classes of possessed nouns, a genitive linker /&233;/ also occurs before the possessor.    mw&224;&225;n m&464;`    child my    *my child*    &464;g&596;m mw&224;&225;n    drum child    *the child's drum*    oky&225; &233; &464;&769;k&234;m    tail GL monkey    *the monkey's tail*    (Crane et all 2011: 77-83)    Nzadi would be coded 2, since the possessor always follows the possessed noun in pragmatically unmarked constructions.       Further reading    Aikhenvald, Alexandra Y. and R. M. W. Dixon, eds. 2013. *Possession and Ownership: A cross-linguistic typology*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Baron, Irène, Michael Herslund, and Finn Sørensen, eds. 2001. *Dimensions of Possession*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  * [GB430: Possession marked by a prefix on possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB430)  * [GB431: Possession marked by a prefix on possessed noun](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB431)  * [GB432: Possession marked by a suffix on possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB432)  * [GB433: Possession marked by a suffix on possessed noun](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB433)

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Clarifying comments: Do elements expressing predicate adjectival meaning take on verbal morphology? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking, if there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. For example: he runs and he greens.
Function: predication, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender
wiki_summary: Do elements expressing predicate adjectival meaning take on verbal morphology? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking, if there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. For example: "he runs" and "he greens".     Procedure  1. Code 1 if most adjectives used predicatively receive markers which are used on verbs.  2. Code 1 if neither adjectives nor predicative verbs receive marking.  3. Code 1 if adjectives receive the same marking as stative verbs.  4. Code 0 if adjectives are obligatorily accompanied by elements which are not obligatorily accompanied by verbs.  5. Code 1 if most examples of property words follow this pattern, or 0 if most do not; code ? if they are split.       Examples    **Hano** (ISO 639-3: lml, Glottocode: hano1246)     Vari-Bogiri 2011: 62, Coded 1:    Adjectives behave like verbs when they function as predicate, preceded by subject marker and TAM category and they function as stative verbs when they refer to state or process.    **Bangi**  (ISO 639-3: bni, Glottocode: bang1354)      Whitehead 1964 [1899]: 18-19, coded 1:    "There is a copula for predicative adjectives, but adjectives still have to agree with the noun class of the noun (and the noun class markers adjectives and verbs use largely overlap)."     Further reading  Leon Stassen. 2013. Predicative Adjectives. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/118)   Related Features  * [GB069: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB069)

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Clarifying comments: Do elements expressing attributive adjectival meaning receive the same treatment as verbs when verbs are used attributively, i.e. inside an NP? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking. If there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. The result need not be finite, participles would count if that is the way verbs are marked when used attributively. This means that if the language in question forms modifying verbs by participles (“running man”) and this is the same for adjectival roots (“redding man”) then there is a yes here.
Function: attribution, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender
wiki_summary: Do elements expressing attributive adjectival meaning receive the same treatment as verbs when verbs are used attributively, i.e. inside an NP? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking. If there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. The result need not be finite, participles would count if that is the way verbs are marked when used attributively. This means that if the language in question forms modifying verbs by participles (“running man”) and this is the same for adjectival roots (“redding man”) then there is a yes here.       Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used with verbs which are modifiers, and this morpheme is also used with adjectives (defined semantically as property words),   2. And this morpheme is not used when the verb is used predicatively.  3. Code 1 if some core adjective used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs whereas others do not.     Examples  **Baka** (ISO 639-3: bkc, Glottocode: baka1272)       Djoupée 2002: 68-69, coded 0:     "There is no morphologically distinguishable adjective word class in Baka: adjectives always morphologically behave like nouns."    **Bolgo** (ISO 639-3: bvo, Glottocode: bolg1251)     De Rendinger 1949: 181. coded 0:     "There is no adjectival morphology."        **Balinese** (ISO 639-3: ban, Glottocode: bali1278)     Clynes 1995: 242, coded 1:    'In Balinese, adding prefix me- to stative verbs (which are also classified as 'adjectives' by Clynes) have intransitive verb's characteristic(s) but behave as adjectives.'         Further reading  Leon Stassen. 2013. Predicative Adjectives. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](https://wals.info/chapter/118)     Related Features  * [GB068: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB068)

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S NPs, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.
wiki_summary: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S NPs, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if core case is at least sometimes marked on noun phrases by means of bound markers (clitics, affixes, tone, ...).  2. Code 0 if core argument functions are only marked on noun phrases using phonologically free adpositions.   3. Code 0 if core argument functions are only 'marked' by means of constituent order.  4. Code 0 if case marking is not mentioned in the grammar or in the examples. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  5. Code ? if you have reason to believe that the author may have missed case markers or specific case-marking functions of other morphemes.     Examples    **Warrongo** (ISO 639-3: wrg, Glottolog: waru1264)    Warrongo has case markers on every element of the NP (Tsunoda 2011: 342ff):    ```  ngaygo-ngomany-jo gando-nggo gamo bija-n  1SG.GEN-ABL-ERG dog-ERG water.ACC drink-NF  'My dog drank water.'  (Tsunoda 2011: 358)  ```    **Mundang** (ISO 639-3: mua, Glottolog: mund1325)    In Mundang, the plural marker also marks non-subject case. In other words, plural is only marked on nouns in non-subject function (Elders 2000: 392-393):    ```  mè kō bàl-rā ɓè  1SG see elephant-PL PRF  'I have seen elephants.'  (Gloss and translation translated from French)  ```    If the subject argument is plural, the verb carries the plural marker (ibid: 394-396):    ```  zá ngɔ̀ŋ-rā gíì  people slaughter-PL goat  'The people slaughter a goat.'  ```    **Hokkaido Ainu** (ISO 639-3: ain, Glottolog: ainu1240)    Hokkaido Ainu has no morphological cases whatsoever, and is coded 0.     Further reading    Andrew Spencer. 2009. Case as a Morphological Phenomenon. In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 185–199). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. **Note that Spencer does not count clitics as morphological case, while in Grambank they are counted as such.**    Bernard Comrie. 2013. [Alignment of Case Marking of Full Noun Phrases](http://wals.info/chapter/98). In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.     Martin Haspelmath 2009. [Terminology of Case](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/CaseTerminology.pdf). In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 505–517). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press.    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. [Position of Case Affixes](http://wals.info/chapter/51). In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. Feature: Are there morphological cases for independent personal pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: This question is about independent pronouns only; indexes are irrelevant here. Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S pronouns, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.
wiki_summary: This question is about independent pronouns only; indexes are irrelevant here. Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S pronouns, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if core case is at least sometimes marked on pronouns using tone, affixation, suppletion, or any other kind of bound marking.    2. Code 0 if core argument functions are only marked on pronouns with phonologically free adpositions.  3. Code 0 if core argument functions are only marked using constituent order.   4. Code 0 if case marking on pronouns is not mentioned in the grammar or in the examples. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  5. Code ? if you have reason to believe that the author may have missed case markers (e.g. because they don't analyze tone) or specific case-marking functions of other morphemes.     Examples    **Eipomek** (ISO 639-3: eip, Glottolog: eipo1242)    In Eipomek, independent pronominal subjects may be marked with the bound morpheme *-de* (Heeschen 1998: 171-172-):    ```  na-de bo-am-ne-buk, an-de dob-nama-lam  1SG-S carry-PRF-1SG.PRS-when, 2SG-S take.FUT-2SG  'It is me who has carried it, and you will take it.'  (simplified glosses)  ```    **Lardil** (ISO 639-3: lbz, Glottolog: lard1243)    Lardil has different pronouns for different case functions (Klikeid 1976: 108-107):     |          | Nominative | Accusative |   | -------- | ---------- |----------- |   | 1SG      | ngata      | ngithaa-n  |   | 2SG      | nying-ki   | ngimpee-n  |   | 3SG      | ni-ya      | niwee-n    |    **Abun** (ISO 639-3: kgr, Glottolog: abun1252)    In Abun, there are no morphological cases at all, not for pronominal noun phrases and not for non-pronominal noun phrases. It is coded as "0" for this feature (Berry 1999: 48-49). Argument functions are solely coded by means of word order:    ```  men kas  1PL run  'We ran.'    men gwa Isak  1PL hit Isak  'We hit Isak.'    Isak gwa men  Isak hit 1PL  'Isak hit us.'  ```     Further reading    Andrew Spencer. 2009. Case as a Morphological Phenomenon. In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 185–199). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. **Note that Spencer does not count clitics as morphological case, while in Grambank they are counted as such.**    Bernard Comrie. 2013. [Alignment of Case Marking of Pronouns](http://wals.info/chapter/99) . In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Martin Haspelmath 2009. [Terminology of Case](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/CaseTerminology.pdf). In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 505–517). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.
wiki_summary: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if oblique case is marked on nouns or noun phrases using tone, affixation, clitics or any other phonologically bound means.  2. Code 0 if oblique case is only marked on nouns or noun phrases using phonologically free adpositions.  3. Code 0 if oblique case is only marked using constituent order.  4. Code ? if you think there is not enough data or analysis to say whether oblique case is marked on nouns or noun phrases (e.g. because it is not clear whether the marker(s)are phonologically bound, or nothing is mentioned by the author and there are no examples of oblique noun phrases). Mention this in the comment column.     Examples    **Warrongo** (ISO 639-3: wrg, Glottolog: waru1264)    Warrongo has case markers on every element of the NP (Tsunoda 2011: 342ff):    ```  ngali nyina-ya jarribara-ngga yamba-ngga  1DU.NOM sit-IMP good-LOC camp-LOC  'Let's sit down in the good camp.'  (Tsunoda 2011: 343)  ```    **Zuni** (ISO 639-3: zun, Glottolog: zuni1245)    Zuni has a directional enclitic _-kʷin_ and a locative enclitic _-ʔan_. No clear examples are given where we can check whether they really attach to the end of the noun phrase or just to the noun: (my glosses)     ```  kalapa-kʷin  Gallup-DIR  '(He went) to Gallup'  Newman (1965: 66)    kʔakʷe-'w-an  house-PL-LOC  '(We stayed) at their houses'  Newman (1965: 66)  ```    **Ndam** (ISO 639-3: ndm, Glottolog: ndam1251)    In Ndam, the locative of disyllabic nouns with mid-mid melody is formed by lowering the melody to low-low. low-low nouns are turned into locatives by changing their melody to low-high (Bross 1988: 57-58):    ```  būgō 'house' → bùgò 'in the house'  gūjʌ̄n 'my stomach' → gùjʌ̀n 'in my stomach'  gə̀lè 'concession' → gə̀lé 'in the concession'  ```    **Fore** (ISO 639-3: for, Glottolog: fore1270)    Fore marks allative case by means of the enclitic _=ti_ (Scott 1978: 104, 109-111):    ```  pi nkáu='i wa-y-e  that place=ALL go-he-INDIC  'He goes to that place.'  (Scott 1978: 109; glosses and transcription slightly adapted and clitic mark added)  ```  **Holoholo** (ISO 639-3: hoo, Glottolog: holo1240)    Various Bantu languages have one or more 'locative noun classes', which qualify as oblique case markers for the purposes of Grambank. Holoholo is a good example, having three 'locative' noun class 'prefixes' (classes 16, 17, 18 in Coupez 1955: 36, 38), which are in fact proclitics (they only attach to the noun, which is the first element of the noun phrase) and thus count as both prepositions and oblique case markers here.    ```  heelungu  ha-lungu  LOC-country  'In the country.'    kwilungu  ku-lungu  LOC-country  'Close to the country.'    mwilungu  mu-lungu  LOC-country  'In the country.'  ```    **Hokkaido Ainu** (ISO 639-3: ain, Glottolog: ainu1240)    Hokkaido Ainu has no morphological cases whatsoever, and is coded 0.     Further reading    Andrew Spencer. 2009. Case as a Morphological Phenomenon. In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 185–199). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. Note that Spencer does not count clitics as morphological case, while in Grambank they are counted as such.    Martin Haspelmath 2009. [Terminology of Case](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/CaseTerminology.pdf). In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 505–517). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press.    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. [Position of Case Affixes](http://wals.info/chapter/51). In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. Feature: Are there morphological cases for independent oblique personal pronominal arguments (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Are independent personal pronouns morphologically marked for oblique case (i.e. not S/A/P)? Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.
wiki_summary: Are independent personal pronouns morphologically marked for oblique case (i.e. not S/A/P)? Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if oblique case is marked on pronouns using tone, affixation, suppletion, or any other phonologically bound means.  2. Code 0 if oblique case is only marked on pronouns using phonologically free adpositions .  3. Code 0 if oblique case is only marked using constituent order.  4. Code ? if you think there is not enough data or analysis to say whether oblique case is marked on pronouns (e.g. because it is not clear whether the marker(s)are phonologically bound, or nothing is mentioned by the author and there are no examples of oblique noun phrases). Mention this in the comment column.     Examples    **Aneityum** (ISO 639-3: aty, Glottolog: anei1239)    In Aneityum, there are oblique prefixes for independent personal pronouns (Lynch 2000: 119-120):    ```  a-nworen is ithii, eris ika va-ñ Inm̃anjap̃itac  LOC-place 3sg.P one 3PL.P call GOAL-TR Inm̃anjap̃itac  'to a place which is called Inm̃anjap̃itac'  ```    **Ritarungo** (ISO 639-3: rit, Glottolog: rita1239)    In Ritarungo, different pronouns are used for different case functions, and the dative pronoun is the same as the genitive pronoun (Heath 1980: 44). In the following paradigm, only the stems for first exclusive dual nominative (_liñu_) and dative (_ñalaŋu_) can really be called suppletive:      |          | Nominative | Dative     |   | -------- | ---------- |----------- |   | 1SG      | ra         | raku       |   | 1ExDu    | liñu       | ñalaŋu     |   | 1ExPL    | napu       | napuluŋu   |   | 1InDu    | li         | lici       |   | 1InPL    | lima       | limalaŋu   |    **Abun** (ISO 639-3: kgr, Glottolog: abun1252)    In Abun, there are no morphological cases at all, not for pronominal noun phrases and not for non-pronominal noun phrases. It is coded as "0" for this feature (Berry 1999: 48-49). Core argument functions are solely coded by means of word order, and non-core argument roles (such as the dative) feature a phonologically free preposition:    ```  men kadum men bi tiket is ye-suk-mise  1PL show 1PL bi ticket is PERS-NOM-evil  'We showed our tickets to the police.'  (Berry 1999: 52)  ```     Further reading    Andrew Spencer. 2009. Case as a Morphological Phenomenon. In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 185–199). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. **Note that Spencer does not count clitics as morphological case, while in Grambank they are counted as such.**    Bernard Comrie. 2013. [Alignment of Case Marking of Pronouns](http://wals.info/chapter/99) . In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Martin Haspelmath 2009. [Terminology of Case](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/CaseTerminology.pdf). In A. L. Malchukov & A. Spencer (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Case* (pp. 505–517). Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press. Feature: Are there prepositions?
Clarifying comments: Prepositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They precede the noun phrase they occur with. Proclitics (case markers that only occur noun phrase initially) count as prepositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as prepositions. If there is only one preposition, this is enough for a 1 here.
wiki_summary: Prepositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They precede the noun phrase they occur with. Proclitics (case markers that only occur noun phrase initially) count as prepositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as prepositions. If there is only one preposition, this is enough for a 1 here.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar mentions prepositions or proclitics in the language and there is no evidence (in examples) that the author's definition of 'preposition' conflicts with the one used in Grambank.  2. Code 1 if you find examples of prepositions or proclitics in the language.  3. Code 0 if a grammar mentions postpositions or enclitics, but no prepositions or proclitics.  4. Code 0 if a language does not appear to have any adpositions.     Examples    **Yongbei Zhuang** (ISO 639-3: zyb, Glottolog: yong1276)    Yongbei Zhuang, coded as 1 (Luo 2008: 335-336): the term 'preposition' is mentioned and examples are given. There is no indication that Luo's definition deviates from ours.    Examples of prepositions are *ʔdi⁶* 'with' (comitative), *ʔju⁵* 'in' (locative), *haɯ³* 'to' (dative):    ```  ʔdi⁶ ʔaːu¹ '(talk) with uncle'  ʔju⁵ ʔbon⁵ '(sleep) in bed'  haɯ³ te¹ '(tell) to him'  ```    **Shabo** (ISO 639-3: sbf, Glottolog: shab1252)    Shabo, coded as 0 (Kibebe 2015: 324): it is mentioned that there are only postpositions.    ```  k̛on-e-m ponti heleti-ŋga  tree-DEF-M on bird-exist  'There is a bird on the tree'    ufe-nda kon-e-m ʃunʃeti hopu-d-mo  person-FPL tree-DEF-M under rest-2/3PL-PROG  'Women/people are resting under the tree.'  ```    **Bats** (ISO 639-3: bbl, Glottolog: bats1242)    Bats, coded as 0 (Holisky 1994: 168-170): a number of examples of postpositions are given, but prepositions are not mentioned or found in the grammar.    ```  t'iv-en mak Va  bridge-DAT on is  'He is on the bridge'    t'iv-en k'ik'el Jaix-n-as  bridge-DAT under go-AOR-1SG/ERG  'I walked under the bridge'  ```    **Ndam** (ISO 639-3: ndm, Glottolog: ndam1251)    Ndam, coded as ? (Bross 1988: 1-60): possibly no adpositions; the locative is said to be formed with tone, but the description is not comprehensive enough and does not contain enough data to be certain that there are no adpositions.     ```  Der Lokativ wird rein tonal gebildet. Die vorliegenden Belege haben in der Grundform   entweder die Tonstruktur Mittel-Mittel, die sich im Lokativ zu Tief-Tief verändert. ...  oder Tief-Tief, die sich in Tief-Hoch wandelt.  (The locative is formed purely by means of tone. The following examples have Mid-Mid tones  as underlying melodies, which is changed into Low-Low in the locative. ... or Low-Low,  which is changed into Low-High.)  (Bross 1988: 58)    būgō 'house' → bùgò 'in the house'  gūjʌ̄n 'my belly' → gùjʌ̀n 'in my belly'  gə̀lè 'concession' → g͏èlé 'in the concession'    ```    **Panamint** (ISO 639-3: par, Glottolog: pana1305)    Panamint is a good example of a language with inpositions (cf. Dryer 2013), which is coded 0 here. Inpositions in Panamint come right after the noun, before other nominal modifiers, as is illustrated below for *tukkwantü* 'under', which comes in between a pronoun and an attributive numeral, and for *ma* 'from', which comes in between a noun and an adjective (Dayley 1989: 257):    ```  Mümmi tukkwantü pahittünna.  you.all-O under three  'It's under you three'      Ohipim ma nati’iwantünna tiyaitaiha satü.  cold from mean-O died that  'He died from a mean cold'  ```     Further reading    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. [Order of Adposition and Noun Phrase](http://wals.info/chapter/85). In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.     Related Features    * [GB027	Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB027)    * [GB075	Are there postpositions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB075)

Feature: Are there postpositions?
Clarifying comments: Postpositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They follow the noun phrase they occur with. Enclitics (markers that only occur noun phrase finally) count as postpositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as postpositions. If there is only one postposition, this is enough for a 1 here.
wiki_summary: Postpositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They follow the noun phrase they occur with. Enclitics (markers that only occur noun phrase finally) count as postpositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as postpositions. If there is only one postposition, this is enough for a 1 here.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar mentions postpositions or enclitics in the language and there is no evidence (in examples) that the author's definition of 'postposition' conflicts with the one used in Grambank.  2. Code 1 if you find examples of postpositions or enclitics in the language.  3. Code 0 if a grammar mentions prepositions or proclitics, but no postpositions or enclitics.  4. Code 0 if a language does not appear to have any adpositions.     Examples    **Lagwan** (ISO 639-3: kot, Glottolog: lagw1237)    Lagwan is coded 1 in Grambank. Lukas (1936: 56) attests two postpositions, temporal *ká* and *fa* 'except'. He gives only the following examples, from which it is impossible to check whether they are postpositions or suffixes, but as there is no evidence that Lukas' definition of postposition conflicts with ours elsewhere, this is not considered a problem.    ```  fázàr ká  early.morning TEMP  'In the early morning.'    méa ɣo-ne zumi-a-tan šēn kii fa  people city-PROX food-GEN-3PL have.not fish except  'The people of this city have no food but fish.'    (my glosses; ɣo-ne is erroneously represented as ro-ne in the original example)  ```    **Kwini** (ISO 639-3: gww, Glottolog: kwin1241)    In Kwini, case relations are marked with bound morphemes (in a morphosyntactic sense, but not in a phonological sense) that are at times attached to the end of the noun phrase, where they qualify as enclitics and thus postpositions, and at other times attached to the initial word of the noun phrase, where they qualify as inpositions (McGregor 1993: 36-41). Because they behave as postpositions at least in some cases, Kwini is coded 1 for the purpose of Grambank. The following is a list of postpositions found in Kwini, adopted from McGregor (1993: 36):    ```  ngindalu LOC(ative)  gu DAT(ive)  yanga ABL(ative)  we PURP(osive)  nyine INST(rumental)  gude COMIT(ative)  nangga GEN(itive)  miya DU(al)  ```    **Siwi** (ISO 639-3: siz, Glottolog: siwi1239)    Souag (2010: 306) states that "Siwi (...) is exclusively prepositional", which is sufficient to code it 0.    **Baharna Arabic** (ISO 639-3: abv, Glottolog: baha1259)    In a sketch of Baharna Arabic, Holes (2006:241-255) lists plenty of prepositions, but no postpositions. This is sufficient to assume an absence of postpositions in this language.    **Panamint** (ISO 639-3: par, Glottolog: pana1305)    Panamint is a good example of a language with inpositions (cf. Dryer 2013), which is coded 0 here. Inpositions in Panamint come right after the noun, before other nominal modifiers, as is illustrated below for *tukkwantü* 'under', which comes in between a pronoun and an attributive numeral, and for *ma* 'from', which comes in between a noun and an adjective (Dayley 1989: 257):    ```  Mümmi tukkwantü pahittünna.  you.all-O under three  'It's under you three'      Ohipim ma nati’iwantünna tiyaitaiha satü.  cold from mean-O died that  'He died from a mean cold'  ```     Further reading    Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. [Order of Adposition and Noun Phrase](http://wals.info/chapter/85). In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.      Related Features    * [GB027	Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB027)    * [GB074	Are there prepositions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB074)

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that only mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Clarifying comments: The portmanteau morphemes in questions could be of person, number or TAM or markers of reciprocity, location, benefactive, direction etc. If there are affixes devoted to TAM solely these are also counted. Person markings expressing more than one argument, relative markers or relative pronouns are also included here if they form a phonological unit with the root. The outcome of this affixation has to be a finite verb, i.e. an affix that makes a verb into an instrumental noun for example would not count. This feature is not logically triggered by the following features, but if you have coded 1 for either of these you are advised to consider whether it would also result in a 1 for this feature: 152, 151, 149, 82, 83, 84, 107, 104, 103, 147, 148, 114 and 115. The reason why there is no strict logical dependency is because while they all deal with markings on the verb, these can theoretically be other markings than prefixes, proclitics, enclitics or suffixes (reduplication, tone and suppletion). Since this kind of marking is rare, we recommend all coders being aware of this link even though it is not technically a strict dependency.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change
wiki_summary: The portmanteau morphemes in questions could be of person, number or TAM or markers of reciprocity, location, benefactive, direction etc. If there are affixes devoted to TAM solely these are also counted. Person markings expressing more than one argument, relative markers or relative pronouns are also included here if they form a phonological unit with the root. The outcome of this affixation has to be a finite verb, i.e. an affix that makes a verb into an instrumental noun for example would not count. This feature is not logically triggered by the following features, but if you have coded "1" for either of these you are advised to consider whether it would also result in a "1" for this feature: 152, 151, 149, 82, 83, 84, 107, 104, 103, 147, 148, 114 and 115. The reason why there is no strict logical dependency is because while they all deal with markings on the verb, these can theoretically be other markings than prefixes, proclitics, enclitics or suffixes (reduplication, tone and suppletion). Since this kind of marking is rare, we recommend all coders being aware of this link even though it is not technically a strict dependency.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are elements coding something other than just A, S or P,  2. And these elements form a phonological unit with the verb,  3. And they occur before the verb,  4. And the outcome of the affixation is a verb (not e.g. a nominalisation).       Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	    * The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound  * Only one or very few       Examples     Further reading  Not specificaly about non-participant prefix marking but there is interesting  work on the reasons why suffixation appears to be more prevalent than  prefixation. So far the best statistics is WALS Chapter 26: http://wals.info/chapter/26 and the most recent paper on the potential explanation is    Himmelmann, Nikolaus. 2014. Asymmetries in the prosodic phrasing of function words: Another look at the suffixing preference. Language 90/4. 927-960.      Related Features  GB080: Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
