Feature: Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Clarifying comments: This affix must be stem-internal and dedicated to a particular purpose, either derivational or inflectional (see general definitions for more information on productivity and dedicated functions). In keeping with existing data, if the only infixation process described for a language involves reduplication, please code 0 but be sure to note in the comments field that infixing reduplication is present.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change
wiki_summary: This affix must be stem-internal and dedicated to a particular purpose, either derivational or inflectional (see general definitions for more information on productivity and dedicated functions). In keeping with existing data, if the only infixation process described for a language involves reduplication, please code 0 but be sure to note in the comments field that infixing reduplication is present.       Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is at least one infix mentioned which is used for derivational, aspectual or voice-changing purposes.  2. Code 0 if no infixes are mentioned, if only a very small number of non-productive infixes are mentioned, or if the only evidence of infixation consists of fossilized forms.       Examples    **Kashaya** (ISO: kju, Glottolog: kash1280)    In Kashaya a plural action meaning (e.g. an action performed multiple times on the same object, or an action performed on multiple objects) is expressed through a morpheme that has both suffix and infix allomorphs. One infix allomorph is -t-, which is infixed before a root-final consonant.    | Verb | Plural Action Form | Meaning |  | --- | --- | --- |  | p<sup>h</sup>anem- | p<sup>h</sup>ane-t-m- | 'hit with the fist' |  | p<sup>h</sup>i&577;ya:q- | p<sup>h</sup>iya-t-q- | 'recognize' |  | p<sup>h</sup>a'co:q<sup>w</sup>- | p<sup>h</sup>a'co:-t-q<sup>w</sup>- | 'stab' |    (Buckley 2000: 7)     Kashaya would be coded 1.       Further reading  Yu, Alan. 2007. A Natural History of Infixation. Oxford: Oxford University Press.     Related Features  * [GB079: Verbal prefixes/proclitics](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB079)  * [GB080: Verbal suffixes/enclitics](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB080)

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Clarifying comments:
This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. On the verb here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of present tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both on the verb and auxiliary. However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.

Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for GB082, but (0) for [GB084 (future tense)](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas present tense has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.
wiki_summary: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of present tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.    Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for GB082, but (0) for [GB084 (future tense)](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.     Procedure  1. Find section discussion tense in the grammatical description  2. If present tense is not explicitly defined check the descriptions of the other tenses (if there are any)  3. Code 1 if there is an affix, suppletion, tonal marking or reduplication used to mark present tense on the verb.  4. If present tense is only marked by absence of other markers, code (0).  5. If the language is described as having a "non-past" tense and it is overtly marked, code it as (1) for GB082, but (0) for GB084, and a (1) for GB083. (Granted that it is a bound marker and not free-standing.)       Examples  **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Swedish has a present tense marker "-r" (Skirgård p.c.), as the table below shows. Swedish is coded as a 1 for this feature.    | | present | past | infinitive |  |-------- | ---- | ----------- |-- |  | wash dishes | _diskar_ | _diskade_ |_diska_|   | swim | _simmar_ | _simmade_ | _simma_ |     Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Tense. Cambridge University Press  * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf)       Related Features    These are the currently active features that are related.There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here.     * [GB082	Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082)  * [GB083	Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB083)  * [GB084	Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB084)  * [GB086	Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB086)  * [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095)  * [GB110	Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB110)  * [GB119	Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB119)  * [GB120	Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB120)  * [GB121	Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB121)  * [GB309	Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB309)  * [GB312	Is there overt morphological marking on the particle")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB521)

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Clarifying comments:
This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. On the verb here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing overt marking of past tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that past tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both on the verb and auxiliary. However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.

It can be difficult to distinguish perfective/perfect/punctual aspect from past tense, since past tense tends to be perfective. If this is an issue, bring it up for discussion.
wiki_summary: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing overt marking of past tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that past tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.    It can be difficult to distinguish perfective/perfect/punctual aspect from past tense, since past tense tends to be perfective. If this is an issue, bring it up for discussion.     Procedure  1. Find section discussion tense in the grammatical description  2. If past tense is not explicitly defined check the descriptions of the other tenses and moods (if there are any)  3. Code 1 if there is an affix, suppletion, tonal marking or reduplication used to mark past tense on the verb.  4. If past tense is only marked by absence of other markers, code (0).  5. If the language is described as having a "non-past" tense and it is overtly marked, code it as (1) for GB082, but (0) for GB084, and a (1) for GB083. (Granted that it is a bound marker and not free-standing.)  6. If unsure on whether it's a aspect marker or past tense marker, bring it up for discussion in the group.       Examples  **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Swedish has a past tense marker "-de" (Skirgård p.c.), as the table below shows. There is also vowel-alternative for tense, as is common in other Germanic languages as well. Swedish is coded as a 1 for this feature.    | | present | past | infinitive |  |-------- | ---- | ----------- |-- |  | wash dishes | _diskar_ | _diskade_ |_diska_|   | swim | _simmar_ | _simmade_ | _simma_ |  | dance | _dansar_ | _dansade_ | _dansa_ |  | fly | _flyger_ | _flög_ | _flyga_ |         Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Tense. Cambridge University Press  * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf)  * Östen Dahl, Viveka Velupillai. 2013. The Past Tense. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  (Available online at http://wals.info/chapter/66, Accessed on 2016-08-08.). [link here](http://wals.info/chapter/66)     Related Features  These are the currently active features that are related. Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Clarifying comments:
This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. On the verb here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of future tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both on the verb and auxiliary. However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.

Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for [GB082](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082), but (0) for this feature (GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas present tense has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.

It can be hard to distinguish future tense from different modal categories, after all if something is in the future it has not yet occurred and can be construed as something wished for, planned, intended etc rather than actually on the concrete timeline of events. This is why it's necessary to take extra notice on sections on mood, especially irrealis, when coding for future tense.

If a language only has future tense under negation, this does not count for this feature. It needs to be present for affirmation as well. [This was brought up in this issue thread.](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/62). The reason for this is that conditions such as only under negation are likely to give rise to quite different analysis by different linguists (hence hard to ensure comparability) and might also be overlooked. If we were to treat such marginal cases as 1 we would most likely have to go back to a lot of the cases that were coded as 0 and re-evaluate their coding more thoroughly.
wiki_summary: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of future tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.    Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for [GB082](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082), but (0) for this feature (GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.    It can be hard to distinguish future tense from different modal categories, after all if something is in the future it has not yet occurred and can be construed as something wished for, planned, intended etc rather than actually on the concrete timeline of events. This is why it's necessary to take extra notice on sections on mood, especially irrealis, when coding for future tense.    If a language only has future tense under negation, this does not count for this feature. It needs to be present for affirmation as well. [This was brought up in this issue thread.](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/62). The reason for this is that conditions such as "only under negation" are likely to give rise to quite different analysis by different linguists (hence hard to ensure comparability) and might also be overlooked. If we were to treat such marginal cases as "1" we would most likely have to go back to a lot of the cases that were coded as "0" and re-evaluate their coding more thoroughly.     Procedure  1. Find section discussion tense in the grammatical description  2. If future tense is not explicitly defined check the descriptions of the other tenses and moods (if there are any)  3. Code 1 if there is an affix, suppletion, tonal marking or reduplication used to mark future tense on the verb.  4. If future tense is only marked by absence of other markers, code (0).  5. If the language is described as having a "non-past" tense and it is overtly marked, code it as (1) for GB082, but (0) for GB084  6. If unsure on wether it's a mood marker or future tense marker, bring it up for discussion in the group.       Examples  **Acholi** (ISO 639-3: ach, Glottocode: acol1236)    In Acholi, future tense is marked by an infix _"bi"_ which derives from the verb "to come"  - _bino_. Acholi is coded as 1 for this feature. Malandra (1952:78-79) gives the following examples:    | past | present | future |  | ---- | ----------- |-- |  | _àyecò_ I tore | _àyécò_ I tear |_ábíyecò_ I will (shall) tear|   | _àkayò_ I reaped | _àkáyò_ I reap |_àbíkayò_ I will (shall) reap|        Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Tense. Cambridge University Press  * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf)  * Dahl, Östen and Viveka Velupillai. 2013. The Future Tense.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  (Available online at http://wals.info/chapter/67, Accessed on 2016-08-08. [link here](http://wals.info/chapter/67)  * Malandra, Alfred. 1952. A new Acholi grammar. (Eagle language study serie, gle language study series.) Nairobi, Kampala & Dar es Salaam: Eagle Press. xi+159pp.     Related Features  These are the currently active features that are related. There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here.   * [GB082	Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Clarifying comments:
This feature is concerned with bound marking of imperfective/perfective grammatical aspects. These categories could go by the name of punctual/continuous, preterit/progressive etc. The answer could be yes even if it's only one that is overtly marked, i.e. if imperfective is by affix and perfective by auxiliary for example. Please take notice that GB310 and GB86 are not covering exactly the same functions, they cover more grammatical aspects than punctual/continuous. If this marking is only relevant for a small subset of verbs, alert patron and discuss.

If this distinction is only available in some TAM-conditions, this counts as well. For example, if there isn't an aspectual distinction in the past but only in the present, this still triggers a '1'.
wiki_summary: This feature is concerned with bound marking of imperfective/perfective grammatical aspects. These categories could go by the name of punctual/continuous, preterit/progressive etc. The answer could be "yes" even if it's only one that is overtly marked, i.e. if imperfective is by affix and perfective by auxiliary for example. Please take notice that GB310 and GB86 are not covering exactly the same functions, they cover more grammatical aspects than punctual/continuous. If this marking is only relevant for a small subset of verbs, alert patron and discuss.    If this distinction is only available in some TAM-conditions, this counts as well. For example, if there isn't an aspectual distinction in the past but only in the present, this still triggers a '1'.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an affix, suppletion, tonal marking or reduplication used to mark punctual or continuous aspect on either the main verb  2. If this is only true for a small set of verbs, alert patron and discuss (this is because suppletion can apply on small sets in a way that is not intended to be covered by this feature).  3. If only one of the aspects is overly marked, code 1  4. If there is no marking of aspect at all, code 0  5. If it is not possible to tease apart present tense and imperfective, and that is the only possible relevant construction in the language for this feature, code as "?".     Examples  **Chukchii** (ISO 639-3: ckt, Glottocode: chuk1273)    In Chukchii, there is aspectual marking on the verb that distinguishes progressive aspect from a neutral aspect. The suffix differs between men's and women's language (_-rkə_ / _-ccə) and varies somewhat with phonological context. Dunn(1999:176, 185) gives the examples below. Chukchii is coded as a 1 for this feature.    ||non-fut | future |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |  Neutral aspect | _jetɣʔi_  ’she came’ | _rejetɣʔe_  ’she will come’ |  Progressive aspect | _jetərkən/jetəccən_  ’she is coming’ | _rejetərkən/rejetəccən_  ’she will be coming’ |       Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Tense. Cambridge University Press  * Comrie, Bernard. 1976. Aspect. Cambridge University Press [link to PDF](https://user.phil-fak.uni-duesseldorf.de/~filip/Comrie.Aspect.pdf)  * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf)  * Dahl, Östen & Viveka Velupillai. 2013. The Past Tense. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  (Available online at http://wals.info/chapter/66, Accessed on 2016-08-08.). [link here](http://wals.info/chapter/66)  * Dunn,  Michael J.  1999. A Grammar of Chukchi. Canberra: Australian National University. (Doctoral dissertation, Australian National University; xxiii+386pp.)     Related Features    These are the currently active features that are related. There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here.   * [GB082	Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082)  * [GB083	Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB083)  * imperfective aspect available on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB086)  * [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?] (https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095)  * [GB110	Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB110)  * [GB119	Can mood be marked by an Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element indexing/cross-referencing the S argument and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb. The index needs to follow the verbal host it is bound to.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the S argument (e.g. most verbs code the S argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern. If it is impossible to identify the major pattern, code all main patterns (this might be the case in the so-called split-S/stative-active languages).  3. If the verb shows overt agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments, as the English _-s_ in _he go-es_ vs. _we go_), still code as 1. The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples    **Example 1: Korowai** (khe/koro1312; van Enk and de Vries 1997: 87-90, 183)    Code as 1 (the fact that there are zero morphemes and syncretism of 2nd and 3rd person does not matter)    Independent verb forms express status, subject person-number, mood, and aspect. They are used in independent (final) clauses, subordinate clauses, and chained (medial) clauses. Dependent verb forms do not express subject person and number.    The person-number suffixes in the realis are as follows:    * 1SG _-le_/_-nde_  * 1PL _-le_/_-te_/_-nde_  * 2/3SG zero/_-l_  * 2/3PL _-te(l)_    This same set is used with small variations for the other statuses, moods, and aspects. Intentional and imperative mood take an entirely different set of person-number endings, distinguishing second from third person in both singular and plural. The 'zero' ending (stem-only form) is the usual non-1SG realis form.    ```  ye   khén-telo-do          yakhatimekho  he   angry-be.3SG.REAL-DS  renounce.3SG.REAL  'He went angry and she renounced.'  ```    **Example 2:** Bukiyip (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    Code as 0.     Argument indexes (person-number-gender) vary depending on the verb class. There are two intransitive classes:    - Class 5 (intr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(BEN/DIR)  - Class 6 (intr., small number of stative verbs): V-OBJ    For coding one considers only the major pattern (here Class 5 with suffixes, as in (a)), Class 6 with S suffixes from the object suffixes paradigm, as in (b), is a minor pattern and should be ignored, so Bukiyip is coded as 0.    ```  (a) Major pattern:      Ny-é-nak-moli         malmu?      2SG.SBJ-REAL-go-come  why      'Why did you come?' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 42)    (b) Minor pattern:       éblany-iwe.      be.ashamed-1SG.OBJ      'I am ashamed' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 31)  ```     Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:  Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567.     Related Features  [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element immediately before and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb denoting the S participant.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the S argument (e.g. most verbs code the S argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern unless it is impossible to identify a major pattern (might be the case in the so-called split-S/stative-active languages), then code both patterns.  3. If the verb shows overt agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments, as the English _-s_ in _he go-es_ vs. _we go_), this is still a "1". The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples  **Example 1:** Bukiyip (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    Code as 1:     Argument indexes (person-number-gender) vary depending on the verb class. There are two intransitive classes:    - Class 5 (intr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(BEN/DIR)  - Class 6 (intr., small number of stative verbs): V-OBJ    For coding one considers only the major pattern (here Class 5) and codes Bukiyip as 1.    ```  Ny-é-nak-moli         malmu?  2SG.SBJ-REAL-go-come  why  'Why did you come?' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 42)  ```       Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:   Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567.     Related Features  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element immediately after and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb denoting the A participant.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the A argument (e.g. most verbs code the A argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern. If it is impossible to identify the major pattern, code all main patterns.  3. If the verb shows overt indexing/agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments, as the English _-s_ in _he eat-s_ vs. _we eat_), this is still a 1. The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples    **Example 1: Korowai** (khe/koro1312; van Enk and de Vries 1997: 87-90, 183)    Code as 1 (the fact that there are zero morphemes and syncretism of 2nd and third person do no matter)    Independent verb forms express status, subject person-number, mood, and aspect. They are used in independent (final) clauses, subordinate clauses, and chained (medial) clauses. Dependent verb forms do not express subject person and number.    The person-number suffixes in the realis are as follows:  * 1SG _-le_/_-nde_  * 1PL _-le_/_-te_/_-nde_  * 2/3SG zero/_-l_  * 2/3PL _-te(l)_    This same set is used with small variations for the other statuses, moods, and aspects. Intentional and imperative mood take an entirely different set of person-number endings, distinguishing second from third person in both singular and plural. The 'zero' ending (stem-only form) is the usual non-1SG realis form.    ```  nu	maun		mi-p  I	water		drink-1SG.INTENT  'I want to drink water.' (van Enk and de Vries 1997: 67)  ```    **Example 2:** Cashinahua (cash1254/cbs; Camargo 2007: 1876)    Code as 1    "There is no person agreement in Cashinahua. The verb may agree only in number, agreement in the singular being zero marked. There is no agreement in number with the predicate if the subject is the 1pl or 2pl pronoun." (Camargo 2007: 1876)    ```  kaman-an baka  ʂau  pi-mis-bu.  dog-ERG  fish  bone eat-HAB-PL  ‘The dogs eat fish bones.’ (Camargo 2007: 1877)    paku-n    nam-ɨ-Ø   pi-mis.  Paku-ERG  meat-OBJ  eat-HAB  ‘Paco always eats meat.’ (Camargo 2007: 1873)    ɨa, ɨn  daja-mis-ki.  me  I   work-HAB-ASS  ‘As for me, I work.’ (Camargo 2007: 1875)    ɨan,   ɨn   namɨ   pi-mis-ki.  I      I    meat   eat-hab-ass  ‘As for me, I eat meat.’ (Camargo 2007: 1875)  ```      **Example 3: Bukiyip** (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    Code as 0.    The verb in Bukiyip indexes S, A, and P arguments. The A argument is always expressed as a prefix.    ```  Monoken  da         wo   ny-ú-klipw-e              ye?  why      therefore  NEG  2SG.SBJ-IRR-tell-1SG.OBJ  NEG  'Why didn't you tell me?' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 42)  ```     Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:   Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567. Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element immediately before and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb denoting the A participant.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the A argument (e.g. most verbs code the A argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern. If it is impossible to identify the major pattern, code all main patterns.  3. If the verb shows overt indexing/agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments), this is still a 1. The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples  **Example 1: Bukiyip** (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    Code as 1.    The verb in Bukiyip indexes S, A, and P arguments. The A argument is always expressed as a prefix.    ```  Monoken  da         wo   ny-ú-klipw-e              ye?  why      therefore  NEG  2SG.SBJ-IRR-tell-1SG.OBJ  NEG  'Why didn't you tell me?' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 42)  ```   Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:   Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567.     Related Features  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element immediately after and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb denoting the P participant.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the P argument (e.g. most verbs code the A argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern. If it is impossible to identify the major pattern, code all main patterns.  3. If the verb shows overt indexing/agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments), this is still a 1. The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples    **Example 1: Bukiyip** (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    Code as 1:     The verb in Bukiyip indexes S, A, and P arguments. The position of the argument person-number-gender indexes varies depending on the verb class:    - transitive classes:      * Class 1 (tr., small in number): SBJ-OBJ-V      * Class 2 (tr., large in number): SBJ-V-OBJ      * Class 3 (tr., large in number): SBJ-(OBJ)-V      * Class 4 (tr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(OBJ)      * Class 7 (tr., one verb, obigatory subject NP): SBJ-V-(OBJ)    - transitive classes:      * Class 5 (intr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(BEN/DIR)      * Class 6 (intr., small number of stative verbs): V-OBJ    It is impossible to identify one major position of P indexes, as both class 2 and 4 (suffixes), as well as class 3 (prefixes) are large in number, so code as 1 for both GB093 and GB094, so code as having both suffixes and prefixes.    ```  Monoken  da         wo   ny-ú-klipw-e              ye?  why      therefore  NEG  2SG.SBJ-IRR-tell-1SG.OBJ  NEG  'Why didn't you tell me?' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 42)  ```      **Example 3: Korowai** (khe/koro1312; van Enk and de Vries 1997: 87-90, 183)    Code as 0 (no indexing of the P argument on the verb)    Independent verb forms express status, subject person-number, mood, and aspect. They are used in independent (final) clauses, subordinate clauses, and chained (medial) clauses. Dependent verb forms do not express subject person and number.    ```  nu  maun   mi-p  I   water  drink-1SG.INTENT  'I want to drink water.' (van Enk and de Vries 1997: 67)  ```     Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:   Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567.     Related Features  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element immediately before and phonologically bound to the verb or auxiliary verb denoting the O participant.  2. If there is some variation in the position of marking of the P argument (e.g. most verbs code the A argument with a suffix, but a couple use a prefix) consider only the major pattern. If it is impossible to identify the major pattern, code all main patterns.  3. If the verb shows overt indexing/agreement only with some arguments (e.g. only with animate arguments or only with 3rd person singular arguments), this is still a 1. The question aims to capture which of the three arguments S, A, and P trigger indexing/agreement and not how much indexing/agreement there is.     Examples  **Example 1: Yuracaré** (yuz/yura1255; van Gijn 2006)    Code as 1    Subjects and objects are marked on the verb; subjects are suffixes and objects are prefixes (van Gijn 2006: 144-145).    ```  ti‐bobo‐m  1SG.OBJ‐hit‐2SG.SBJ  ‘You hit me.’ (van Gijn 2006: 145)  ````    **Example 2: Bukiyip** (ape/buki1249; Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 25–33)    The verb in Bukiyip indexes S, A, and P arguments. The position of the argument person-number-gender indexes varies depending on the verb class:    - transitive classes:      * Class 1 (tr., small in number): SBJ-OBJ-V      * Class 2 (tr., large in number): SBJ-V-OBJ      * Class 3 (tr., large in number): SBJ-(OBJ)-V      * Class 4 (tr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(OBJ)      * Class 7 (tr., one verb, obigatory subject NP): SBJ-V-(OBJ)    - transitive classes:      * Class 5 (intr., relatively large in number): SBJ-V-(BEN/DIR)      * Class 6 (intr., small number of stative verbs): V-OBJ    It is impossible to identify one major position of P indexes, as both class 2 and 4 (suffixes), as well as class 3 (prefixes) are large in number, so code as 1 for both GB093 and GB094.    ```  H-a-b-ah                        (oub).  3SG.M.SBJ-REAL-3PL.OBJ(16)-eat  coconuns[16]  'He ate (coconuts).' (Conrad and Wogiga 1991: 27)  ```      **Example 3: Korowai** (khe/koro1312; van Enk and de Vries 1997: 87-90, 183)    Code as 0 (no indexing of the P argument on the verb)    Independent verb forms express status, subject person-number, mood, and aspect. They are used in independent (final) clauses, subordinate clauses, and chained (medial) clauses. Dependent verb forms do not express subject person and number.    ```  nu  maun   mi-p  I   water  drink-1SG.INTENT  'I want to drink water.' (van Enk and de Vries 1997: 67)  ```     Further reading  [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100)    If in doubts about S, A, and P:   Haspelmath, Martin. 2011. On S, A, P, T, and R as comparative concepts for alignment typology. Linguistic Typology 15: 3, 535–567.     Related Features  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Clarifying comments:
**ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**

“Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for 1. This pattern includes cases referred to as (alignment) split in the literature.
Polarity (i.e. positive vs. negative distinction) does not count as a TAM category.
Absence of overt indexing in the imperative does not count here either.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**    “Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes.  This pattern includes some of the cases referred to as (alignment) split in the literature.   Polarity (i.e. positive vs. negative distinction) does not count as a TAM category.   Absence of overt indexing in the imperative does not count here either.     Procedure  1. Consider the flagging patterns of the language (coded in [GB408](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408), [GB409](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409), and [GB410](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)). Is there any variation in the flagging of either S, A, or P which is determined by TAM categories (e.g. certain cases are used only in the perfective but not in the imperfective)? Code "1". Specifically look for such terms as *split ergative/ergativity* and *differential subject marking*.  2. Consider the indexing patterns of the language (coded in (coded in [GB089](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)–[GB094](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)). Is there any variation in the indexing of either S, A, or P which is determined by TAM categories? Code 1 both for difference in the form of the respective markers in case it result in different alignment patterns as well as for variation in the position of indexes (prefix/proclitic vs. suffix/clitic) even if the overall alignment pattern remains the same.  2. Code 0 if TAM results in merely different allomorphs of person/number indexes in the same position, so that both the overall alignment pattern and the position of markers remain the same. For the purposes of this question, the alternation between zero and overt indexes in some TAM does not count (code as 0).  3. Code 0 if there is no variation in indexing or flagging according to TAM.      Examples    **Code 1: Itzá (itz/itza1241; Mayan; Guatemala; Hofling and Tesucún 2000: 357)**    A transitive verb indexes the A argument by means of the so-called ‘Set A’ **prefixes**, e.g. *inw-* ‘1sA’ in (a) and (b), and with the P argument by means of the ‘Set B’ **suffixes**, e.g. *-ech* ‘2sP’ in the same example:    ```  Aspect: incompletive  k-inw-il-ik-ech.  INCOMPL-1sA-see-INCOMPL.TR-2sP  ‘I see you.’    Aspect: completive  t-inw-il-ik-ech.  COMPL-1sA-see-COMPL.TR-2sP  ‘I saw you.’  ```    With intransitive verbs both Set A and Set B affixes can occur. In this case the distribution is conditioned by the aspect of the clause (called ‘status’ in Mayan linguistics). The set A person markers are used in the non-completive aspect, e.g. *inw-* ‘1sA’ in (c), whereas the B markers are used in the completive aspect, e.g. *-ech* ‘2sP’ in (d):    ```  Aspect: incompletive  k-inw-em-el.  INCOMPL-1sA-descend-INCOMPL.INTR  ‘I descend.’    Aspect: completive  em-Ø-ech.  descend-COMPL.INTR-2sP   ‘You descended.’  ```    **Code 1: Georgian (kat/nucl1302; Kartvelian; Harris 1981: 27)**    In Series I (Present) the A argument is in the nominative case, e.g. *deda* ‘mother.NOM’ in (a), whereas the P argument is marked with the dative case, e.g. *tavis švil-s* ‘self.GEN child-DAT’ in (a).   In Series II (Aorist) the A argument is in the narrative case (aka ergative), e.g. *deda-m* ‘mother-NARR’ in (b), the P  argument is in the nominative, e.g *tavis-i švil-i* ‘self.GEN-NOM child-NOM’ in (b).    ```  Series I (Present)  a. deda       bans             tavis    švil-s.     mother.NOM she.bathes.him.I self.GEN child-DAT     ‘The mother is bathing her child.’       Series II (Aorist)  b. deda-m       dabana             tavis-i       švil-i.     mother-NARR  she.bathed.him.II  self.GEN-NOM  child-NOM     ‘The mother bathed her child.’  ```     Further reading  Dixon, R.M.W. 1994. *Ergativity*. (Section 4.3 Split conditioned by tense/aspect/mood)     Related Features  Features 89-90 coding indexing patterns:    [GB089 Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090 Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)    Features 408–409 coding flagging alignment patterns:    [GB408	Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408)    [GB409	Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)    [GB410	Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Clarifying comments:
**ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**

Marking strategies include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. The distinction between intransitive and transitive verbs is not included here.
“Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes.
Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for 1.
For languages to be coded 1 the respective verb classes need to be of a substantial size (several dozens verbs or more) and ideally represent a productive pattern.
The presence of verb classes whose members are often exhaustively listed in a descriptive grammar and are presented as an exceptional patterns does not qualify as 1.
The patterns of interest is more common with intransitive verbs and include cases of the so-called active-inactive alignment (or simply: active or agentive-patientive or stative-active) in cases of differentially marked S argument. Some grammars use the terms unergative-unaccusative verbs. The pattern of interest is, however, not restricted to the S argument and variations in marking of A and P arguments are also included.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, verb classification, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: Marking strategies include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. The distinction between intransitive and transitive verbs is not included here.   “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes.   Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1".   For languages to be coded "1" the respective verb classes need to be of a substantial size (several dozens verbs or more) and ideally represent a productive pattern.   The presence of verb classes whose members are often exhaustively listed in a descriptive grammar and are presented as an exceptional patterns does not qualify as "1".   The patterns of interest is more common with intransitive verbs and include cases of the so-called active-inactive alignment (or simply: active or agentive-patientive or stative-active) in cases of differentially marked S argument. Some grammars use the terms unergative-unaccusative verbs. The pattern of interest is, however, not restricted to the S argument and variations in marking of A and P arguments are also included.       Procedure  1. Consider the flagging patterns of the language (coded in [GB408](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408), [GB409](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409), and [GB410](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)). Is there any variation in the flagging of either S, A, or P which is determined by verb classes? Code 1 both for difference in the form of the respective markers in case it result in different alignment patterns as well as for variation in the position of indexes (prefix/proclitic vs. suffix/clitic) even if the overall alignment pattern remains the same. If there is a relevant variation, consider whether the respective verb classes are of substantial size, if the classes are substantially large, code "1". Specifically look for such terms as *active(-inactive)*, *agentive-patientive* or *stative-active alignment* or *split-S* and consider the respective verb classes. Look for cases of *non-canonical argument marking* and consider the respective verb classes.    2. Consider the indexing patterns of the language (coded in [GB089](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)–[GB094](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409), and [GB410](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)). Consider whether there are any differences in the form of the respective indexes and they either result in different alignment patterns or there is variation in the position of indexes (prefix/proclitic vs. suffix/clitic) even if the overall alignment pattern remains the same. If yes, consider whether the respective verb classes are of substantial size, if the classes are substantially large, code "1". Ignore mere variations in the phonological form of the indexes which are conditioned by various [conjugation classes](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB111). Specifically look for such terms as *active(-inactive)*, *agentive-patientive* or *stative-active alignment* or *split-S* and consider the respective verb classes. Look for cases of *non-canonical argument marking* and consider the respective verb classes.     Examples  **Maca** (wpc/maco1239; Rosés Labrada 2015: 294, 297)    Code "1"    Mako verb roots can be divided into two classes depending on the _phonology_ of the verb: roots ending in a consonant (Class I) and roots ending in a vowel (Class II).    Class I: _ed-_ ‘see’, _otid-_ ‘work’, _pʰõɾ-_ ‘put away’, _kɨkɨd-_ ‘dry in the sun’, _amat-_ ‘squeeze’    Class II: _hã-_ ‘make/do’, _di-_ ‘scrape’, _wahi-_ ‘not know’, _wi-_ fell’, _wo-_ ‘stink/smell’    Class I verbs attach the subject (S/A) markers in a suffix slot immediately following the verb root.   Class II verbs attach (S/A)) the subject markers in a prefix slot immediately preceding the verb root.  ```  ʧɨ̃-hãmat-obe  1SG-stand.up-TAME   ```  vs.  ```  me-t-obe  fall-1SG-TAME  ```    **Basque** (eus/basq1248; Hualde 2003)    Code "1"    Monovalent predicates in Basque are devided into two groups: the so-called unergative predicates take the S argument in the ergative case, as in (a), whereas the so-called unaccusative predicates have the S argument in the absolutive case, as in (b).    The class of unergative verbs contains quite a few simple verbs, such as *dirdiratu* 'glimmer', *botatu* 'bounce', *bozkatu* 'vote', *gogoetatu* 'meditate', *irakin* 'boil', *iraun* 'persist', *bazkaldu* 'have dinner', *afaldu* 'have supper', and *dimititu* 'resign' (Hualde 2003: 388–389). Moreover, there is a large class of unergative [complex predicates (or light verb constructions)](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB123), which are monovalent, they are composed of a bare noun and a verb indicating action: egin 'do', as in (c).   ```  a. Jonek   saltatu  du. (unergative)     Jon.ERG jump     AUX    'Jon jumped.' (Hualde 2003: 364)    b. Jon      etorri da. (unaccusative)     Jon(ABS) come   AUX     'Jon came.' (Hualde 2003: 364)    c. Jonek    korri    egin   du. (unergative complex predicate)     Jon.ERG  run      do     AUX.TR     'Jon ran.' (Hualde 2003: 390)  ```    **German** (deu/stan1295)    Code "0"    German has about a dozen verbs taking the P argument in the dative case, they include *danken* 'thank' (*Ich danke dir* 'I thank you'), *folgen* 'follow' (*Bitte folgen Sie mir!* 'Please, follow me!'), and *verzeihen* 'pardon, forgive' (*Ich kann ihm nicht verzeihen.* 'I cannot excuse him.'). German is coded "0" because this verb class does not qualify as substantially large. Many other languages (if not every language) have small classes of predicates with marking patterns deviating from the one major pattern.    **Osage** (osa/osag1243; Siouan; Pustet 2002)    Code "1"    Osage transitive verbs index both A and P arguments, as in (a):    ```  ǫ-tha-nǫk̩ˀǫ  aSGP-2sgA-hear  'You hear/heard me.' (Wolff 1952:234, as in Pustet 2002: 391)  ```    Around 70% of intransitive verbs use the same indexes to mark the S argument as the ones used for the A argument, as in (b), whereas the remaining 30% of intransitive verbs (still a substantial amount) use the indexes identical to the ones used for the P arguments. gether,these two paradigmsform coding patternA in Osage. There seems to be a semantic basis for the formal contrast between the indexing patterns with A and P prefixes. This semantic distinction is  described in terms of the notion of agency (i.e "active" and "non-active" verbs).    ```  b. tha-k̩ˀǫ'çagi (and other active verbs)      2sgA-very.fast    'You are very fast' (La Flesche 1932:88, as in Pustet 2002: 391)          c. ǫ-shį'     1sgP-fat    'I am fat' (La Flesche 1932:131, as in Pustet 2002: 391)  ```     Further reading    [Bernard Comrie. 2013. Alignment of Case Marking of Full Noun Phrases. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: MPI EVA.](http://wals.info/chapter/98) (the section on active-inactive alignment)    Dixon, R.M.W. 1994. *Ergativity*. (Section 4.1. Split conditioned by the semantic nature of the verb)    [Siewierska, Anna. 2013. Alignment of Verbal Person Marking. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/100) (the section on active alignment)       Related Features  General features on indexing:    [GB089 Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090 Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091 Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092 Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093 Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094 Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)    General features on flagging:    [GB408 Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408)    [GB409 Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)    [GB410 Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Clarifying comments:
**ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**

“Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for 1. This pattern includes cases referred to as person-based (alignment) split and hierarchical alignment in the literature.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, person, number, gender
wiki_summary: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**    “Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". This pattern includes cases referred to as person-based (alignment) split and hierarchical alignment in the literature.      Procedure  1. Consider whether there are any differences in the form of the argument indexes on the verb (coded in [GB089](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)–[GB094](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)) related to the person of arguments (1st vs. 2nd vs. 3rd). If there is some variation, code 1 if it either results in different alignment patterns or if the position of indexes differs (prefix/proclitic vs. suffix/clitic) even if the overall alignment pattern remains the same.  2. Code 1 if case/adposition marking of S, A, or P arguments (coded in [GB408](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408), [GB409](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409), and [GB410](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)) varies according to person of the marked argument. If there is some variation, code 1 if it either results in different alignment patterns or if the position of indexes differs (prefix/proclitic vs. suffix/clitic).  3. The alternation between zero marking for some persons and overt marking for other persons does not suffice for 1.  4. Code 0 if there is no variation in indexing or flagging according to person, even if other referential properties of arguments matter, such as animacy, number, pronominal vs. nominal status.  5. Code 0 if person triggers merely different overt allomorphs of flagging or indexing, so that the overall alignment pattern remains the same.     Examples  **Code 1: English** (eng/stan1293)  The alignment pattern of English case marking is conditioned by person, number and nominal/pronominal distinction. The first person (singular an plural) distinguishes S/A from P, as in (a), whereas the case marking of the second person pronouns shows neutral alignment, as in (b).    (a) First person:    ***I*** *smiled.* (S)    ***I*** *have read this book.* (A)    *He saw ***me***.* (P)    (b) Second person:    ***You*** *smiled.* (S)    ***You*** *have read this book.* (A)    *I saw ***you***.* (P)      **Code 1: Kirmanjki** (kiu/kirm1248; Selcan 1998)  Kirmanjiki shows variations in case marking of core participants based on a number of factors: animacy, noun vs. pronoun, person distinctions and [TAM (GN095)](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095).  In non-past tenses, S, A and nominal inanimate Ps, as well as some pronominal P arguments (1pl, 2pl) are in the direct case.   Animate nominal Ps, as well as 1sg, 2sg, 3sg and 3pl pronominal P are in the oblique case.   This pattern of case marking yields neutral alignment for inanimate nouns, as well as for 1 pl and 2 pl pronouns, and accusative alignment for animate nouns, as well as for 1sg, 2sg and 3sg/pl pronouns.   Because person is one of the factors, the language is coded as 1.     Further reading  Dixon, R.M.W. 1994. Ergativity. (Section 4.2 Split conditioned by the semantic nature of NPs)     Related Features  Features 89-90 coding indexing patterns:  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)    Features 408–409 coding flagging alignment patterns:    [GB408	Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408)    [GB409	Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)    [GB410	Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)

Feature: Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Clarifying comments:
Do some verbs have two or more suppletive allomorphs whose distribution is conditioned by the person of an S, A, or P argument?
Suppletive are allomorphs which are not similar in pronunciation, i.e. cannot be related to each other by morpho-phonological rules?
The question covers both strong and weak suppletion, as well as ablaut.
There must be at least **three** verbs to code 1.
wiki_summary: Do some verbs have two or more suppletive allomorphs whose distribution is conditioned by the person of an S, A, or P argument?   Suppletive are allomorphs which are not similar in pronunciation, i.e. cannot be related to each other by morpho-phonological rules?  The question covers both strong and weak suppletion, as well as ablaut.   There must be at least **three** verbs to code 1.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if at least three verb stems vary according to the person of S, A, and/or P arguments.  2. Code 1 if the grammar does not list the verbs but says that there are some/a few/several/couple of them.  3. Code 0 if only one or two examples are provided, add a comment.     Examples  **Code 1: Tainae** (ago/tain1253; Angan)  Carlson (1991: 92) provides a non-exhaustive list of seven verbs (‘blow magic at’, ‘desire’, ‘eat’, ‘cook’, ‘kill’, ‘hit’, ‘give’) which have suppletive forms depending on the person of the P argument.     Further reading  There is some discussion of suppletion in Haspelmath, M. 2002. *Understanding morphology*.      Related Features  Features 89-90 coding indexing patterns:  [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has a benefactive argument. The marker could be analyzed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the benefactor or benefactee. Serial verb constructions that include a marker of benefactive (typically the root for give) do not count here.
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, benefactive, derivation, valency increase
wiki_summary: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has a benefactive argument. The marker could be analyzed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the benefactor or benefactee. Serial verb constructions that include a marker of benefactive (typically the root for "give") do not count here.     Procedure  1. Look up the section on oblique argument constructions and/or verbal morphology.  2. If there is no such section, search for the words "give", "receive", "recipient", "benefactive" and "applicative".  3. If the language has no morphology whatsoever, or no way of marking oblique argument structure, code as 0.  4. If the language has a way of marking the benefactive argument on the verb by indexing, code as 1.  5. If the language has a way of marking that a benefactive argument exists, but does not index, code as 1.  6. If unclear, bring up for discussion.     Examples    **Arabana** (ISO 639-3: ard, Glottolog: arab1267)    In Arabana, the general transitivizer _-la-_ functions, amongst others, as a benefactive marker:    ```  Thudni-la-thira  cry-BEN-PUNC  '(They) cry over someone.'  (Hercus 1994: 150)    Thanta wirra-la-rnda  stuff buy-BEN-PRES  '(Father) buys dress material for (them)'  (Hercus 1994: 150)  ```    **Jina** (ISO 639-3: jia, Glottolog: jina1244)    In Jina, in continuous aspect clauses, indirect object pronouns are infixed inside a reduplicated verb (reduplication marks continuous aspect). This counts as indexing, and triggers a 1 for this feature.    ```  na zal-ama-cə-zala  1SG REDUP:CONT-2SG.F.BEN-3SG.F-send  'I am sending her to you.'  (Kappel Schmidt, Odden & Holmberg 2002:111, my glosses)  ```     Further reading    Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.     Maria Polinsky. 2013. [Applicative Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/109).  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.      Peterson, D. A. (1999). [*Discourse-functional, historical, and typological aspects of applicative constructions*](https://escholarship.org/uc/item/86t3g76t) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.      Related Features  * [GB103	Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB103)  * [GB104	Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB104)  * [GB108	Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB108)  * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)  * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)

Feature: Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has an instrumental argument. The marker could be analysed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the instrument.
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, instrumental, derivation, valency increase
wiki_summary: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has an instrumental argument. The marker could be analysed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the instrument.      Procedure  1. Look up the section on oblique argument constructions and/or verbal morphology.  2. If there is no such section, search for the words "with", "instrument" and "comitative".  3. If the language has no morphology whatsoever, or no way of marking oblique argument structure, code as 0.  4. If the language has a way of marking the instrumental argument on the verb by indexing, code as 1.  5. If the language has a way of marking that a instrumental argument exists, but does not index, code as 1.  6. If unclear, bring up for discussion.     Examples    **Makhuwa** (ISO 639-3: vmw, Glottolog: makh1264)    Makhuwa has an instrumental applicative (the same form also functions as benefactive and locative/directive applicative):    ```  Amíná o-n-rúw-él' eshimá nkhóri  1.Amina 1-PRES.CJ-stir-APPL 9shima 3.spoon  'Amina prepares shima with a spoon.'  (van der Wal 2009: 72)  ```     Further reading    Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.     Maria Polinsky. 2013. [Applicative Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/109).  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Peterson, D. A. (1999). [*Discourse-functional, historical, and typological aspects of applicative constructions*](https://escholarship.org/uc/item/86t3g76t) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.    Stolz, Thomas. 1996. Some Instruments Are Really Good Companions - Some Are Not. On Syncretism and the Typology of Instrumentals and Comitatives. *Theoretical Linguistics* 23. 113-200.    Stolz, Thomas. 2001. To be with X is to have X: Comitatives, Instrumentals, Locative, and Predicative Possession. *Linguistics* 39. 321-350.    Stolz, Thomas. 2001. Comitatives vs. Instrumentals vs. Agents. In Bisang, W. (ed.), *Aspects of Typology and Universals*, 153-174. Berlin: Akademie Verlag.     Related Features  * [GB103	Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB103)  * [GB104	Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB104)  * [GB108	Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB108)  * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)  * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)

Feature: Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Clarifying comments:
