GB105 is concerned with both flagging (i.e. case and adposition marking) and indexing on the verb of the respective arguments. 1 is firstly triggered by flagging. Only if there is no overt flagging for the P argument and the recipient argument, indexing is considered. 1 includes both the double-object construction and the secondary-object construction of Haspelmath (2013).

Consider as ditransitive only verbs expressing physical transfer of possession or mental transfer of message (give, lend, hand, feed, send, bring, show, tell, teach).

Consider as ditransitive verbs which allow overt expression of an agent, a theme and a recipient/addressee arguments as separate NPs. The morphological marking of these arguments (e.g. dative case vs. adpositional marking) is irrelevant for counting a verb as ditransitive.
Relevant unit(s): noun, NP, verb, index, case marker
Function: argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification, derivation
wiki_summary: GB105 is concerned with both flagging (i.e. case and adposition marking) and indexing on the verb of the respective arguments. "1" is firstly triggered by flagging. Only if there is no overt flagging for the P argument and the recipient argument, indexing is considered. "1" includes both the "double-object construction" and the "secondary-object construction" of Haspelmath (2013).    Consider as ditransitive only verbs expressing physical transfer of possession or mental transfer of message (give, lend, hand, feed, send, bring, show, tell, teach).    Consider as ditransitive verbs which allow overt expression of an agent, a theme and a recipient/addressee arguments as separate NPs. The morphological marking of these arguments (e.g. dative case vs. adpositional marking) is irrelevant for counting a verb as ditransitive.     Procedure  1. Look up flagging of the P argument of transitive verbs and of the recipient of ditransitive verbs.  2. If there are different marking patterns of the recipient argument, consider the more frequent patterns.  3. If there is identical overt flagging of the two arguments, code as "1".  4. If either (only) the transitive P or the recipient is overtly marked, code as "0".  5. If neither the transitive P nor the ditransitive recipient are overtly marked, consider the indexing on the verb and code as "1" if the two arguments are identically indexing.  6. If the indexing of P differs from the indexing of the recipient, code as "0".  7. If there is neither overt indexing not flagging for both P and the recipient, code as "1".  8. If in doubt or unclear, please bring up for discussion.     Examples  **Example 1: Awa-Cuaiquer** (awac1239/kwi)  Though only some P's (pronouns and certain nouns) are overtly marked with the dative suffix in Awa-Cuaiquer (compare the marked P argument  in a. vs. the unmarked P argument in b.), it still counts as "1", as some P are identically marked with the recipient (as in c.)    ```  a. Demetrio  na-wa    pyan-tɨ-tɨ-s     Demetrio  1sg-DAT  hit-TERM-PST-LOCUT:P     ‘Demetrio hit me.’ (Curnow 1997: 65)    b. Demetrio  kuzhu  pay-t   kway-zi     Demetrio  pig    buy-SV  DROP-NONLOCUT     ‘Demetrio bought a pig.’ (Curnow 1997: 65)    c. na=na          Santos=ta   pashu    mɨla-ta-w     1sg.(NOM)=TOP  Santos=DAT  daughter give-PST-LOCUT:SUBJ     ‘I gave my daughter to Santos.’ (Curnow 1997: 74)  ```     Further reading  * [Haspelmath, Martin. 2013. Ditransitive Constructions: The Verb 'Give'. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.](http://wals.info/chapter/105)  * Malchukov, Andrej, Martin Haspelmath and Comrie, Bernard. 2010. Ditransitive constructions: A typological overview. In Malchukov, Andrej, Martin Haspelmath and Comrie, Bernard (eds.) *Studies in Ditransitive Constructions: A Comparative Handbook*, 1-64. Berlin: de Gruyter Mouton [Link to the publisher](http://www.degruyter.com/view/product/176781)     Related Features  * [GB071	Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB071)  * [GB073	Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB073)  * [GB103	Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB103)  * [GB300	Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB300)  * [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)  * [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation, i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). The marker has to form a phonological unit with the root, be it by affixation, cliticisation, suppletion, reduplication, tone etc. If the verb that the marker is attached to is described as an auxiliary, this also counts but it is advisable to bring this up for discussion.
wiki_summary:
This feature refers to Standard Negation, i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). The marker has to form a phonological unit with the root, be it by affixation, cliticisation, suppletion, reduplication, tone etc. If the verb that the marker is attached to is described as an "auxiliary", this also counts but it is advisable to bring this up for discussion. Procedure 1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation. 2. If the marker is described as an affix or phonologically bound clitic, suppletion, tone or reduplication and you see no reason to doubt that it is indeed bound, answer "1". 3. If the marker is described as a "particle" and it is unclear whether it is bound to the verb or not, look into more sources. 4. If unclarity still remains, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig). 5. If the marker can be bound, and can be free, (and you are sufficiently convinced that when it is described as bound it is indeed bound), answer "1" for this feature and "1" for [GB298](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB298) and/or [GB299](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB298) 6. If there is more than one construction for marking negation, code for all of them. Examples **Turkish** (ISO 639-3: tur, Glottocode: nucl1301) Standard negation in Turkish is accomplished using the suffix _-mA_ (Kornfilt 1997:123). Turkish is coded as a 1 for this feature. 
    1)  _Hasan kitab-ı oku-ma-dı_        Hasan book-Acc. read-Neg-Past       'Hasan didn't read the book'
Further reading * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Linguistics 27. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 1-27. * Dahl, Östen. 1979. Typology of Sentence Negation. Linguistics 17. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 79-106. * Dahl, Östen. 2010. "Typology of Negation" in Horn (ed) The Expression of Negation. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Negative Morphemes. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/112) * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Position of Negative Morpheme With Respect to Subject, Object, and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/144) * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Order of Negative Morpheme and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/143) * Kornfilt, Jaklin. 1997. Turkish. (Descriptive Grammars Series, Descriptive Grammars.) London: Routledge. xxxi+575pp. * Miestamo, Matti. 2013. Symmetric and Asymmetric Standard Negation. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/113) * Payne, John R. 1985. "Negation". I Timothy Shopen (red), Language Typology and Syntactic Description, vol. 1. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Related Features * [GB107 Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB107/) * [GB137 Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB137) * [GB138 Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB138) * [GB139 Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB139) * [GB140 Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB140) * [GB298 Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB298) * [GB299 Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB299) * [GB400 Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB400)

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals the direction or location of the event/state/action that the predicate is referencing. A marker that just indicates that something happens in multiple directions does not count here.
Function: argument marking, oblique, applicative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
wiki_summary: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals the direction or location of the event/state/action that the predicate is referencing. A marker that just indicates that something happens in "multiple directions" does not count here.     Procedure  1. Look up the section on verbal morphology.  2. If no such section exists or does not provide information, search for the terms "direction", "goal", "go", "come" and "location".  3. If the language has no morphology whatsoever, or no way of marking location or direction on the verb, code as 0.  4. If the language has a way of marking the location or direction of the event/state/action bound to the verb, code as 1.  5. If unclear, bring up for discussion.     Examples    **Makuwa** (ISO 639-3: vmw, Glottolog: makh1264)    Makuwa has an applicative marker that can derive directional/locative verbs, as well as benefactive and instrumental verbs.    ```  ni-n-thámá onakhálá ni-n-thám-élá onhípíti  1PL-PRES.CF-move 17.Nacala 1PL-PRES.CJ-move-APPL 17.Ilha  'we move from Nacala to Ilha'  (van der Wal 2009: 72)  ```     Further reading    Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.    Maria Polinsky. 2013. [Applicative Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/109).  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Peterson, D. A. (1999). [*Discourse-functional, historical, and typological aspects of applicative constructions*](https://escholarship.org/uc/item/86t3g76t) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.     Related Features  * [GB103	Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB103)  * [GB104	Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB104)  * [GB108	Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB108)  * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)  * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Clarifying comments: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the number (singular, dual, plural etc) of a participant? The participant triggering the suppletive choice could be any of A, P, or S. Auxiliaries are also included in verbs for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts. There should be (reason to believe that there are) at least three verbs with participant number suppletion to count as 1.
wiki_summary: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the number (singular, dual, plural etc) of a participant? The participant triggering the suppletive choice could be any of A, P, or S. Auxiliaries are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts. There should be (reason to believe that there are) at least three verbs with participant number suppletion to count as 1.       Procedure  1. Check if the language alters its verbs according to number at all.  2. If yes, check if there is suppletion (different stem) involved in the alterations.      Examples  In Koasati (Muskogean) (Kimball 1991: 323–4) we have:    ```  a. ‘dwell’  átal dwell.1sg  alísw dwell.1du  ís-tílk dwell-1pl    b. ‘run’  walíka-l run-1sg  tóɬ-hílk run-1pl  ```     Further reading  A good survey is Veselinova (2006:149-174):    Veselinova, Ljuba. (2006) Suppletion in Verb Paradigms: bits and pieces of a puzzle (Typological Studies in Language 67). Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  The other verb suppletion features are    - GB110: Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?  - GB402: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?  - GB403: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Clarifying comments:
Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the tense or aspect (present, past etc) form it occurs in? Auxiliaries are also included in verbs for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts.
The language should have at least three cases, i.e., three verbs, to count as 'yes' (so there should be three cases exemplified or implied in the description).
wiki_summary: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the tense or aspect (present, past etc) form it occurs in? Auxiliaries are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts.  The language should have at least three cases, i.e., three verbs, to count as 'yes' (so there should be three cases exemplified or implied in the description).     Procedure  1. Check if the language alters its verbs according to tense/aspect at all.  2. If yes, check if there is suppletion (different stem) involved in the alterations. 			     Examples    In Georgian (South Caucasian) (Hewitt 1995: 446, passim) we have  ‘be’    v-ar 1sg-be.pres  v–i-kn-eb-i 1sg-vv-be.fut-ts (fut)-ind  v–i-q’av-i 1sg-vv-be.aor-ind    The verb stem (see the glosses) alters between ar/kn/q'av in PRES/FUT/AOR so  is clearly suppletive according to tense/aspect.     Further reading  An excellent survey is Veselinova (2006:63-134):    Veselinova, Ljuba. (2006) Suppletion in Verb Paradigms: bits and pieces of a puzzle (Typological Studies in Language 67). Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  The other verb suppletion features are    * GB109: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?  * GB402: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?  * GB403: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Clarifying comments:
Are there different groups of verbs that take different finiteness markers on the verb. Phonological rules are not considered here, we are concerned with whether there is non-phonological allomorphy of finiteness marking on verbs depending on which verb is chosen. Tonal classes are particles which may encode finiteness, and can be considered. Please note that a class of suppletive verbs does not count here.

Look for finiteness markers such as:
* Person : 1st, 2nd, 3rd
* Number: singular, plural, dual and trial.
* Gender: masculine, feminine or neuter
* Tense: present, past, or future.
* Aspect: perfect, perfective, progressive.
* Mood : indicative, subjunctive, imperative, optative.
* Voice: active, middle, or passive.
Function: TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, verb classification, argument marking, core, oblique
wiki_summary: Are there different groups of verbs that take different finiteness markers on the verb. Phonological rules are not considered here, we are concerned with whether there is non-phonological allomorphy of finiteness marking on verbs depending on which verb is chosen. Tonal classes are particles which may encode finiteness, and can be considered. Please note that a class of suppletive verbs does not count here.    Look for finiteness markers such as:  * Person : 1st, 2nd, 3rd  * Number: singular, plural, dual and trial.  * Gender: masculine, feminine or neuter  * Tense: present, past, or future.  * Aspect: perfect, perfective, progressive.  * Mood : indicative, subjunctive, imperative, optative.  * Voice: active, middle, or passive.       Procedure  1. Code 1 if finite verbs are formed differently depending on what verb is used, including whether this is simply a two-way distinction between ‘regular’ and ‘irregular’ verbs.  		     Examples  **Aghwan** (ISO 639-3: xag, Glottocode: aghw1237  )    Gippert et al. 2008, coded ?:    "There are strong and weak verbs, whose functional distribution is not fully transparent."    **Bardi** (ISO 639-3: bcj, Glottocode: bard1255)    Bowern 2004: 134, coded as 0:    "Bowern identifies three classes of verb roots: monovalent roots which do not take the transitive prefix n-~a- or an object marker, bivalent roots which subcategorize for two arguments and do take the transitive prefix n-~a- and ambitransitive roots which have direct object marking but may not take the transitive prefix n-~a- (p.134). These are transitivity classes rather than conjugational classes."    **Yulu** (ISO 639-3: yul; Glottocode: yulu1243)     Boyeldieu 1987: 169-172, Coded 1:     Different classes of verbs have different tonal contours when conjugated.       Further reading       Related Features

Feature: Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether intransitive verbs can take a [bound morpheme](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) that implies the addition of just one role in the event denoted by the verb. This could be a causative affix or clitic, an applicative (benefactive, instrumental, ...), ... It has to be productive. Note that there is no logical dependency with GB155 here, as a language could have causatives that change a verb's valency from 2 to 3 but not from 1 to 2.
Function: valency change, derivation, valency increase, causative, applicative
wiki_summary: This feature asks whether intransitive verbs can take a [bound morpheme](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) that implies the addition of just one role in the event denoted by the verb. This could be a causative affix or clitic, an applicative (benefactive, instrumental, ...), ... It has to be productive. Note that there is no logical dependency with GB155 here, as a language could have causatives that change a verb's valency from 2 to 3 but not from 1 to 2.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a grammar mentions a transitivizing marker that changes intransitive to transitive verbs, and it is phonologically bound to the verb.  2. Code 0 if a grammar mentions that there are no (phonologically bound) transitivizing markers on verbs or verb phrases.  3. Code 0 if an otherwise comprehensive grammar does not mention any transitivizing markers on verbs or verb phrases. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  4. Code 0 if a grammar only discusses valency decreasing operations or valency increasing operations that increase the valency of already transitive verbs, but mentions nothing on valency increasing operations that increase the valency of an intransitive verb.  5. Code 0 if a grammar discusses phonologically free morphemes that change intransitive verbs to transitive ones, but not phonologically bound ones.  6. Code ? if you think there is not enough data or analysis to establish the presence or absence of a bound transitivizing morpheme. Write this in the comment column.     Examples    **Ao Naga** (ISO 639-3: njo, Glottolog: aona1235)    Ao Naga (or Chungli Ao, in the source) has a causative suffix, *-taktsɨ*, which can transitivize intransitive sentences, as well as add an additional role to an already transitive clause:    ```  (Intransitive > transitive)  ni-i la tʃip-taktsɨ  1.SG-AGT 3.SG.FEM cry-CAUS.PERF  'I made her cry.'  (Escamilla 2012: 54-56)    (Transitive > ditransitive)  pa-i la-nem mapa injak-takstsɨ  3.SG.MASC-AGT 3.SG.FEM-NEM chore do/work-CAUS.PERF  'He made her do work.'  (Escamilla 2012: 54-56)  ```    **Arhuaco** (ISO 639-3: arh, Glottolog: arhu1242)    Arhuaco (or Ika) has a directive applicative prefix *ka-* that can add an extra role to an intransitive clause:    ```  mi-ka-wa'ka  2.OBJ-APPL.DIR-look  'He looked at you.'  (Haspelmath & Müller-Bardey 2004)  ```    **Barain** (ISO 639-3: bva, Glottolog: bare1279)    Like other Chadic languages, Barain has fossilized remains of a system of intransitive-causative vowel alternation, which is no longer productive (Lovestrand 2012: 126-127). There is no other transitivizing morphology (although there is a passive, reflexive and reciprocal). It is coded as 0.     Further reading    Escamilla, R. M. (2012). [*An Updated Typology of Causative Constructions: Form-Function Mappings in Hupa (California Athabaskan), Chungli Ao (Tibeto-Burman) and Beyond*](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.453.9124&rep=rep1&type=pdf) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.    Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.    Peterson, D. A. (1999). [*Discourse-functional, historical, and typological aspects of applicative constructions*](https://escholarship.org/uc/item/86t3g76t) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.     Related Features    * [GB103	Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB103)    * [GB104	Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB104)    * [GB108	Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB108)    * [GB155	Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB155)    * [GB156	Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB156)

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Clarifying comments: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language.
Function: reflexive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language.      Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar discusses a productive reflexive marker that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) to the verb.  2. Code 1 if the grammar discusses a marker that is phonologically bound to the verb and it encodes both reflexive and reciprocal functions.  3. Code 0 if the grammar discusses reciprocal markers or a phonologically independent reflexive marker, but doesn't mention a phonologically bound reflexive marker on verbs. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  4. Code 0 if the grammar only discusses unproductive reflexive markers on verbs.  5. Code 0 if an otherwise comprehensive grammar does not discuss reflexive markers. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  6. Code ? if there is not enough data or analysis in the available sources to determine whether there is a bound reflexive marker on verbs or whether it is productive.     Examples    **Hokkaido Ainu** (ISO 639-3: ain, Glottolog: ainu1240)    Hokkaido Ainu has a reflexive prefix *yay-* (Tamura 2000: 204):    ```  kik 'to hit'  yay-kik 'to hit oneself'    nuyna 'to hide'  yay-nuya 'to hide oneself'  ```    **Yimas** (ISO 639-3: yee, Glottolog: yima1243)    Yimas doesn't have any specialized reflexives, and receives a 0 value for this feature:    ```  "Yimas lacks any coherent way of forming reflexive constructions" (Foley 1991: 286)  ```    **Rapanui** (ISO 639-3: rap, Glottolog: rapa1244)    Rapanui doesn't have a specialized reflexive form, and receives a value of 0. Semantically reflexive clauses are just expressed with the regular independent pronoun for the person performing the action (Kieviet 2017: 432-433):    ```  ¿Ko haŋa 'ā koe mo hore atu i a koe?  PRF want CONT 2SG for cut away ACC PROP 2SG  'Do you want to cut yourself?'  ```     Further reading    Geniušienė, E. S. (1987). *The typology of reflexives*. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Haspelmath, M., & The APiCS Consortium. (2013). Reflexive constructions. In S. M. Michaelis, P. Maurer, M. Haspelmath, & M. Huber (Eds.), *The Atlas of Pidgin and Creole Language Structures* (pp. 346–349). Oxford: Oxford University Press.    König, E., & Gast, V. (2008). Reciprocity and reflexivity: Description, typology, and theory. In *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 1–31). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.     Related Features    * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)    * [GB124	Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB124)    * [GB147	Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB147)    * [GB148	Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB148)    * [GB303	Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB303)    * [GB305	Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB305)    * [GB306	Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB306)

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Clarifying comments: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized. This feature targets [phonologically bound]( https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers.
Function: reflexive, reciprocal, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized. This feature targets [phonologically bound]( https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar discusses a productive reciprocal marker that is phonologically bound to the verb.  2. Code 1 if the grammar discusses a marker that is phonologically bound to the verb and it encodes both reflexive and reciprocal functions.  3. Code 0 if the grammar discusses reflexive markers or a phonologically independent reciprocal marker, but doesn't mention a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on verbs. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  4. Code 0 if the grammar only discusses unproductive reciprocal markers on verbs.  5. Code 0 if an otherwise comprehensive grammar does not discuss reciprocal markers. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  6. Code ? if there is not enough data or analysis in the grammar to determine whether there is a bound reflexive marker on verbs or whether it is productive.     Examples    **Kuku-Yalanji** (ISO 639-3: gvn, Glottolog: kuku1273)    Kuku-Yalanji has a dedicated reciprocal suffix *-wa* (Patz 2002: 103):    ```  nyaji-l 'see' → nyaji-wa-y 'see each other'  kunja-l 'call, summon' → kunja-wa-y 'camm each other'  binal-bunga-l 'teach' → binal-bunga-wa-y 'call each other'  murru-kanga-l 'scold' → murru-kanga-wa-y 'scold each other'  ```    **Umbundu** (ISO 639-3: umb, Glottolog: umbu1257)    In Umbundu, the same prefix *li-* is used for both reflexive and reciprocal derivations.    ```  oku-li-mon-a  INF-REFL/REC/-see-a  'to see one's self' or 'to see each other'  (Stover-Wesley 1885: 46, my glosses)  ```     **Rapanui** (ISO 639-3: rap, Glottolog: rapa1244)    Rapanui doesn't have a reciprocal construction; semantically reciprocal clauses are just expressed with the regular independent personal pronouns (Kieviet 2017: 433). It is coded with 0.      Further reading    Evans, N. (2008). Reciprocal Constructions: Towards a Structural Typology. In E. König & V. Gast (Eds.), *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 33–104). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Geniušienė, E. S. (1987). *The typology of reflexives*. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    König, E., & Gast, V. (2008). Reciprocity and reflexivity: Description, typology, and theory. In *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 1–31). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Nedjalkov, V. P. (2007). Overview of the research: Definitions of terms, framework, and related issues. In V. P. Nedjalkov (Ed.), E. S. Geniušienė (Trans.), *Reciprocal Constructions* (pp. 3–114). Amsterdam: John Benjamins. And other chapters of the five-volume collection edited by Nedjalkov, which include chapters on 39 different genealogically diverse languages.     Related Features    * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)    * [GB124	Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB124)    * [GB147	Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB147)    * [GB148	Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB148)    * [GB303	Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB303)    * [GB305	Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB305)    * [GB306	Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB306)

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Clarifying comments: This questions aims at capturing verbal classifier systems, these systems are not based on agreement with the noun class system (Aikhenvald 2000:149). The system can however be identical or very similar to the possessive, numeral or demonstrative classifier systems.
wiki_summary: This questions aims at capturing verbal classifier systems, these systems are not based on agreement with the noun class system (Aikhenvald 2000:149). The system can however be identical or very similar to the possessive, numeral or demonstrative classifier systems.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are markers on verbs that vary according to the nature of the absolutive argument,  2. If this is not simply agreement with a system of noun classes.       Examples    **Anindilyakwa** (ISO 639-3: aoi, Glottocode: anin1240)      Van Egmond 2012: 237, Coded 1:    "Enindhilyakwa nominal incorporation is of the Classifier type (Rosen 1989), in that the valency of the verb is completely unaffected. They can classify items that may be further specified by an external nominal."  ```  narrv-ma-rreku-wurra-ngv-ma               abvrrv-lhangwa     mvngarukwa  3a-VEG-long.and.flexible-throw-p2-/raa     3a.PRO-POSS       VEG.fishing.line  ‘they have thrown out their fishing lines’  ```  **Navajo** (ISO 639-3: nav, Glottocode: nava1243)     Barron 1982: 137; Allan 1977: 287, Coded 1:    Navajo utilizes many particles on the verb to classify the object to which it refers.  ```  bééso sì-?á.  money perfect-lie (of round entity)  'A coin is lying (there).'    bééso sì-nìl.  money perfect-lie (of collection)  'Some money (small change) is lying (there).'    bééso sì-X-tsòòz.  money perfect-lie (of flat flexible entity)  'A note (bill) is lying (there).'   ```     Further reading  Aikhenvald, Alexandra (2003) Classifiers: a typology of noun categorization devices. Oxford Studies in Typology and Linguistic Theory . Oxford University Press, New York, USA. [Link](https://research.jcu.edu.au/lcrc/people/director/selective-papers/2006.-classifiers-and-noun-classes-semantics-pp.-463-70-of-volume-1-article-1111-of-encyclopedia-of-language-and-linguistics-2nd-edition-edited-by-keith-brown.-elsevier-oxford/at_download/file)     Related Features  * [GB038: Are there demonstrative classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB038)    * [GB057: Are there numeral classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB057)    * [GB058: Are there possessive classifiers?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB058)

Feature: Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Clarifying comments: Is there a copula in use (in an equative sentence) when the predicate is nominal? This copula does not have to be obligatory, nor a finite verb, it could be a demonstrative. Please note that adjectives are not included within the category of 'nominals' here.
wiki_summary: Is there a copula in use (in an equative sentence) when the predicate is nominal? This copula does not have to be obligatory, nor a finite verb, it could be a demonstrative. Please note that adjectives are not included within the category of 'nominals' here.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is an element which can be used when there is a nominal used predicatively, even if this is restricted to certain contexts, and if this marker has other functions such as being a demonstrative.         Examples    **Haitian** (ISO 639-3: hat, Glottocode: hait1244)     Valdman 1988: 90 Coded 1:    In Haitian, there is no copula required for predicates consisting of adjectives or location. There is a restricted copula for nominal predicates.  ```  M  se  jounalis      [Predicate nominal]   Li bon      [Predicate adjective]  I  COP journalist                          It good  I'm a journalist                           It's good  ```    **Abui** (ISO 639-3: abz, Glottocode: abui1241)      Kratochvíl 2007: 161, Coded 0:    In Abui, there is no copula that links the nominal predicate with its argument. The bare NP kalieta ‘old person’ serves as  nominal predicate.  ```  raha   kalieta   chief  old.person  ‘the chief is an old person’   ```     Further reading  Leon Stassen. 2013. Zero Copula for Predicate Nominals. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)   The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Link](http://wals.info/chapter/120)     Related Features

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Clarifying comments:
Serial verbs are two or more verbs in juxtaposition, functioning as a single predicate. Some languages allow intervening material and others do not. There is no morphology to mark their relationship with each other. Each of the verbs is a separate phonological word but the construction as a whole is expressed in one intonational unit. Morphology is shared to a greater or lesser extent.

Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.
wiki_summary: Serial verbs are two or more verbs in juxtaposition, functioning as a single predicate. Some languages allow intervening material and others do not. There is no morphology to mark their relationship with each other. Each of the verbs is a separate phonological word but the construction as a whole is expressed in one intonational unit. Morphology is shared to a greater or lesser extent.     Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.       Procedure  1. Code 1 if two or more verbs can be juxtaposed and function as a single predicate and expressed in one intonational unit, including when the verbs take finiteness marking.      Examples    **Bunak** (ISO 639-3: bfn, Glottocode: buna1278)    Schapper 2010: 446-448, Coded 1:  ```  Neto baqi     g-ege    il     a.  1SG  NPRX.AN  3AN-give water drink  ‘I gave him water to drink.’     Neto  bai     a  laun  1SG   thing  eat quick  ‘I eat quickly.’  ```  **Korafe-Yegha** (ISO 639-3:  kpr, Glottocode:  kora1294)     Farr 1999: 158, Coded 1:  ```  Nan=da  ghaka eva=i          bu     feunghe  jighi   bunununghu-sira.  1S=GEN  canoe sea.wave=CEFF  get.I  swell.I  hold.I  disintegrate.II-DP.3S.FN  ‘My canoe the sea waves took hold of, swelled over, held fast, and dashed to pieces.’  ```       Further reading  Aikhenvald, Alexandra, and Dixon, Robert. 2006. Serial verb constructions: a cross-linguistic typology. Oxford: Oxford University Press. [Link](https://cstn.files.wordpress.com/2009/10/aikhenvald_dixon-serial_verb_constructions_explorations_in_linguistic_typology.pdf)     Related Features  * [GB150: Is there clause chaining?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB150)

Feature: Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments:
This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as auxiliary verbs in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they fulfilled our criteria of inflecting word.

While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.

A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking (infinite mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.
wiki_summary:
This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they fulfilled our criteria of "inflecting word". While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature. A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together. Procedure 1. Look up section on mood marking in the grammatical description 2. Consider all marking of mood, i.e. not only conditional. 3. If you do not find any mood markers that inflect, code as (0) 4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers 5. If not clear that it is a mood marker, code language as (?) 6. If the markers are clearly marking mood, code language as (1). Examples **Turkish** (ISO 639-3: vma, Glottocode: mart1255) In Turkish, the verb 'to be' _ol_ forms an auxiliary verb together with bound mood marking, see below example for the necessitative mood (Kornfilt 1997:365). Turkish is coded as a 1 for this feature. 
    1) Ali oda-ya gir-erken Hasan iş-in-i bit-ir-iyor ol-malı-y-dı       Ali room-Dat. enter-while Hasan work-3.sg.-Acc. finish-Caus.-Prog. be -Nec.-Cop.-Past      'While Ali was entering the room Hasan had to be finishing his work'
Further reading * Bybee, Joan; Perkins, Revere; and Pagliuca, William. The Evolution of Grammar, Univ. of Chicago Press, 1994. * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf) * Palmer, F. R., Mood and Modality, Cambridge Univ. Press, 1986 (second edition 2001). Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as auxiliary verbs in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.
wiki_summary: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.     Procedure  1. Look up section on aspect marking in the grammatical description  2. Consider all marking of aspect, i.e. not only perfective.  3. If you do not find any aspect markers that inflect, code as (0)  4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers  5. If not clear that it is a aspect marker, code language as (?)  6. If the markers are clearly marking aspect, code language as (1).     Examples  **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Swedish uses an auxiliary derived from the verb 'to have' to indicate the difference between simple past and present perfect. Swedish is an example of a 1 for this feature.    | | Simple past | Present perfect |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   | swim | _simmade_ | _har simmat_ |   | dance | _dansade_ | _har dansat_ |            Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as auxiliary verbs in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they are probably inflecting words marking tense.

These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably inflecting words marking tense.     Procedure  1. Look up section on tense marking in the grammatical description  2. Consider all marking of tense, i.e. not only past.  3. If you do not find any tense markers that inflect, code as (0)  4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers  5. If not clear that it is a tense marker, code language as (?)  6. If the markers are clearly marking tense, code language as (1).     Examples  **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254)    Swedish uses an auxiliary derived from the verb 'to come' for marking future tense. Swedish is coded as 1 for this feature.     | | Present| Future |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   | swim | _simmar_ | _kommer att simma_ |   | dance | _dansar_ | _kommer att dansa_ |        Further reading  * Comrie, Bernard. 1985. Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Clarifying comments:
Verbal compounding is two or more verb stems acting as one phonological and grammatical word. Verb compounds share the same arguments. Languages with serial verbs can often have verb compounds too, however they might not always be described as such.

Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.
wiki_summary: Verbal compounding is two or more verb stems acting as one phonological and grammatical word. Verb compounds share the same arguments. Languages with serial verbs can often have verb compounds too, however they might not always be described as such.    Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is a conventionalised way of combining verbs into a single phonological word.     Examples  Ainu (ainu1240), coded as 1: "Verb compounding is primarily of the "Noun + Verb", but there are a few examples of "Verb + Verb" compounding."    Notsi (nots1237), coded as 1: "(p. 43) E.g. adodo-li = 'think-throw away' = 'forget'"     Further reading  [to be added]     Related Features  Distinguish this from serial verb constructions (GB118) and clause chaining (GB150)

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns constructions involving a non-predicating element expressing the lexical meaning of the construction, in conjunction with a semantically fairly empty verb, which enables the element to function as a predicate by providing the necessary morphology, e.g. 'eye do' for 'see'; or 'sneeze hit' for 'sneeze'. Exclude constructions that fall into the categories of verb compounding, clause-chaining, auxiliaries and serial verbs are excluded from the category of light-verb. The verb needs to be sufficiently productive, it cannot only concern a few instances. It is uninteresting whether the predicating element is of nominal/verbal/other root. This means for example that what is described in the literature as co-verb constructions most likely are a subcategory of light verbs. It is also uninteresting for the definition of light-verbs whether or not the non-finite predicating element can occur outside the construction or not, both scenarios are acceptable. The category of light verbs cannot all consist of constructions describing states, there has to be at least a few dynamic events. There should also be instances where it is hard to define whether the non-finite predicating element (adjunct) is clearly nominal or not.
wiki_summary: This question concerns constructions involving a non-predicating element expressing the lexical meaning of the construction, in conjunction with a semantically fairly empty verb, which enables the element to function as a predicate by providing the necessary morphology, e.g. 'eye do' for 'see'; or 'sneeze hit' for 'sneeze'. Exclude constructions that fall into the categories of verb compounding, clause-chaining, auxiliaries and serial verbs are excluded from the category of "light-verb". The verb needs to be sufficiently productive, it cannot only concern a few instances. It is uninteresting whether the predicating element is of nominal/verbal/other root. This means for example that what is described in the literature as "co-verb constructions" most likely are a subcategory of light verbs. It is also uninteresting for the definition of light-verbs whether or not the non-finite predicating element can occur outside the construction or not, both scenarios are acceptable. The category of light verbs cannot all consist of constructions describing states, there has to be at least a few dynamic events. There should also be instances where it is hard to define whether the non-finite predicating element (adjunct) is clearly nominal or not.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are productive verbs which are semantically fairly general which combine with a non-predicating element to produce a predicate.  2. Code 0 if these are limited to verb compounding or serial verb constructions.       Examples  **Korafe-Yegha  (kora1294; Farr 1999:63-66) Coded 1:**    Nominal + generic verb (do, say, see, hit, spear, do again, hold, get) are common.  ```  boare de        tattoo hit            ‘tattoo (someone)’  ambe de         sago hit              ‘process sago’  jinogu tam bu   swoon find            ‘swoon’  ata gae         foot spear            ‘spear/sting foot’  bairobo bu      choice of catch get   ‘get first pick of catch’  buri dighi      tether tie            ‘tether’  uvu mindi       liquid consume        ‘drink’  oka bambu       fish get              ‘catch fish’  ```  **Awtuw (awtu1239; Feldman 1986:153) Coded 0:**    Excluded by Grambank definition. There is a [direction verb (non-argument marked, non-TAM marked) + fully inflected "go" verb ] construction, but it is analysed as a serialisation construction by Feldman.  ```  rey tapwo da-ka+ lak- e  3MS fire FA-get+go DS-P  he brought the fire downstream   ```     Further reading  [Anderson, G. D. (2011), Auxiliary Verb Constructions (and Other Complex Predicate Types): A Functional–Constructional Overview. Language and Linguistics Compass, 5: 795-828](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1749-818X.2011.00311.x)    [Seiss, Melanie. 2009. On the difference between auxiliaries, serial verbs and light verbs. Proceedings of the LFG09 Conference, ed. by M. Butt and T. H. King, 501–19. Stanford, CA: CSLI Publications.](http://web.stanford.edu/group/cslipublications/cslipublications/LFG/14/papers/lfg09seiss.pdf)     Related Features  [GB118: Are there serial verb constructions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB118)

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Clarifying comments: Noun-verb incorporation is defined as a special construction where obligatorily bare (i.e. articleless, numberless, modifierless) nouns must occur adjacent to or inside of the verb (in a fixed order). This question asks essentially, can transitive verbs become intransitive by means of noun incorporation, and is this process productive? This need not be the default productive way of intransitivizing nouns, but the process must be productive. The incorporated noun is semantically the direct object of the verb. For example: he was painting the bike = he was bike-painting. Noun incorporation where the noun is acting as modifier do not count, such as she was running like Jacob runs = she was Jacob-running. If it is necessary to still overtly mark the direct object, for example with a pronoun, that does not count.
wiki_summary: Noun-verb incorporation is defined as a special construction where obligatorily bare (i.e. articleless, numberless, modifierless) nouns must occur adjacent to or inside of the verb (in a fixed order). This question asks essentially, can transitive verbs become intransitive by means of noun incorporation, and is this process productive? This need not be the default productive way of intransitivizing nouns, but the process must be productive. The incorporated noun is semantically the direct object of the verb. For example: "he was painting the bike" = "he was bike-painting". Noun incorporation where the noun is acting as modifier do not count, such as "she was running like Jacob runs" = "she was Jacob-running". If it is necessary to still overtly mark the direct object, for example with a pronoun, that does not count.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is there is a strategy for intransitivizing verbs that either binds a bare object nominal morphologically to the verb, or requires a bare object nominal to be positioned immediately adjacent to the verb.  2. Code 0 if the nominal involved in this construction is not obligatorily bare, or if it does not express the semantic object of the verb.  3. Code 0 if the direct object must be expressed by an overt element in the syntax (e.g. a pronoun) in addition to the verb-adjacent nominal.			     Examples    **Comanche** (ISO 639-3: com, Glottolog: coma1245)    Comanche noun incorporation de-transitivizes a verb, and is commonly used to express habitual activities. The incorporated noun must be a bare root with no number or case marking.    *Noun Incorporation*    [pukumakwI&577;et&616; ur&616;&616;]    puku-makwih-&577;e-t&616;&616;<sup>=</sup> ut&616;&616;    horse-chase, herd-RPT:ASP-GEN:ASP=PL they    They're chasing horses.      cf. *Non-incorporated Direct Object*    [ehka n&616;&616; wa&577;&243;&577;a makwI&577;ep&616;nnit&407;]    eHka n&616;&616; wa&577;&243;&577;-a makwih-&577;e-h/H/p&616;nni-t&616;<sup>=</sup>    those=OBJ I cat-OBJ chase, herd-RPT:ASP-ONGO:ASP-GEN:ASP    I'm chasing the cats.    (Charney 1993: 123)      Comanche would be coded 1.         Further reading    Caballero, Gabriella, Michael J. Houser, Nicole Marcus, Teresa McFarland, Anne Pycha, Maziar Toosarvandani, & Johanna Nichols. 2008. Nonsyntactic ordering effects in noun incorporation. Linguistic Typology 12: 383-421.    Gerdts, Donna. 1998. Incorporation. In A. Spencer and A. Zwicky (eds.) The Handbook of Morphology. London: Blackwell. 84-100.    Mithun, Marianne. 1984. The evolution of noun incorporation. Language 60: 847-894.    Mithun, Marianne. 1986. On the nature of noun incorporation. Language 62: 32-37.    deReuse, Willem. 1994. Noun incorporation. In R. Asher (ed.) Encyclopedia of Language and Linguistics. Oxford: Pergamon. 2842-2847.       Related Features  * [GB122: Is verb compounding a regular process?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB122)  * [GB123: Are there verb-adjunct (a.k.a. 'light verb') constructions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB123)

Feature: Is there an existential verb?
Clarifying comments: Is there an element expressing existential predication, that is **different from the equative or attributive copula**? It is possible that there are more than one existential verbs making further distinctions, temporary versus permanent existence or a special marker for negative existence. Different positional verbs do not count here. The existential marker can be used for the expression of other functions, such as aspect, as long as it is not identical to the copula of identity or attribution. The existential element need not be a verb in the language in any other sense than being the existential verb. The existence of a negative existential is not sufficient for a 1.
wiki_summary: Is there an element expressing existential predication, that is **different from the equative or attributive copula**? It is possible that there are more than one existential verbs making further distinctions, temporary versus permanent existence or a special marker for negative existence. Different positional verbs do not count here. The existential marker can be used for the expression of other functions, such as aspect, as long as it is not identical to the copula of identity or attribution. The existential element need not be a verb in the language in any other sense than being the existential "verb". The existence of a negative existential is not sufficient for a 1.      Procedure  1. Find the existential construction in the language  2. Find the equational and attributive constructions.  3. Code 1 if there is an overt existential element is different from both the equative and attributive elements (if any).  4. Code 0 otherwise.     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * It exists but is the same as the copula	   * It exists but also encodes position			     Examples  **Swedish [swe]** has a verb that is different from the predicative copula ("är") and positional verbs ("sitta", "stå", "ligga", etc): "finns" (Hedvig Skirgård, p.c.).    Original: _det finns inga spöke-n_    Gloss: it exist no ghost-PL    Trans: There are no ghosts      Original: _Sheena är en punkare_    Gloss: Sheena is a punk rocker    Trans: Sheena is a punk rocker        Original: _Kopp-en är på bord-et_    Gloss: cup-DEF is on table-DEF    Trans: The cup is on the table       Further reading  Anderson, Neil. (1989) Folopa existential verbs. In Karl Franklin (ed.), Studies in componential analysis (Data Papers on Papua New Guinea Languages 36), 83-105. Ukarumpa: Summer Institute of Linguistics.     Related Features  The existential construction is also touched upon in its negated for in:    GB140: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Clarifying comments: English would receive 0 here, as you can simply say that 'a bottle is on the table'. Dutch would be coded as 1, as you always have to specify whether an object 'stands' or 'lies' on the table (you cannot say that it 'is' on the table). Different configurations are possible, however (e.g. 'sit' vs. 'stand', 'hang' vs. 'lie' vs. 'stand'). Note that this feature does not concern morphological (or other overt) marking for position or shape, but really the use of different verbs for this purpose (in other words, suppletion). If the posture verbs are clearly dominant in frequency this is sufficient to count as 'obligatory' for the purpose of this question, even if non-posture alternatives are grammatical.
wiki_summary: English would receive 0 here, as you can simply say that 'a bottle is on the table'. Dutch would be coded as 1, as you always have to specify whether an object 'stands' or 'lies' on the table (you cannot say that it 'is' on the table). Different configurations are possible, however (e.g. 'sit' vs. 'stand', 'hang' vs. 'lie' vs. 'stand'). Note that this feature does not concern morphological (or other overt) marking for position or shape, but really the use of different verbs for this purpose (in other words, suppletion). If the posture verbs are clearly dominant in frequency this is sufficient to count as 'obligatory' for the purpose of this question, even if non-posture alternatives are grammatical.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if verb roots (not verb morphology) which express location (such as *is* in *the book is on the table*) also encode the posture ('lie', 'stand', 'sit', 'hang', e.g. ‘the book lies on the table’ = ‘the book is on the table’), and if there is no frequently used more general way of encoding location.  2. Code 0 if expressions of location do not also obligatorily encode posture. A look at texts and examples should give you an idea of this.  3. Code ? if you cannot find clear examples of locational predication.     Examples    **Meyah** (ISO 639-3: mej, Glottolog: meya1236)    In Meyah, different positional verbs are obligatorily used to predicate the existence and location of (a) humans, (b) animals, trees, corn stalks, and houses, and (c) snakes, ants, rocks, yams, water, rainbows. Humans are considered to 'sit' (*eker*). Members of category (b), which includes animals and inanimate objects that have legs, are considered to 'stand' (*ot*). Members of category (c), which have in common that they don't have any legs, are considered to 'lie' (*ah*) (Gravelle 2004: 223). Some examples are:    ```  (a) Humans sit:    Idu bera en-eker gu mei  Idu TOP DUR-sit in water  'Who is in the water?'    (b) Nonhuman leg-possessing entities stand:    Mega mos ongga en-ot gij Iskuruk  tree mos REL DUR-stand in Iskuruk  'The mos tree that is in Iskuruk village...'    (c) Legless entities lie    Ineymes en-ah gu monuh Mandacan  Ineymes Dur-lie.down at place Mandacan  'Ineymes village is in the Mandacan area.'    (Gravelle 2004: 224)  ```    **Standard Dutch** (ISO 639-3: nld, Glottolog: dutc1256)    In Standard Dutch, there is a composite generic verb *zich bevinden* which can be used to specify the location of an entity without indicating its posture. It is, however, rarely used in day-to-day speech, and usually either _staan_ 'to stand' or *liggen* 'to lie' is used when referring to something's location. Dutch gets a 1 for this feature.    ```  (a) A bottle 'stands':    De fles staa-t in de kamer hier-naast.  DEF bottle stand-3SG in DEF room here-beside   'The bottle is in the room next door.'    (b) A ball 'lies':    De bal lig-t in de kamer hier-naast.  DEF ball lie-3SG in DEF room here-beside   'The ball is in the room next door.'  ```    **Hatam** (ISO 639-3: had, Glottolog: hata1243)    Hatam has a generic verb *jo* which can be used to refer to an entity's location without specifying the posture of that entity. Of course, there are also posture verbs, but they are not used obligatorily, or by default, in locative predication constructions. Notably, in the examples, posture verbs are only used for animate entities. Hatam is coded 0.    ```  Use of the generic verb 'jo':    Lampu jo gau meja (dip).  lamp be above table top  'The lamp is above the table.'    Ni-mmeng mui jo tai biei.  3SG-leaf dry be around tree  'There are dry leaves (directly) around the tree.'    Srad jo ghai dani.  book be around me  'The books are scattered around me.'    (Reesink 1999: 64)  ```    ```  Use of posture verbs:    No gwam ei meja behei.  he sit LOC table under  'He is sitting under the table.'  (Reesink 1999: 62)    Ya ei biei behei.  stand LOC tree under  'He is standing under a tree.'  (Reesink 1999: 62)    Minsien bong ei ig ne-te hi.  dog lie LOC house 3SG-side other  'The dog is lying beside the house.'  (Reesink 1999: 63)  ```    **English** (ISO 639-3: eng, Glottolog: stan1293)    English is like Hatam, in that location of inanimate entities is usually specified with *to be*, and not with a posture verb, although English also has posture verbs such as *lie*, *stand*, *sit* and *hang*. English is also coded 0.     Further reading    Ameka, F., & Levinson, S. C. (2007). [Introduction: The Typology and Semantics of Locative Predicates: Posturals, Positionals, and Other Beasts](http://pubman.mpdl.mpg.de/pubman/item/escidoc:59551:3/component/escidoc:59552/Ameka_2007_introduction.pdf). *Linguistics*, 45(5–6), 847–871.    Newman, J. (2002). A cross-linguistic overview of the posture verbs “sit”, “stand”, and “lie.” In J. Newman (Ed.), *The Linguistics of Sitting, Standing, and Lying* (pp. 1–24). Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing Company.     Related Features    * [GB116	Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB116)

Feature: Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
Clarifying comments: In languages with a small number of verbs verb-noun or verb-adjective locutions are used instead, e.g., 'do meeting' for 'meet'. If a language has a small number of verbs in this sense, typically it will says that there is a closed class of verbs and a large part of the grammar will be devoted to the constructions whereby a verb from the closed class combines with an open-class item to form the predicate in most sentences. If the grammar never remarks on the size of the verbal inventory this almost always means that the language does not have a small number of verbs in the sense of the present question.
wiki_summary: In languages with a small number of verbs verb-noun or verb-adjective locutions are used instead, e.g., 'do meeting' for 'meet'. If a language has a small number of verbs in this sense, typically it will says that there is a closed class of verbs and a large part of the grammar will be devoted to the constructions whereby a verb from the closed class combines with an open-class item to form the predicate in most sentences. If the grammar never remarks on the size of the verbal inventory this almost always means that the language does not have a small number of verbs in the sense of the present question.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there are fewer than 100 verbs in the language.     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned			     Examples  Djamindjung (Schultze-Bernt 2003:83) is an example of a language with only around 30 verbs.     Further reading  Schultze-Berndt, Eva. (2000) Simple and complex verbs in Jaminjung: A study of event categorisation in an Australian language. Katholieke Universiteit Nijmegen doctoral dissertation.     Related Features    GB123: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored.
wiki_summary: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if SV, 2 if VS, and 3 if both, not counting focus constructions, or left- or right-dislocation.     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Pronouns have opposite order	   * Different depending on clause type or TAM etc.	   * Occurs with a type of focus construction		     Examples    See WALS Chapter 82 http://wals.info/chapter/82.     Further reading    See WALS Chapter 82 http://wals.info/chapter/82.     Related Features  The other clause constituent features for transitive clauses:    - GB131: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?  - GB132: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?  - GB133: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?    And:    - GB134: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?  - GB136: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.
wiki_summary: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.      Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Pronouns have a different order	   * Different depending on clause type or TAM etc.			     Examples    See WALS Chapter.     Further reading    Dryer, Matthew S. (2005) Order of Subject, Object, and Verb. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), World Atlas of Language Structures, 330-333. Oxford University Press.    Dryer, Matthew S. (1989) Discourse-Governed Word Order and Word Order Typology.  Belgian Journal of Linguistics 4. 69-90.     Related Features  The other clause constituent features:    - GB130: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?  - GB132: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?  - GB133: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?    And:    - GB134: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?  - GB135: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?  - GB136: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
