Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Clarifying comments:
Whatever the order in main clauses is, does it change in subordinate clauses?
For example, is the order between woman/man/chases the same in 'the woman chases the man' versus 'I think that the woman chases the man'. It is sufficient for a 1 if there are different options in subordinate clauses that are not available in main clauses.
wiki_summary: Whatever the order in main clauses is, does it change in subordinate clauses?  For example, is the order between woman/man/chases the same in 'the woman chases the man' versus 'I think that the woman chases the man'. It is sufficient for a 1 if there are different options in subordinate clauses that are not available in main clauses.     Procedure       Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Only in some type of subordinate clauses	   * Order is more restricted in main clauses	  * Order is more restricted in subordinate clauses			     Examples  German is an example of a language that changes its word order in subordinate clauses in that the main verb invariably comes at the end in subordinate clauses while in main clauses it may appear as the second constituent.     Further reading    Dryer, Matthew S. (1992) Adverbial Subordinators and Word Order Asymmetries. In John A. Hawkins & Anna Siewerska (eds.), Performance Principles of Word Order, 50-67. European Science Foundationk: EUROTYP Working Papers.     Related Features  The clause constituent features:    - GB130: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?  - GB131: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?  - GB132: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?  - GB133: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?    And:    - GB135: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?  - GB136: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Clarifying comments: By clausal objects here we mean clauses that are directly governed by a finite verb (typically verbs of 'wanting', 'saying' etc.). In other words, complement subordinate clauses and not relative clauses. For example, 'I like apples' (nominal object) versus 'I like that you play the piano every morning' (clausal object) are in the same position (SVO). Many of the languages that do change are SOV languages that have SVO for (long) clausal objects. The question aims at discerning whether they are treated like prototypical nominal direct objects (not indirect or obliques). This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this.
wiki_summary: By clausal objects here we mean clauses that are directly governed by a finite verb (typically verbs of 'wanting', 'saying' etc.). In other words, complement subordinate clauses and not relative clauses. For example, 'I like apples' (nominal object) versus 'I like that you play the piano every morning' (clausal object) are in the same position (SVO). Many of the languages that do change are SOV languages that have SVO for (long) clausal objects. The question aims at discerning whether they are treated like prototypical nominal direct objects (not indirect or obliques). This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this.     Procedure  1. Find the word order regarding nominal objects (often mentioned explicitly).  2. Fine the word order regarding clausal objects (often from examples).  3. Code 1 if the positions are the same, and 0 otherwise.     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned     Examples  For example, 'I like apples' (nominal object) versus 'I like that you play the piano every morning' (clausal object) are in the same position (SVO).     Further reading  One point of interest is whether the position changes as clausal objects  are typically longer and have more internal parsing structure than nominal  objects. Some parsing/memory processing theory predicts that languages  should treat them differently as a result, see, e.g., Hawkins (2014) and  earlier work by him:    Hawkins, John A. 2014. Cross-linguistic Variation and Efficiency. Oxford: Oxford University Prees.     Related Features  The clause constituent features:    - GB130: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?  - GB131: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?  - GB132: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?  - GB133: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?    And:  - GB134: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?  - GB136: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Clarifying comments: The order is fixed if you cannot permute the order of core constituents and the verb without either i) changing the propositional content of the clause or ii) requiring intonational signalling or further elements (particles, cleft components, adjuncts).
wiki_summary: The order is fixed if you cannot permute the order of core constituents and the verb without either i) changing the propositional content of the clause or ii) requiring intonational signalling or further elements (particles, cleft components, adjuncts).     Procedure  1. Find the order of core arguments in the language.  2. Determine whether order permutations i) are possible, ii) do not change the propositional content and iii) do not require further elements (particles, cleft components, adjuncts)  3. If the three conditions of step 2 are all met, code 0 (order is not fixed), otherwise code 1 (order is fixed)     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned that there is any variation	   * There is variation due to topicalisation and focus				     Examples  Many Australian languages, e.g., Bardi (Bowern 2012:592-594), permute  the order of core arguments depending on discourse features. These order  differences do not change propositional content and require no further  elements and so Bardi is an example of a language coded as 0 for this  feature.    Bowern, Claire. (2012) A grammar of Bardi. Berlin: Mouton.     Further reading    Dryer, Matthew S. (1989) Discourse-Governed Word Order and Word Order Typology.  Belgian Journal of Linguistics 4. 69-90.     Related Features  The clause constituent features:    - GB130: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?  - GB131: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?  - GB132: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?  - GB133: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?    And:    - GB134: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?  - GB135: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. The position clause-final includes suffixes on verbs in verb-final clauses, even if it isn't indeed the very last suffix on the verb. Prefixes on clause-final verbs do not count as clause-final negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-final, this is sufficient to count as clause-final negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.
wiki_summary: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. The position "clause-final" includes suffixes on verbs in verb-final clauses, even if it isn't indeed the very last suffix on the verb. Prefixes on clause-final verbs do not count as clause-final negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-final, this is sufficient to count as clause-final negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.     Procedure  1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation.  2. Consider all the described constructions that fit the category of Standard Negation  3. If the marker is clause-final, code "1" for this feature (GB137).  4. If SN is both clause-initial and can also be clause-final, code "1" for this feature (GB137) and "1" for [GB138	Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB138)  5. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion     Examples    **Dutch** (ISO 639-3: nld, Glottocode: dutc1256)    The marker of standard negation in Dutch, _niet_ can (but does not always) appear at the end of the clause. Here is an example from Shetter (1984:146). This results in a coding of 1 for GB137.    ```  hij kent Anneke helemaal niet  3SG.MASC know Anneke at.all NEG  ‘He doesn't know Anneke at all’  ```     Further reading  * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Linguistics 27. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 1-27.  * Dahl, Östen. 1979. Typology of Sentence Negation. Linguistics 17. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 79-106.  * Dahl, Östen. 2010. "Typology of Negation" in Horn (ed) The Expression of Negation. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Negative Morphemes. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/112)  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Position of Negative Morpheme With Respect to Subject, Object, and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/144)  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Order of Negative Morpheme and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/143)   * Miestamo, Matti. 2013. Symmetric and Asymmetric Standard Negation. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/113)   * Payne, John R. 1985. "Negation". I Timothy Shopen (red), Language Typology and Syntactic Description, vol. 1. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.  * Shetter, William Z. 1994. _Dutch: an essential grammar_. London: Routledge. 267pp. (auf Einband: Essential Grammar).     Related Features  * [GB107	Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB107/)  * [GB137	Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB137)  * [GB138	Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB138)  * [GB139	Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB139)  * [GB140	Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB140)  * [GB298	Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB298)  * [GB299	Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB299)  * [GB400	Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB400)

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. This includes prefixes on clause-initial verbs, but suffixes on clause-initial verbs do not count as clause-initial negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-initial, this is sufficient to count as clause-initial negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.
wiki_summary: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. This includes prefixes on clause-initial verbs, but suffixes on clause-initial verbs do not count as clause-initial negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-initial, this is sufficient to count as clause-initial negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.     Procedure  1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation.  2. Consider all the described constructions that fit the category of Standard Negation  3. If the marker is clause-initial, code "1" for this feature (GB137).  4. If SN is both claus-initial and clause final, code "1" for this feature (GB138) and "1" for [GB137	Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB137)  5. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig).     Examples  **Bininj Kun-Wok** (ISO 639-3: gup, Glottocode: gunw1252)    Negation is marked by a free-standing particle that occurs before the verb, resulting in clauses where the negation is the first element. This is an example of coding 1 for GB138    ```  Marrek Birri-ngui-yi  NEG 3a/3-eat-IRR  ‘They didn't eat it’  ```         Further reading  * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Clarifying comments: Is the negative construction for declarative negation (I don't drink) different from negative imperative (don't drink!). This feature covers more than only different negators: different order, loss of finiteness or addition of new elements would also suffice. If the analysis of the language-specific researcher results in two different forms for negative imperative and prohibitive, then we are only concerned with the construction that is fulfilling the traditional imperative function here.
wiki_summary: Is the negative construction for declarative negation ("I don't drink") different from negative imperative ("don't drink!"). This feature covers more than only different negators: different order, loss of finiteness or addition of new elements would also suffice. If the analysis of the language-specific researcher results in two different forms for negative imperative and prohibitive, then we are only concerned with the construction that is fulfilling the traditional imperative function here.     Procedure  1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation.  2. Find the section that deals with imperative.  3. If there is not section that describes negative imperatives (aka "prohibitives"), code "?" for this feature.  4. If there are two different negators, code "1"  5. If negative imperatives and declarative constructions contain the same markers, but in a systematically different order, code "1"  6. If they are the same, code "0".  7. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig).  8. If clarity is not reached, code "?" for this feature     Examples  **Finnish** (ISO 639-3: fin, Glottocode: finn1318)    Standard negation in Finnish is accomplished with an inflecting verb and the main verb in a finite form. The negative imperative contains a different marker. Below is a paradigm based on Karlsson (1999:70, 168). Finnish is coded as 1 for this feature.    || affirmative | negative |   |---|  - |----------- |   |declarative| _he lukevat_ they read | _he eivät lue_ they do not read|   |imperative| _lue_ read! | _älä lue_ don't read!|        Further reading  * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Linguistics 27. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 1-27.  * Dahl, Östen. 1979. Typology of Sentence Negation. Linguistics 17. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 79-106.  * Dahl, Östen. 2010. "Typology of Negation" in Horn (ed) The Expression of Negation. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Negative Morphemes. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Clarifying comments: This feature pertains only to the negative marker itself, be it an independent particle, verb, auxiliary, clitic or affix. By non-verbal here we are referring to locational (the dog is in the kitchen), existential (There is a heaven) or nominal predication (Ursula is a witch). Negation of possession, attributives (adjectives) capability or knowing are not included. However, it is very likely that languages that have different negation from the standard negator for these functions also make a distinction between locational/existential and standard.
wiki_summary:
This feature pertains only to the negative marker itself, be it an independent particle, verb, auxiliary, clitic or affix. By non-verbal here we are referring to locational ("the dog is in the kitchen"), existential ("There is a heaven") or nominal predication ("Ursula is a witch"). Negation of possession, attributives (adjectives) capability or knowing are not included. However, it is very likely that languages that have different negation from the standard negator for these functions also make a distinction between locational/existential and standard. Procedure 1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation. 2. Find the sections that describe locational, existential and nominal predication. 3. If at least one of those three has a different negator from verbal negation, code this features as "0". 4. If you can only find information on one of those three, and it is the same as the verbal negation, code as "?". 5. If you can't find information on any of the three categories of non-verbal negation, code as "?" 6. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig). 7. If clarity is not reached, code "?" for this feature Examples **Turkish** (ISO 639-3: tur, Glottocode: nucl1301) Standard negation in Turkish is accomplished using the suffix _-mA_, but existential negation is marked by a different marker that takes tense marking (Kornfilt 1997:123-124). Turkish is coded as a 0 for this feature. 
    1)  _Hasan kitab-ı oku-ma-dı_        Hasan book-Acc. read-Neg-Past       'Hasan didn't read the book'      2) (ben) hasta deǧil-im       I sick Neg.Cop-1sg       'I am not sick'

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Clarifying comments: In a number of languages, predicates referring to uncontrolled events or states are encoded differently from those that refer to controlled events. Often, such a distinction surfaces in predicates referring to sensations (such as hunger, thirst, pain, cold, cramps, sleepiness ...), emotions (anger, happiness), or cognitive states (forgetting, remembering). Such uncontrolled predicates may be found in special constructions, different case frames ('sleep hits me', 'cramp footgrabs me'), they may form a special conjugation class of verbs or adjectives, there may be a dedicated (modal) marker for control vs. non-control, etc. The existence of verbal derivations such as passive or causative does not count as 1 here.
Relevant unit(s): clause, verb, adjective, noun, case marker, NP
Function: control, argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification
Form: special construction, flagging, indexing, conjugation, declension
wiki_summary: In a number of languages, predicates referring to uncontrolled events or states are encoded differently from those that refer to controlled events. Often, such a distinction surfaces in predicates referring to sensations (such as hunger, thirst, pain, cold, cramps, sleepiness ...), emotions (anger, happiness), or cognitive states (forgetting, remembering). Such uncontrolled predicates may be found in special constructions, different case frames ('sleep hits me', 'cramp footgrabs me'), they may form a special conjugation class of verbs or adjectives, there may be a dedicated (modal) marker for control vs. non-control, etc. The existence of verbal derivations such as passive or causative does not count as 1 here.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if an author discusses these kinds of constructions/conjugation classes/... in a grammar.  2. Code 1 if you find several examples of uncontrolled events or states that show a difference from the typical way of expressing (controlled) events or states (look for expressions of hunger, thirst, pain, sickness, vomiting, cold, cramps, sleepiness, anger, happiness).  3. Code 0 if an author explicitly mentions that such constructions are not a feature of the language (e.g. they didn't find any although they were expected to occur because they are found in neighboring languages).  4. Code 0 if you find many examples of uncontrolled events or states that are expressed like any other (controlled) event or state.  5. Code ? if nothing on the topic is said and there is not enough data to decide on whether such constructions may exist or not.     Examples    **Siwai** (ISO 639-3: siw, Glottolog: siwa1245)    Siwai has a lexical split in its alignment system. Intransitive-only verbs can be classified according to the kind of suffixal index they take. There are verbs that take so-called "SO" suffixes, which are made up of an O index + _-u_. In other words, the single argument of SO-verbs is coded the same as a patient in transitive verbs. In another class of intransitive verbs, which take "SA" suffixes, the single argument is coded the same as an agent in transitive verbs (Onishi 1994: 398, 401ff). Experiencers, which have no control over the events that happen to them, are coded differently from agents, which do have control over the action that is performed.    ```  Examples of SO-verbs (uncontrolled states)    haa- 'to want, to agree'  hingh- 'to decay'  hunok- 'to become/be full in stomach'  kamann- 'to feel cold'  kipi'tak 'to hiccup'    nii tuu haa-mu-u-ng  I water want-1SO-NRPAST-M  'I want water'    Onishi (1994: 401-402)  ```    ```  Examples of SA-verbs (controlled actions)    kumar- 'to laugh'  mon- 'to look'  pu'j- 'to shout'  konn- 'to walk'  nok- 'to say'    Onishi (1994: 403)  ```    **Nuu-chah-nulth** (ISO 639-3: nuk, Glottolog: nuuc1236)    Nuu-chah-nulth has a specialized future tense clitic _ʔaːqtɬ_, called 'intentive' by Davidson (2002: 305), that implies that the agent of an action has control over the event.    ```  ts'axʷ-ʃitɬ=ʔaːqtɬ=qa'=s  spear-PERF=INTENT=SUBOR=1sg  'And I am going to spear him.'  Davidson (2002: 305)  ```    **Khwarshi-Inkhoqwari** (ISO 639-3: khv, Glottolog: khva1239)    In Khwarshi-Inkhoqwari there is an 'accidental' marker for verbs, *l*, that indicates that an action is not voluntary and not controlled. Involuntary agents are marked with the contessive case. The verb for 'to blow', for example, can be coded as being controlled _puɬ-a_ or uncontrolled _puɬ-l-a_ (Khalilova 2009: 267).     Further reading    Comrie, B., & van den Berg, H. (2006). Experiencer constructions in Daghestanian languages. In I. Bornkessel, M. Schlesewsky, B. Comrie, & A. D. Friederici (Eds.), *Semantic Role Universals and Argument Linking: Theoretical, Typological, and Psycholinguistic Perspectives* (pp. 127–154). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. **On experiencer constructions, which often distinguish uncontrolled from controlled predicates.**    Haspelmath, M. (2001). Non-Canonical Marking of Core Arguments in European Languages. In A. Y. Aikhenvald, R. M. W. Dixon, & M. Onishi (Eds.), *Non-Canonical Marking of Subjects and Objects* (pp. 53–83). Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing Company. **On unusual case-frames, which may be used in languages to distinguish uncontrolled from controlled predicates.**     Related Features    None.

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Clarifying comments: Passivization is a detransitivizing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) passive markers on lexical verbs. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here.
Function: valency change, passive, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: Passivization is a detransitivizing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) passive markers on lexical verbs. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the use of a phonologically bound morpheme to mark passive clauses.   2. Code 1 if there is no information on phonological (in)dependence but the relevant passivizing marker (auxiliary or particle) is orthographically bound to the verb. Add a comment that your analysis is based on orthography here.  3. Code 1 if you identify a phonologically bound passive marker in the examples/texts provided in a source.  4. Code 0 if a source mentions that there is no passive.    5. Code 0 if a source mentions a phonologically free passive marker or other means of passivization, but not one that is phonologically bound to the verb  6. Code 0 if a grammar treats other valency changing operations in considerable depth but does not mention passive constructions.  7. Code ? if there are examples that contain a potential passivizing construction but their analysis remains inconclusive.    8. Code ? if there are no sources treating valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.  		     Examples    **Udihe** (ISO 639-3: ude, Glottolog: udih1248)     Udihe has a morphological passive, which is formed with the suffix *-u*:    ```  si min-du gida-si-u-zeŋe-i  you me-DAT spear-V-PAS-FUT-2SG  'You will be killed by me.  (Nikolaeva & Tolskaya 2001:572-582)  ```    **Jamaican Creole English** (ISO 639-3: jam, Glottolog: jama1262)     Passives in Jamaican Creole English are formed with the particle *get*. It is coded 0 in Grambank.    ```  Op tu nou dem no nuo ou di fuud get kuk.  up to now 3PL NEG know how DET food PAS cook  'Even now they still don't know how the food was cooked.'  (Farquharson 2013: 86, PAS in gloss is mine, J)  ```    **Bongili** (ISO 639-3: bui, Glottolog: bong1284)     According to Mangulu (2008), Bongili only forms passives by means of a word order change. It is coded 0 for this feature.    ```  "Le passif est rendu ... par l'antéposition du patient avec ou sans pronominalisation   redondante..." (Mangulu 2008: 30)    Active:    ɓa-bom-ák-á moto yáná  3pl-kill-PAST-DIST man yesterday  'They killed a man yesterday.'    Passive:    moto ɓa-bom-ák-á yáná  man 3pl-kill-PAST-DIST yesterday  'A man was killed yesterday.'    (my simplified analysis and glosses)    ```    **Kuku-Uwanh** (ISO 639-3: uwa, Glottolog: kuku1280)     For Kuku-Uwanh, authors Smith & Johnson (2000) explicitly mention that there is no passive or antipassive construction. It is coded 0.    ```  "Nganhcara lacks passive or antipassive constructions. Free word order and the optional   omission of constituents allows Nganhcara to achieve the discourse functions of these   formations without morphological apparatus." (Smith & Johnson 2000: 425)  ```      Further reading    Haspelmath, M. (1990). The Grammaticization of Passive Morphology. *Studies in Language*, 14(1), 25–72.    Keenan, E. L., & Dryer, M. S. (2007). [Passive in the World’s Languages](http://linguistics.ucla.edu/people/keenan/Papers/KeenanDryerPassiveProofs.pdf). In T. Shopen (Ed.), *Language Typology and Syntactic Description, Volume I: Clause Structure* (Second Edition, pp. 325–361). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.    Siewierska, A. (2013). [Passive Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/107). In M. S. Dryer & M. Haspelmath (Eds.), *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.     Related Features    * [GB148	Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB148)    * [GB302	Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB302)    * [GB303	Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB303)    * [GB304	Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB304)    * [GB400	Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB400)

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Clarifying comments: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets productive [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) antipassive markers on lexical verbs, as well as reduplication. Zero-marking or the removal of a transitivizing marker is not sufficient for a 1. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here. If the antipassive marker is only applied in a limited set of probably lexicalized items, it does not trigger 1.
Function: valency change, antipassive, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets productive [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) antipassive markers on lexical verbs, as well as reduplication. Zero-marking or the removal of a transitivizing marker is not sufficient for a 1. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here. If the antipassive marker is only applied in a limited set of probably lexicalized items, it does not trigger 1.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the use of a phonologically bound morpheme to mark antipassive clauses.  2. Code 1 if there is no information on phonological (in)dependence but the relevant antipassive marker (auxiliary or particle) is orthographically bound to the verb. Add a comment that your analysis is based on orthography here.  3. Code 1 if you identify a phonologically bound antipassive marker in the examples/texts provided in a source.  4. Code 0 if a source mentions that there is no antipassive.  5. Code 0 if a source mentions a phonologically free antipassive marker or other means of marking antipassives, but not one that is phonologically bound to the verb  6. Code 0 if a grammar treats other valency changing operations in considerable depth but does not mention antipassive constructions.  7. Code ? if there are examples that contain a potential antipassive construction but their analysis remains inconclusive.  8. Code ? if there are no sources treating valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.		     Examples    **Kuku Yalanji** (ISO 639-3: gvn, Glottolog: kuku1273)    Kuku Yalanji is an example of a language with ergative alignment for nouns that features antipassive marking. As shown in the example below, the antipassive is formed with the suffix *-ji*. In the antipassive clause the former ergative argument in the active clause ('the man', A) becomes absolutive (S). The former absolutive argument (O) becomes an oblique, locative argument in the antipassive clause.    ```  Active clause:  nyulu dingkar-angka minya nuka-ny  3sg.NOM(A) man-ERG:pt(A) meat.ABS(O) eat-PAST  'The man ate meat.'  (Patz 2002: 152)    Antipassive clause:  nyulu dingkar minya-nga nuka-ji-ny  3sg.NOM(S) man.ABS(S) meat-LOC eat-ANTI-PAST  'The man had a good feed of meat (he wasted nothing.)  (Patz 2002: 152)  ```    At the same time, the antipassive marker in Kuku Yalanji exemplifies how such markers often also fulfill other detransitivizing functions in languages such as passivization.    ```  Passive clause:  warru (yaburr-undu) bayka-ji-ny  yg.man.ABS(S) shark-LOC:pt bite-PASS-PAST  'The young man was bitten (by a shark).  (Patz 2002: 148)  ```  **Cilubà** (ISO 639-3: abc, Glottolog: luba1249)    Cilubà is an example of an accusative language without core case flags that has an antipassive marker, *angan*. The typical function of the antipassive in Cilubà is to indicate a non-punctual (e.g. a custom or habit) action by which a non-identifiable patient is affected, or different patients, the identity of which is not immediately relevant in the discourse situation, are affected (Dom, Bostoen & Segerer 2015).     ```  Active:  Mù-sàlaayì u-di ù-lu-a mu-lwishì  NP1-solfier PC1-PRS SC1-fight-FV NP1-enemy  'The soldier who is fighting the enemy.'    Antipassive:  Mù-sàlaayì y-di ù-lu-angan-a mu ci-alu cì-à m-vità  NP1-soldier PC1-PRS SC1-fight-ANTIP-FV LOC18 NP7-meeting.place PC7-CON NP1n-war  'The soldier who is fighting (someone) on the battlefield...'    Dom et al. (2015: 355)  ```     Further reading    Cooreman, A. (1994). A Functional typology of Antipassives. In B. A. Fox & P. J. Hopper (Eds.), *Voice: Form and Function* (pp. 49–88). Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing Company.    Janic, K. (2013). [*L’antipassif dans les langues accusatives*](http://theses.univ-lyon2.fr/documents/lyon2/2013/janic_k/pdfAmont/janic_k_these.pdf) (PhD Thesis). Université Lumière Lyon 2, Lyon.    Polinsky, M. (2013). [Antipassive Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/108). In M. S. Dryer & M. Haspelmath (Eds.), *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Polinsky, M. (2017). [Antipassive](http://ling.umd.edu/assets/publications/Polinsky-17-Antipassive.pdf). In J. Coon, D. Massam, & L. DeMena Travis (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Ergativity*. Oxford: Oxford University Press. Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Clarifying comments: Inverse systems (as defined in this project) are based on an animacy, person, or topicality hierarchy (e.g. first/second person > third person > cats > dogs > other animals > inanimates). Languages can have markers on transitive verbs that indicate whether the agent(-like argument) of the clause is higher on this hierarchy than the patient(-like argument) [= direct marker], or whether the reverse is true, i.e. that the patient outranks the agent on the hierarchy [= inverse marker]. An example would be 'man INV-bite dog' to mean 'the dog bit the man'. Note that in some languages, there are portmanteau morphemes that both function as a person index on verbs and as direct/inverse markers, so different person indexes are used based on where the agent and patient are located relative to each other on the hierarchy. This counts as a 1 for this question. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) inverse markers on lexical verbs.
wiki_summary: Inverse systems (as defined in this project) are based on an animacy, person, or topicality hierarchy (e.g. first/second person > third person > cats > dogs > other animals > inanimates). Languages can have markers on transitive verbs that indicate whether the agent(-like argument) of the clause is higher on this hierarchy than the patient(-like argument) [= direct marker], or whether the reverse is true, i.e. that the patient outranks the agent on the hierarchy [= inverse marker]. An example would be 'man INV-bite dog' to mean 'the dog bit the man'. Note that in some languages, there are portmanteau morphemes that both function as a person index on verbs and as direct/inverse markers, so different person indexes are used based on where the agent and patient are located relative to each other on the hierarchy. This counts as a 1 for this question. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) inverse markers on lexical verbs.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar discusses a marker on the verb that encodes that the patient outranks the agent on an animacy or person hierarchy.  2. Code 1 if there are markers on the verb that can be analyzed as encoding that the patient is higher on an animacy or person hierarchy than the agent. Sometimes authors do not explicitly discuss the function of these markers or they do not present a hierarchy, but they may present a paradigm from which you can figure out the pattern.  3. Code 1 if different indexes are used according to whether the patient outranks the agent on an animacy or person hierarchy or the reverse is true.  4. Code 0 if there are no signs of such a system in the language.     Examples    **Panare** (ISO 639-3: pbh, Glottolog: enap1235)    In Panare (Payne & Payne 2013: 24-25), the inverse marker *y-* only occurs in past-perfective verbs. It indicates that the patient of a clause outranks the agent of the clause on the following topicality hierarchy: 1SG/2 > 3/1PL. It also seems to be used when both the agent and patient are third person.    ```  Kën a-y-ïkïtï-yaj / amën y-^-ḯkïtï-yaj.  an.invis 2-inv-cut-pperf1 2sg inv-di-cut-pperf1  ‘He/she cut you.’  ```    **Cherokee** (ISO 639-3: chr, Glottolog: cher1273)    In Cherokee, there are two sets of prefixes, a 'direct' one and an 'inverse' one. In addition to marking direct or inverse, each prefix also indexes the most animate participant (indicating its person and number). Cherokee would receive 1 for this feature.    ```  anii-kééhya sookwili tee-anii-ahyvthéeɁa   3A-woman horse DST-DIR.3.PL-kick:PRC   ‘The women are kicking the horses’ x  (Scancarelli 1987: 128)  ```    ```  sookwili kaa-uunii-ahyvthéeɁa anii-kééhya   horse ANP-INV.3.PL-kick:PRC 3A-woman   ‘The horses are kicking the women’   (Scancarelli 1987: 129)  ```     Further reading    Klaiman, M. H. (1992). [Inverse languages](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/5edb/28002c60aaa3cad87e7563f21b724ff9af11.pdf). *Lingua*, 88(3/4), 227–261.    Zúñiga, F. (2006). *Deixis and alignment: Inverse systems in indigenous languages of the Americas*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features    * [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    * [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    * [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    * [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    * [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    * [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB94)    * [GB105	Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB105)

Feature: Is there clause chaining?
Clarifying comments:
Clause-chaining here is not just juxtapositioning of minimal clauses with no connectors, but chains of medial clauses (i.e. formally reduced clauses that do not have the full marking that usually occurs on the verb) which are dependent on a single verb that usually (but not always) occurs in a final position. This complete verb is fully specified to provide the missing categories (e.g. TAM, argument marking) for the entire clause chain. Clause chains may be referred to as topic chains, or as sequences of medial clauses/medial verbs. Crucially, this construction involves a single independent verb form, with several medial verbs that are dependent on it for full specification. Clause chains are generally used to describe simple sequences of events, and the medial verbs involved are often marked by special affixes.

Some analyses assert that medial verbs are coordinated, or at the very least not subordinated. However, it can be very difficult to determine this from descriptions and examples in grammars. Here we focus less on these syntactic distinctions and more on surface forms that fit the above description (sequences of stripped down verb forms dependent on a single verb for full specification), used for describing simple sequences of events.

In some cases clause-chaining may be difficult to distinguish from serial verb constructions. Remember that a serial verb construction involves a set of verbs or verb phrases that are typically inflected identically for TAM in a single clause, whereas clause-chaining involves a set of formally reduced clauses involving unmarked verbs, all dependent on a single fully specified verb form. Clause-chaining is also different from verb compounding, in that the verbs involved in clause-chaining all carry full semantic weight (in contrast to the light verb of verb compounding) and different arguments (e.g. objects) may occur in each clause (whereas a verb compound takes a single set of arguments as a whole). In cases where it is unclear which of these constructions is represented by the examples in the grammar, a (?) may be coded, but be sure to indicate in the comments that you were unable to determine which of these constructions is demonstrated in the relevant examples.

This complete verb is fully specified to provide the missing categories (e.g. TAM, argument marking) for the entire clause chain. Clause chains may be referred to as topic chains, or as sequences of medial clauses/medial verbs. Crucially, this construction involves a single independent verb form, with several medial verbs that are dependent on it for full specification. Clause chains are generally used to describe simple sequences of events, and the medial verbs involved are often marked by special affixes.    Some analyses assert that medial verbs are coordinated, or at the very least not subordinated. However, it can be very difficult to determine this from descriptions and examples in grammars. Here we focus less on these syntactic distinctions and more on surface forms that fit the above description (sequences of stripped down verb forms dependent on a single verb for full specification), used for describing simple sequences of events.    In some cases clause-chaining may be difficult to distinguish from serial verb constructions. Remember that a serial verb construction involves a set of verbs or verb phrases that are typically inflected identically for TAM in a single clause, whereas clause-chaining involves a set of formally reduced clauses involving unmarked verbs, all dependent on a single fully specified verb form. Clause-chaining is also different from verb compounding, in that the verbs involved in clause-chaining all carry full semantic weight (in contrast to the light verb of verb compounding) and different arguments (e.g. objects) may occur in each clause (whereas a verb compound takes a single set of arguments as a whole). In cases where it is unclear which of these constructions is represented by the examples in the grammar, a (?) may be coded, but be sure to indicate in the comments that you were unable to determine which of these constructions is demonstrated in the relevant examples.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if the language can express a sequence of events through a series of morphologically reduced verb forms that typically precedes and is dependent on a single, fully-specified verb form.     Examples  **Kumyk** (ISO: kum, Glottolog: kumy1244)    bu-lar, k&246;l-n&252; g&246;r-&252;p,    this-PL lake-ACC see-CONV     araba-syn toqtat-yp,    cart-3.POSS stop-CONV    &269;emodan-ny Manaj-ga da g&246;ter-t-ip,    suitcase-ACC name-DAT also take-CAUS-CONV    k&246;l-n&252; ja&287;a-syn-a bar-yp,    lake-GEN bank-3.POSS-DAT go-CONV    &269;emodan-ny a&269;-yp,    suitcase-ACC open-CONV    &353;y&353;la-ny &269;y&287;ar-yp,    bottle-ACC take.out-CONV    tiz-ip,    put.in.row-CONV    suw-dan toltur-yp,    water-ABL fill-CONV    qajtar-yp &269;emodan-&287;a sal-a.    return-CONV suitcase-DAT put-PRS    _They see the lake, stop their cart, make Manaj bring the suitcase, go to the bank of the lake, open the suitcase, take out the bottles, put them in a row, fill them with water, and put_ (PRS) _them back in the suitcase._  (D&382;anmavov 1967:234)     Further reading  Haspelmath, Martin. 1995. The converb as a cross-linguistically valid category. In M. Haspelmath and E. Konig (eds.) Converbs in Cross-linguistic Perspective. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. 1-55.    Weisser, Philipp. 2013. Dissecting clause-chaining constructions. ConSOLE XXI. Potsdam, 11 Jan. 2013.       Related Features  * [GB118: Serial verb constructions](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB118)  * [GB151: Switch reference](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB151)  * [GB152: Morphological distinctions between simultaneous and sequential clauses](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB152)

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Clarifying comments: Is there an overt marker on the verb, that marks whether the argument has the same/different referent as an argument of the following clause? Some languages (e.g. Kashaya) signal switch reference by using different allomorphs of TAM markers depending on whether the subject of the following clause is the same or different. Some systems (e.g. Southeastern Pomo) only have special morphology to indicate different subjects, whereas the marker that is used for same subjects can also be used for some combinations of clauses with different referents.
wiki_summary: Is there an overt marker on the verb, that marks whether the argument has the same/different referent as an argument of the following clause? Some languages (e.g. Kashaya) signal switch reference by using different allomorphs of TAM markers depending on whether the subject of the following clause is the same or different. Some systems (e.g. Southeastern Pomo) only have special morphology to indicate different subjects, whereas the marker that is used for same subjects can also be used for some combinations of clauses with different referents.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is a marker or morphological alternation that signals whether the subject of a clause has the same or different referent as an argument (usually the subject) of an adjacent clause.     Examples    **Washo** (ISO 639-3: was, Glottolog: wash1253)    *No Switch of Reference*    ya&331;&225;hadik'&616;li g&250;&577;&353;emi&577;&233;:seti&577;a&577;    they-ran-back-and-forth they-stopped-making-noise    'They ran back and forth and stopped making noise.'      *Switch of Reference*    m&233;mluyi-&353; l&233;mehi     if-you-eat-SWITCH I'll-drink    'If you eat, I'll drink.'    (Jacobsen 1967: 247)    Washo would be coded 1 because it uses a -&353; suffix on the verb to mark a switch in reference in the following clause.    **Southeastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: pom, Glottolog: sout2982)    Southeastern Pomo uses markers on the verb to signal sequential actions in sentences comprised of multiple clauses. A general form of the sequential action marker can be used whether or not the subject of the first clause is the same as the second clause, according to Moshinsky.    &577;a x&803;ol-o-fla qnak'-ya    1SG hither-travel-SEQ fall.asleep-PERF    'He fell asleep after I came'      yiwi yoq-fla bxe t&803;laq-ya    3SG shoot-SEQ deer fall.over-PERF    'After he shot it, the deer fell over'      A different sequential marker is also available, which specifies that the clauses have different subjects.    &577;a x&803;ol-o-yukin tu qnak'-in-ya    1SG hither-travel-SEQ.SWITCH already fall.asleep-?-PERF    'He fell asleep before I came'      ma moc'ki-yukin &577;a til-o-di-t    2SG wake.up-SEQ.SWITCH 1SG thither-travel-POTENTIAL-IMPERF    'I'll go before you wake up'    (Moshinsky 1974: 76)    Southeastern Pomo would be coded 1. Although the general sequential marker can be used whether or not there is a switch in the referent of the subject across two clauses, there is an allomorph of the sequential action marker that is dedicated to marking a switch in the referent of the subject across adjacent clauses.     Further reading  Austin, Peter. 1981. Switch-reference in Australia. Language 57: 309-334.    Jacobsen, William. 1983. Typological and genetic notes on switch-reference in North American languages. In J. Haiman and P. Munro (eds.), Proceedings of a Symposium on Switch Reference and Universal Grammar. Amsterdam: John Benjamins. 151-183.    Roberts, John. 1997. Switch-Reference in Papua New Guinea. Papers in Papuan Linguistics 3, 101–241. Canberra, ACT, Australia: Australian National University.     Related Features  * [GB152: Marking of simultaneous and sequential clauses](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB152)

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with whether there is an overt marker dedicated to signaling the distinction between temporally simultaneous and sequential actions. If sequential meaning is a secondary function of an imperfective aspect this does not count; it must be indicated by a devoted marker. The language does not need to express both sequential and simultaneous temporal relationships overtly; one marker devoted to either function will do.
wiki_summary: This question is concerned with whether there is an overt marker dedicated to signaling the distinction between temporally simultaneous and sequential actions. If sequential meaning is a secondary function of an imperfective aspect this does not count; it must be indicated by a devoted marker. The language does not need to express both sequential and simultaneous temporal relationships overtly; one marker devoted to either function will do.     Procedure  1. If there is a marker in the verbal morphology that indicates the action of an adjacent verb is temporally simultaneous with that verb, code 1.  2. If there is a marker in the verbal morphology that indicates that the action of an adjacent verb is temporally sequential with that verb, code 1.  3. If clauses or verbs are combined in a way that implies sequential or simultaneous action but no overt verb marker is dedicated to this function, code 0.  4. If simultaneous or sequential temporal relationships are implied through the use of imperfective aspect or adverbial elements other than a dedicated verbal marker, code 0.		     Examples  **Southeastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: pom, Glottolog: sout2982)    Southeastern Pomo uses different markers on the verb to signal whether the action expressed by the following verb form happened in sequence with the action of the first verb, or simultaneous with the first verb.    *Simultaneous* -day    yiwi &577;a sca-day sma-n q'lal-ya    3SG 1SG be.there-SIMULT sleep get-PERF    'He fell asleep while I was there'      &577;a wit xbac'-day x&803;ol-o-di-t    1SG 1SG.obj ask-SIMULT hither-travel-POTENTIAL-IMPERF    'I'll come when he asks me'      *Sequential* -fla    &577;a x&803;ol-o-fla qnak'-ya    1SING hither-travel-SEQ fall.asleep-PERF    'He fell asleep after I came'      yiwi yoq-fla bxe t&803;laq-ya    3SING shoot-SEQ deer fall.over-PERF    'After he shot it, the deer fell over'    (Moshinsky 1974: 76)      Southeastern Pomo would be coded 1 because the temporal relationship between sequential events is marked by a suffix on the verb. There is also a marker on the verb to indicate simultaneous events. However, this language would still be coded 1 if only one of these temporal relationship markers existed.     Further reading  Please contact the patron of this feature for references relevant to this phenomenon.     Related Features  * [GB151: Switch-reference](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB151)

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Clarifying comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are targeted by this question. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) causative markers.
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
wiki_summary: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are targeted by this question. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) causative markers.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the use of a phonologically bound morpheme to mark causatives.  2. Code 1 if there is no information on phonological (in)dependence but the relevant causative marker is orthographically bound to the verb. Add a comment that your analysis is based on orthography here.  3. Code 1 if you identify a phonologically bound causative marker in the examples/texts provided in a source.  4. Code 0 if a source mentions that there is no causative.    5. Code 0 if a source mentions a periphrastic or phonologically independent causative construction, but not one marked with a bound marker.    6. Code 0 if a grammar treats other valency changing operations in considerable depth but does not mention causative constructions.  7. Code ? if there are examples that contain a potential causative construction but their analysis remains inconclusive.    8. Code ? if there are no sources treating valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.       Examples    **Ao Naga** (ISO 639-3: njo, Glottolog: aona1235)    Ao Naga (or Chungli Ao, in the source) has a causative suffix, *-taktsɨ*, which can transitivize intransitive sentences, as well as add an additional role to an already transitive clause:    ```  (Intransitive > transitive)  ni-i la tʃip-taktsɨ  1.SG-AGT 3.SG.FEM cry-CAUS.PERF  'I made her cry.'  (Escamilla 2012: 54-56)    (Transitive > ditransitive)  pa-i la-nem mapa injak-takstsɨ  3.SG.MASC-AGT 3.SG.FEM-NEM chore do/work-CAUS.PERF  'He made her do work.'  (Escamilla 2012: 54-56)  ```    **Barain** (ISO 639-3: bva, Glottolog: bare1279)    Like other Chadic languages, Barain has fossilized remains of a system of intransitive-causative vowel alternation, which is no longer productive (Lovestrand 2012: 126-127). There is no other transitivizing morphology (although there is a passive, reflexive and reciprocal). It is coded as 0.     Further reading    Escamilla, R. M. (2012). [*An Updated Typology of Causative Constructions: Form-Function Mappings in Hupa (California Athabaskan), Chungli Ao (Tibeto-Burman) and Beyond*](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.453.9124&rep=rep1&type=pdf) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.    Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.     Related Features    * [GB113	Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB113)    * [GB156	Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB156)

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Clarifying comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are included in this feature. This question targets causative constructions that feature an element that clearly originated as a verb that means or meant 'to say' (e.g. 'I said for the stone to fall' to mean 'I made the stone fall'). Note that, exceptionally, for this feature, constructions that appear to be synchronically fossilized but were clearly productive in the past also count.
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
wiki_summary: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are included in this feature. This question targets causative constructions that feature an element that clearly originated as a verb that means or meant 'to say' (e.g. 'I said for the stone to fall' to mean 'I made the stone fall'). Note that, exceptionally, for this feature, constructions that appear to be synchronically fossilized but were clearly productive in the past also count.   Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the existence of a causative construction that features an element that originates as a verb for 'to say'.  2. Code 1 if you spot an unambiguous causative construction that features an element that otherwise means 'to say' (e.g. where the causee is an inanimate entity)  3. Code 0 if causative constructions are comprehensively discussed, but nothing is said about a causative construction featuring a 'say' element.  4. Code 0 if there are no causative constructions.  5. Code ? if you spot potential causative constructions featuring a 'say' element, but the analysis is inconclusive.  6. Code ? if there are no sources treating causatives or other valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.     Examples    **Amkoe** (ISO 639-3: huc, Glottolog: hoaa1235)    Amkoe has a bound causative prefix *kí-*, exemplified here, that is very similar to the verb for 'say', *kíí* (Collins & Gruber 2014: 165)    ```  ǎ"ri yà xà 'a kí-|'í yȁ  what Q QF PROG CAUSE-cry 3SG  "What is making him/her cry?"  ```    **Nukna** (ISO 639-3: klt, Glottolog: nukn1238)    Nukna usually expresses causative meaning through clause chaining. The verb *me* 'say' is one of the main verbs that is used in such clause chains. In the following examples, the meaning of *me* is clearly causative:    ```  ko me-tá umi=yá tárikngi-ine-k  2SG.AGT speak-2SG.DS.SEQ water=AGT become.dry-FUT-3SG  'You say (something that causes) the water (to) become dry.'    ámna yáin-lá=yá me-t ámnanáráwa=yá yáup tá-u-ráng  man head-3SG.POSS=AGT speak-2/3PL.DS.SEQ people=AGT work do-RP-2/3PL  'The head men said (something that caused) the people (to) do the work.'    (Taylor 2015: 130)  ```     Further reading    Escamilla, R. M. (2012). [*An Updated Typology of Causative Constructions: Form-Function Mappings in Hupa (California Athabaskan), Chungli Ao (Tibeto-Burman) and Beyond*](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.453.9124&rep=rep1&type=pdf) (PhD Thesis). University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California.     Haspelmath, M., & Müller-Bardey, T. (2004). [Valency change](http://www.eva.mpg.de/fileadmin/content_files/staff/haspelmt/pdf/2005val.pdf). In G. E. Booij, C. Lehmann, J. Mugdan, & S. Skopeteas (Eds.), *Morphology: An International Handbook on Inflection and Word-Formation* (Vol. 2, pp. 1130–1145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyter.      Related Features    * [GB155	Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB155)

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Clarifying comments: The repetition of phonological material within a word for semantic or grammatical purposes is known as reduplication. In order for there to be a (1) here reduplication needs to be a productive pattern and the copies need to be adjacent. Both full and partial reduplication count. The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone.

The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	   * Some examples but not productive	   * Possible partial reduplication	   * There are instances of repeated verbs but that does not count as reduplication			     Examples     Further reading    Gil, David. 2005. From repetition to reduplication in Riau Indonesian. In Bernhard Hurch & Veronika Mattes (eds.), Studies on reduplication. Berlin; New York: Mouton de Gruyter.     Related Features  The other reduplication features:    - GB159: Are nouns reduplicated?  - GB160: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?

From repetition to reduplication in Riau Indonesian. In Bernhard Hurch & Veronika Mattes (eds.), Studies on reduplication. Berlin; New York: Mouton de Gruyter. Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Clarifying comments: The repetition of phonological material within a word for semantic or grammatical purposes is known as reduplication. In order for there to be a (1) here reduplication needs to be a productive pattern. Both full and partial reduplication count. The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. Reduplication is a productive pattern, a few examples of repetition of phonological material does not necessarily constitute evidence of reduplication. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone. Word classes other than verbs and nouns that are subject to reduplication include adjectives (red-red) or adverbs (daily-daily). The element reduplicated in the feature needs to consistitute a phonological word (i.e., a reduplicated affix does not count).

Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. The element reduplicated in the feature needs to consistitute a phonological word (i.e., a reduplicated affix does not count).     Procedure     Examples     Further reading    Gil, David. 2005. From repetition to reduplication in Riau Indonesian. In Bernhard Hurch & Veronika Mattes (eds.), Studies on reduplication. Berlin; New York: Mouton de Gruyter. Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns bound grammatical marking of trial number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB319	Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB319) which focuses on the non-bound marking of trial number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.
wiki_summary: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of trial number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB319	Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB319) which focuses on the non-bound marking of trial number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or nominal morphology  2. If the author describes a bound marker of trial number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the only marking of trial number are on nouns derived from other word classes (adjectives, verbs etc) or only a small subset of all nouns, code 0  4. If the grammar describes trial number as not marked productively or somewhere else but on the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Northwest Kiwai**   (ISO 639-3: kiw, Glottocode: nort2930)     Trial marking is not common, and since a similar enough meaning can often be expressed with a plural marker trial is rarely (if ever) described as being obligatory. However, there are languages where markers of trial number appear on the noun and dissimilarly from the numeral three. Kiwai is coded as 1 for GB165    Brown et al (2016:25)  ```  Umi=obi ro pusi p-obodidio bi=mo   dog=TR NOM cat DPST-chase TR=PL  ‘Three dogs chased the cat.’  ```  Brown et al (2016:46)  ```  netua ga'u  two one  ‘three (numeral)’  ```     Further reading  * Jason Brown and Alex Muir and Kimberley Craig and Karika Anea. 2016. A short grammar of Urama. Canberra: Asia-Pacific Linguistics. 101pp.  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)     Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for Feature: Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns bound grammatical marking of paucal (From Latin _paucalis_ meaning “few, little”) number on nouns, i.e. a number marker that is unspecified as to exact amount, but more than one and usually less than 10 (depending on what is being counted). This feature is in contrast to [GB320 Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB320) which focuses on the non-bound marking of paucal number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

This feature is in contrast to [GB320 Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB320) which focuses on the non-bound marking of paucal number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or nominal morphology  2. If the author describes a bound marker of paucal number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the only marking of paucal number are on nouns derived from other word classes (adjectives, verbs etc) or only a small subset of all nouns, code 0  4. If the grammar describes paucal number as not marked productively or somewhere else but on the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Sa** (ISO 639-3: sax, Glottocode: saaa1241)    Paucal marking is not common, and since a similar enough meaning can often be expressed with a plural marker it is rarely (if ever) described as being obligatory. However, there are languages where markers of paucal number appear on the noun. Sa is an example of code 1 for GB166, there is a paucal suffix (and trial).    Elliot (1976:45)    ```  asalsal-ir-pat  whiteman-PL-PAUC  ‘white men (3 or 4)’    ```  ```  dam-ir-til  yam-PL-TRIAL  ‘yams (3 exactly)’    ```  ```kuli-r-  dog-PL  ‘dogs’    ```     Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Elliott, George Robert. 1976. A description of Sa, a New Hebrides language. (MA thesis, Macquarie University; 258pp.)     Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB041)
