Feature: Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Logophoric pronouns are used distinguish reference to an individual whose speech or thought or feeling is being reported from other third-person referents. Unsurprisingly, then, logophoric pronouns are commonly found in reported speech contexts. This question concerns the existence of an anaphoric pronoun that specifically receives its referential identity from the 3rd person subject of the superordinate clause in a reported speech construction (i.e. the speaker/thinker/feeler). In other words, is there a special pronominal form that occurs in the complement clause of a speech or thought verb, that designates the subject of the speech/thought verb as its referent (as opposed to any other 3rd person referent)?
wiki_summary: Logophoric pronouns are used distinguish reference to an individual whose speech or thought or feeling is being reported from other third-person referents. Unsurprisingly, then, logophoric pronouns are commonly found in reported speech contexts. This question concerns the existence of an anaphoric pronoun that specifically receives its referential identity from the subject of the superordinate clause in a reported speech construction (i.e. the speaker/thinker/feeler). In other words, is there a special pronominal form that occurs in the complement clause of a speech or thought verb, that designates the subject of the speech/thought verb as its referent (as opposed to any other referent)?     Procedure  1. If there is a pronominal form that is used in the complement clause of a speech/thought verb to indicate co-reference with the individual whose speech/thought is represented in that clause (i.e. the subject of the superordinate clause)...  2. And if this pronoun has a different form than the personal and reflexive pronoun, then code 1.  3. If the logophoric pronoun meets the criteria in (1) and (2) above, but is derived from another pronoun, code 1.  4. If there is no difference in the pro-form used when the referent in a reported speech subordinate clause is the individual whose speech is reported or a different individual, code 0.     Examples    **Ewe** (ISO 639-3: ewe, Glottolog: ewee1241)    Kofi be y&232;-dzo    NAME say LOG-leave    Kofi<sub>i</sub> said he<sub>i</sub> was leaving.      Kofi be e-dzo    NAME say pro-leave    Kofi<sub>i</sub> said he/she<sub>j</sub> was leaving.    (Clements 1975: 142)    Ewe would be coded 1, because there is a special anaphoric pro-form used to indicate that the speaker (Kofi) who is the subject of the first clause is also the subject of the second clause. When Kofi is not the subject of the subordinate clause, a non-logophoric 3rd person pronoun is used.    This contrasts with a language like English, where no logophoric pronoun exists, and both of these meanings are expressed with the same form:    John<sub>i</sub> said he<sub>i/j</sub> was leaving.    This can mean that either John was leaving and said so, or that John said that someone else was leaving. English would be coded 0.     Further reading  Clements, George N. 1975. The logophoric pronoun in Ewe: Its role in discourse. Journal of West African Languages 2: 141–177.    Hyman, Larry M. and Bernard Comrie. 1981. Logophoric reference in Gokana. Studies in African Linguistics 3: 19–37.     Related Features  * [GB305: Reflexive pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB305)

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Gender is defined as a fixed, closed class system of classes that nouns fall into, as opposed to noun classifiers which are more open and tend to be therefore larger in number.  This question is about whether adjectives (defined semantically as 'adnominal property words') show agreement with gender of nouns they modify.  This be true for more than a small class of semantically restricted adjectives; English 'blond' v. 'blonde' for example would not be enough to answer 1 for the question.  Code 1 even if it is restricted in a particular context, such as in the plural.
wiki_summary: Gender is defined as a fixed, closed class system of classes that nouns fall into, as opposed to noun classifiers which are more open and tend to be therefore larger in number.  This question is about whether adjectives (defined semantically as 'adnominal property words') show agreement with gender of nouns they modify.  This be true for more than a small class of semantically restricted adjectives; English 'blond' v. 'blonde' for example would not be enough to answer 1 for the question.  Code 1 even if it is restricted in a particular context, such as in the plural.     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used when at least some adnominal property words are used that varies according to the noun used, in at least one context (e.g. in the plural),  2.  And there is a fixed number of these morphemes (i.e. a fixed number of genders, as opposed to them being classifiers, totalling up to 30).     Examples    **Kambaata (kamb1316; Treis 2008:256) Coded 1:**    Adjectives (the targets of agreement) agree in case and gender with their head nouns (the controllers of agreement).   ```  Qeráa’rr-ut    maránch-at  ées     sagáb-unta                  ass-itée’u.  long-F.NOM     walk-F.NOM  1SG.ACC become:thirsty-1SG.PURP.DS  do-3F.PVE  The long walk made me thirsty    Qah-ú       shonkoor-á       udul-éen        wor-éenno.  small-M.ACC sugar:cane-M.ACC pound-3HON.PCO  put:into-3HON.IPV  A little bit of sugar cane is pounded and added [to the brew].   ```  **Wadjiginy (wadj1254; Ford 1990:89) Coded 0:**     Only a few adjectives are marked for gender. This system may have been borrowed in or was the start of a system which is not productive.  ```  canakku   kaɲi-mi     ɲaraca  good.sgf  2sgSNF-sit  daughter  Are you OK, daughter?  ```  **Hozo (hozo1236; Kassa 2014:19, 22) Coded ?:**    Boundness status of the gender marker is unclear. "The adjective shows also the gender by the pronouns ʔa ʻheʼ or  ʔe ʻshe'.  ```  ʔa  kʼəndib hummi   he  short   thief  The short thief.    ʔe kʼəndib hummi   she short  thief  The short female thief.  ```     Further reading  [Corbett, Greville G. 1991. Gender. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/gender/gender-agreement/EBC59E9D9A6CC84101758D4C3AEF6738)    [Greville G. Corbett. 2013. Number of Genders.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](http://wals.info/chapter/30)     Related Features  [GB171: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB171)    [GB172: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB172)    [GB198: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB198)

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Demonstratives can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.
wiki_summary: Demonstratives can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used when at least some demonstratives are used that varies according to the noun used,  2.  And there is a fixed number of these morphemes (i.e. a fixed number of genders, as opposed to them being classifiers.     Examples  **Gubeeher (gube1234; Cobbinah 2013:209-210) Coded 1:**  ```  u-na’-t-am          bamba            ba-duhun  2-give-VEN-1SGOBJ   CL.ba.DEM.PROX   AGR.ba-hot  ‘Give me that hot (CL.ba) one [=ba-rux ‘water’]’  ```  **Jamsay Dogon (jams1239; Heath 2008:161-162), coded 1:**    "There are different forms for human and non-human "this/that"."     Further reading  [Corbett, Greville G. 1991. Gender. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/gender/gender-agreement/EBC59E9D9A6CC84101758D4C3AEF6738)    [Greville G. Corbett. 2013. Number of Genders.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](http://wals.info/chapter/30)     Related Features  [GB170: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB170)    [GB172: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB172)    [GB198: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB198)

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Articles can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.
wiki_summary: Articles can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used when at least some articles are used that varies according to the noun used,  2.  And there is a fixed number of these morphemes (i.e. a fixed number of genders, as opposed to them being classifiers.     Examples    **Movima (movi1243; Haude 2006:139) Coded 1:**    Table 11: The Article    |              | presential    |     absential |  “past”      |  |-------------| ------------- | ------------- | -------------|  |  masc.sg    | us            |     kus       |  us, (usos)  |  |  fem.sg     | i’nes         | kinos         | isnos        |  |  ntr.sg     | as            | kos           | os           |  |  plural     | is            | kis           | is, (isos)   |    ```  ji:yi    kus      tami:ba  cry.MD   ART.m.a  baby  ‘The baby cried'.  ```      **Apurinã (apur1254; Facundes 2000:355), coded 0:**    Coded 0 because it lacks articles, but "Note that demonstratives can be used to express definiteness, demonstratives agree in gender with the head noun".    **Udihe (udih1248; Girfanova 2002:8), coded 0:**     "Not mentioned, inferred 0 because no gender."       Further reading  [Corbett, Greville G. 1991. Gender. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/gender/gender-agreement/EBC59E9D9A6CC84101758D4C3AEF6738)    [Greville G. Corbett. 2013. Number of Genders.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](http://wals.info/chapter/30)     Related Features  [GB170: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB170)    [GB171: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB171)    [GB198: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB198)

Feature: Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Clarifying comments: Does animacy of an argument (S or A or P) determines the form or presence of the indexing on the verb. This system of marking has to be unrelated or not reducible to the gender/noun class system as revealed by agreement in the noun phrase.
wiki_summary: Does animacy of an argument (S or A or P) determines the form or presence of the indexing on the verb. This system of marking has to be unrelated or not reducible to the gender/noun class system as revealed by agreement in the noun phrase.     Procedure  1. Check the section on verbal morphology to identify whether the language has any indexing at all. Code 0 if it has not.  2. If there is indexing, consider which categories are indexed on the verb. Code 0 if only person and/or number and/or clusivity are indexed and the marking is consistent for both animate and inanimate referents.  3. If there is indexing of the animacy feature or animacy conditions the use of allomorphs (including zero marking) for number or person marking, this is potentially a 1. Consider the agreement feature within an NP and the respective gender/classes. Code 1 if the sets of referents identified on the basis of verbal indexing is not identical to the sets of referents identified on the basis of agreement with an NP.   4. Code 0 if the same gender/noun class as the ones identified on the basis of agreement within an NP are found in the indexing system.     Examples  **Anamuxra** (anam1248/imi; Ingram 2001: 196, 307)     In Anamuxra animacy matters for indexing on the verbs both for subjects (S/A) and objects (P) arguments. Each of these two cases alone would suffice for "1".     "In transitive clauses, only animate P objects are indexed on the verb, while inanimate P objects are not." (Ingram 2001: 307)    ```  a. [u-mka=x]           aku-i   n-simu-pa-n     IA-CLnhan=ACC.SG    FD-OBL  3sgO-spear-FP-1sgS     'I speared one (pig) over there.' (Ingram 2001: 217)    b.  mugux-a-ka      uns-pa  p-xada-pa-ri      house-ND-CLres  fire-CLres  get-EXH-FP-3sgS      'The fire got the whole house.'  ```    Animacy also matter for how subjects are indexed, this alone would also be sufficient for "1".    "Bound pronominal suffixes are used to indicate number in case of animate subjects; for inanimate subjects the third person singular is used regardless of number." (Ingram 2001: 196)    Though animacy also determines the type of possessive construction used, this is not revealed by agreement in the noun phrase and thus does not qualify as gender/noun class visible in the NP domain.     Further reading  No suggestions.     Related Features  Features on indexing in general:    [GB089	Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB089)    [GB090	Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB090)    [GB091	Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB091)    [GB092	Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB092)    [GB093	Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB093)    [GB094	Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB094)

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: The property word can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. Attributive nominal modifier is roughly equal to the old term adjective.
wiki_summary: The property word can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. "Attributive nominal modifier" is roughly equal to the old term "adjective".     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used when at least some adnominal property words are used that varies according to the number of the noun used.     Examples    **Yeri [yapu1240; Wilson 2017:129-132] Coded 1:**    ```  neigal   sɨpekɨ-i  yot-u-i       ∅-o           tapo.  cuscus  little-pl  dem-mdist-pl  3pl-stay.r    tree.hole  ‘Those small cuscuses live in the hole of the tree.’   ```  **Barambu (bara1361), coded 0 but should be 1:**    Plural prefix is occasionally attached to adjectives, or plurality is often shown through reduplication.     ```  (ä)-      gú̹ɽú̹-gu̹ɽu̹             a-ŋguà  (plural)- short (REDUP)        (plural)- tree  Short trees  ```    **Kenga (keng1240; Vandame 1968:18-21), coded 1:**    "The plural clitic can attach to the end of the noun phrase, so also to the adjective."       Further reading  [Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)      Related Features  [GB185: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB185)  [GB186: Can an article agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB186)

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: Demonstratives can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. NB: This concerns cases where there is a head NP different from the demonstrative. Disregard whenever the demonstrative can function as the head noun in the NP, e.g., if demonstratives function as pronouns.
wiki_summary: Demonstratives can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. NB: This concerns cases where there is a head NP different from the demonstrative. Disregard whenever the demonstrative can function as the head noun in the NP, e.g., if demonstratives function as pronouns.     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used with demonstratives that varies according to the number of the noun used,   2.  And this is when the demonstratives are used with a noun rather than as pronouns.  2.  Check that this is different from an enclitic which is marking number.     Examples    **Dupaningan [dupa1235; Robinson 2011:93-95] Coded 1:**      | | Proximal (close) |  Medial (middle) | Distal (far) |   | -------- |-------------| -------------| -------------- |  |Specific | =aye ‘this’ | =aya ‘that’ | =ayo ‘that there’|  |Singular demonstrative (nominal)|ide ‘this (thing)’ | iday ‘that (thing)’ | idu ‘that (thing) over there’|   |Plural demonstrative (nominal)| daginde ‘these (things)’| daginday ‘those (things)’| daginto ‘those (things) over there’|  |Oblique (locative)| ihe ‘here’| ihay ‘there’| ihu ‘over there’|     ```  daginde        i   ˈanak     a    mappya  PROX.PL.DEM   DEF  children  LK    good  ‘These are the good children.’  ```    **Kaki Ae [kaki1249; Clifton 1995:46,55,80] Coded 0:**    Deduced from the following examples.     ```  ë'a  Uriri aru-'u  vori-vori  ü'üka  that Uriri man-PL  big-PL     two  'those two Uriri leaders'     Aro    o'ekema,     aro ë'a  aevere luema     leve,         aro     o'ekema   2s-ERG make-2sS-LOC 2s-ERG   that   word-POSS in-LOC stand-? 2s-ERG make-2sS-LOC   o'ekema      haekekae,          lofohae        siahuhae.  make-2sS-LOC strengthen-3sS-IMP strong-3sS-IMP power-3sS-IMP  'You stand in those words to make us strong, with strength and power.'     ```     Further reading  [Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)      Related Features  [GB185: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB185)  [GB186: Can an article agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB186)

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: Articles can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number.
wiki_summary: Articles can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number.      Procedure  1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme that is used when at least some articles are used that varies according to the number of the noun used.     Examples  **Movima (movi1243; Haude 2006:139) Coded 1:**    Movima shows singular and plural agreement.     **Table 11: The Article**    |              | presential    |     absential |  “past”      |  |-------------| ------------- | ------------- | -------------|  |  masc.sg    | us            |     kus       |  us, (usos)  |  |  fem.sg     | i’nes         | kinos         | isnos        |  |  ntr.sg     | as            | kos           | os           |  |  plural     | is            | kis           | is, (isos)   |    ```  jiram-poj-kay   is      ney   monloto  pretty-CAU-INV  ART.pl  here  earring  ‘I liked those earrings.'  ```   Further reading  [Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)      Related Features  [GB184: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB184)  [GB185: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB185)

Feature: Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying comments: This needs to be a productive pattern. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.
wiki_summary: This needs to be a productive pattern. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.      Procedure    1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme which is phonologically bound to nouns which denotes smaller size, this includes reduplication and stem changes such as tonal change.  2.  If it is not a marker that behaves like other noun class markers.     Examples    **Nend [nend1239; Harris 1990:135) Coded 1:**    |Noun | Reduplicated Noun |  |---------|-----------------|  |iliv -  bow |iliv iliv  - toy bow |  |olam - house |olam olam  - shelter/blind|  |alaz - flying fox |alaz alaz -  small bat|    **Ainu (ainu1240), Coded 1:**    '-po' diminutive attaches to words referring to small or trifling things, may also add a nuance of affection or familiarity.  ```  cep-po  fish-small   ‘small fish’  ```    **Awa-Cuaiquer (awac1239; Curnow 1997:89) Coded 0:**     'Diminutive meaning is expressed through lexical means (word for 'child')'       Further reading  [Nieuwenhuis, P. (1985). Diminutives.](https://www.era.lib.ed.ac.uk/bitstream/handle/1842/6728/370224.pdf?sequence=1)     Related Features  [GB188 Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB188)

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying comments: This needs to be a productive pattern. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.
wiki_summary: This needs to be a productive pattern. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.     Procedure    1.  Code 1 if there is a morpheme which is phonologically bound to nouns which denotes larger size,  2.  If it is not a marker that behaves like other noun class markers.     Examples  **Hixkaryana (hixk1239; Derbyshire 1979:83-4) Coded 1:**    Phonologically bound particle 'ymo'   ```  toto-ymo  person- AUG  The big man  ```    **Tehuelche (tehu1242; Fernández Garay 2004:9-29) coded 0:**     'Augmentative marking not observed, neither in grammatical sections, nor sample texts.'       Further reading  [Shepardson, K.N., 1982. An integrated analysis of Swahili augmentative-diminutives. Studies in African linguistics, 13(1), p.1.](https://journals.linguisticsociety.org/elanguage/sal/article/download/1111/1111-2256-1-PB.pdf)     Related Features  [GB187: Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB187)

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the phonological properties of the noun are one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their phonological properties for this feature to be coded 1. That is, some phonological property of a noun must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Examples of phonological properties that may play a role in gender/class assignment include tone or initial consonants. Note that noun class/gender morphology may create phonological similarities across members of a certain noun class or gender; however, this is not sufficient for a 1 coding for this feature. Phonological properties must contribute to the categorization of nouns to classes/genders, rather than simply result from associated morphology.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the phonological properties of the noun are one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their phonological properties for this feature to be coded 1. That is, some phonological property of a noun must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Examples of phonological properties that may play a role in gender/class assignment include tone or initial consonants. Note that noun class/gender morphology may create phonological similarities across members of a certain noun class or gender; however, this is not sufficient for a 1 coding for this feature. Phonological properties must contribute to the categorization of nouns to classes/genders, rather than simply result from associated morphology.     Procedure  1. If there is a noun class/gender system such that there are markers which attach to targets of agreement (e.g. adjectives), which vary according to the noun’s lexically assigned category ...  2. And if there seems to be a correlation between use of a particular gender marker and certain phonological properties of the noun, then code 1.  3. Code 0 if there is no class/gender system or the assignment of nouns to classes/genders does not pattern according to the phonological properties of the noun.     Examples  **Kilen** (Glottolog: kile1243)    There are two classes of nouns in Kilen: one for /n/-final stems and one for vowel-final stems. Allomorphy of nominal suffixes is determined by these two categories, which correspond to the final sound of the stem (Zhang 2013: 77).    | Case | V-final | n-final |  | --- | --- | --- |  | --- | *warehouse* xas&808;i | *garden* jafux&601;n |  | NOM | xas&808;i-&216; | jafux&601;n-&216; |  | ACC | xas&808;i-w&601; | jafux&601;n-m&601; |  | GEN | xas&808;i-ji | jafux&601;n-i |  | DAT | xas&808;i-d&601; | jafux&601;n-du |  | LOC | xas&808;i-l&601; | jafux&601;n-dul&601; |  | PROL | xas&808;i-li | jafux&601;n-duli |    Table 5.1 Case Suffixes (Zhang 2013: 80)    Kilen is coded as 1.    **North Levantine Arabic** (ISO 639-3: apc, Glottolog: nort3139)    For nouns that are neither names nor human designations, gender cannot be inferred from meaning but usually from form: singular nouns ending in -e/-a/-?/-t are feminine (Cowell 1964: 209). This language is coded 1.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB051: Sex and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB052: Shape and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB053: Animacy and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB054: Plant status and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB321: Large, unpredictable gender/noun class](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB321)

Feature: What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Clarifying comments: Adnominal proper word is roughly equal to the old term adjective, we want to include elements that mark adjectival function but that might not be described as adjectives, see feature 69. The question concerns the pragmatically neutral order(s).
wiki_summary: "Adnominal proper word" is roughly equal to the old term "adjective", we want to include elements that mark "adjectival" function but that might not be described as "adjectives", see feature 69. The question concerns the pragmatically neutral order(s).       Procedure    1.  Code 1 if most adnominal property words are placed before nouns.  2.  Code 2 if most adnominal property words are placed after nouns.	  3.  Code 3 if adjectives can be placed before or after nouns, either because both orders are possible or because some adjectives precede and some adjectives follow.  4.  Code 0 if property words cannot be used attributively.  5.  Do not code 0 if property words are a sub-class of verbs: code 1, 2 or 3.     Examples    **Amma (amap1240; Årsjö 1999:94) Coded 3:**  ```  sopo nu siyoli   tall house big  'a big and tall house'  ```    **Maco (maco1239; Rosés Labrada 2015:283) Coded 2:**    When adjectives are used attributively they usually follow the underived noun     ```  wiɾi ɨwaɾi-ˀbo       dew-aˀbo     hũn-an-õ-∅  dog  tail-CL:OBLONG  be_white-CL  have-DUR-CL:MASC-3.COP  ‘the dog has a white tail’   (lit. a tail that is white=a tail a white one)  ```  **Ghadames (ghad1239; Kossmann 2013:129) Coded 0:**    Attribution of adjectival concepts is basically achieved by means of relative clauses with stative verbs in the participial form.    ```  tawz̆aett=e   măttít-ăt   girl ANP     small:P-PTC:F:S  ‘this small girl (lit. this girl that was small)’   ```     Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Order of Adjective and Noun.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/87)     Related Features  [GB024: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB024)    [GB025: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB025)    [GB065: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB065)    [GB203: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB203)

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for second person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of second person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for second person singular, but not second person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular second person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.
wiki_summary: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for second person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of second person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for second person singular, but not second person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular second person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.     Procedure  1. If the language has second person independent pronouns that take a different form depending on whether the referent is male or female, code 1.  2. If the language has second person independent pronouns that do not contrast in gender, or that contrast according to some element of the gender system other than male/female sex, code 0.     Examples  **Standard Arabic** (ISO 639-3: arb, Glottolog: stan1318)    Arabic independent pronouns include masculine and feminine forms for the second person singular and plural.    *Second Person Independent Personal Pronouns*    | Gender | Singular | Dual | Plural |  | ---- | ---- | ---- | ---- |  | Masculine | 'anta |  | 'antum |  | Feminine | 'anti |  | 'antunna |  | Non-specific |  | 'antumaa |  |    (Ryding 2005: 298)    Although there is only one second person dual independent personal pronoun which can be interpreted as either male or female, the presence of a male/female distinction in the singular and plural forms is sufficient to trigger a 1 for this feature for Standard Arabic.     Further reading  Siewierska, Anna. 2005. Gender distinctions in independent personal pronouns. In Haspelmath, Martin, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil, and Bernard Comrie (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures, 182–185. Oxford: Oxford University Press.     Related Features  * [GB197: Male/female distinction in first person pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB197)  * [GB051: Sex as a factor in noun class/gender systems](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for first person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of first person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for first person singular, but not first person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular first person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.
wiki_summary: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for first person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of first person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for first person singular, but not first person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular first person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.     Procedure  1. If the language has first person independent pronouns that take a different form depending on whether the referent is male or female, code 1.  2. If the language has first person independent pronouns that do not contrast in gender, or that contrast according to some element of the gender system other than male/female sex, code 0.     Examples  **Thai** (ISO 639-3: tha, Glottolog: thai1261)    Thai has a complex set of independent personal pronouns. Among their basic pronouns are first person forms that vary by masculine/feminine gender.    *First Person Singular Pronouns*    | Gender | Form |  | --- | --- |  | Male | ph&466;m |  | Female (informal) | ch&225;n |  | Female (formal) | dich&225;n |    (Smyth 2002: 39)    The contrast between these independent first person pronouns is sufficient to trigger a 1 for this feature in Thai.        Further reading  Siewierska, Anna. 2005. Gender distinctions in independent personal pronouns. In Haspelmath, Martin, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil, and Bernard Comrie (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures, 182–185. Oxford: Oxford University Press.     Related Features  * [GB196: Male/female distinction in second person pronouns](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB196)  * [GB051: Sex as a factor in noun class/gender systems](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)

Feature: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: This applies to cardinal numbers primarily. A system of numeral classifiers (GB057) cannot be coded as a system of agreement in gender/noun class.
wiki_summary: This applies to cardinal numbers primarily. A system of numeral classifiers (GB057) cannot be coded as a system of agreement in gender/noun class.     Procedure  1.  Code 1 if morphemes can be used with (but not necessarily phonologically bound to, and not necessarily obligatorily) at least some cardinal numbers that vary according to the noun used,  2.  And these morphemes are a closed class of under about 30, to distinguish these from classifiers which are a more open class.     Examples  **Abkhaz (abkh1244; Chirikba 2003:34-35; Hewitt 2010:33-35) Coded 1:**     The cardinals take class agreement markers. ‘One’ has suppletive forms for humans and non-humans. For non-human nouns, cardinal numerals take the suffix -ba/pa. Human nouns they take the suffix -j°ə(-k'). Ordinal and other numerals take no agreement    **Cicipu (cici1237; McGill 2009:285-286) Coded 1:**  ```  kà-bárá      [ká-mpà]  [kà-yápù]  NC1-old_man  AG1-this   AG1-two  These two old men  ```  **Aja (Sudan) (ajas1235; Santandrea 1976:73-75) Coded 0:**    There is no grammatical gender system. Different words are used to distinguish male from female persons; to indicate whether an animal is male or female, a word for 'male' or 'female' is added to the noun.    **Yuki (yuki1243; Balodis 2011:176-179) Coded ?**    Adnominals seem to be able to take patient-argument marking; this occurs only when the noun is animate. The data is too scant to tell which is a consequence of the other.     Further reading  [Corbett, Greville G. 1991. Gender. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/gender/gender-agreement/EBC59E9D9A6CC84101758D4C3AEF6738)    [Greville G. Corbett. 2013. Number of Genders.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](http://wals.info/chapter/30)     Related Features  [GB170: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB170)    [GB171: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB171)    [GB172: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB172)

Feature: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Clarifying comments:
This feature is concerned with the ordering of a universal quantifier used adnominally and the noun. We are specifically focused on the relative position of the collective universal quantifier ('all'); in languages that do not have a distinction between collective and distributive universal quantifiers ('all' vs. 'every'), a quantifier that could be translated as 'all' and has a primarily plural use will be a sufficient target for this feature.

There are four possible codes for this feature, reflecting the fact that the collective universal quantifier might occur strictly before or strictly after the noun, may be allowed in both of these relative positions, or may not be present in a language. A 0 code is also applicable when the language does not allow a basic construction with an adnominal collective universal quantifier and a noun (e.g. if only a floating construction is used).

Orders that result from constructions like quantifier float (e.g. English The children have all come) should be disregarded for the purposes of coding this feature.
wiki_summary: This feature is concerned with the ordering of a universal quantifier used adnominally and the noun. We are specifically focused on the relative position of the collective universal quantifier ('all'); in languages that do not have a distinction between collective and distributive universal quantifiers ('all' vs. 'every'), a quantifier that could be translated as 'all' and has a primarily plural use will be a sufficient target for this feature.    There are four possible codes for this feature, reflecting the fact that the collective universal quantifier might occur strictly before or strictly after the noun, may be allowed in both of these relative positions, or may not be present in a language. A 0 code is also applicable when the language does not allow a basic construction with an adnominal collective universal quantifier and a noun (e.g. if only a floating construction is used).    Orders that result from constructions like quantifier float (e.g. English "The children have all come") should be disregarded for the purposes of coding this feature.     Procedure		  1. If there is a collective universal quantifier, or general universal quantifier that can be translated as 'all', and that quantifier occurs only before the noun (UQ-N), code 1.  2. If there is a collective universal quantifier, or general universal quantifier that can be translated as 'all', and that quantifier occurs only after the noun (N-UQ), code 2.  3. If the collective universal quantifier or equivalent can occur either before or after the noun (UQ-N *or* N-UQ), code 3.  4. If there is no collective universal quantifier or other universal quantifier that can be translated as 'all' and be used in an adnominal construction, code 0.  5. If there is no mention of universal quantifiers at all, code (?).     Examples  Examples are not yet available but will be inserted shortly.       Further reading  Bach, E. E. Jelinek, A. Kratzer, and B.H. Partee, eds. 1995. *Quantification in Natural Languages*. Studies in Linguistics and Philosophy 54. Dorcrecht: Springer Science+Business Media.     Related Features  GB204: Collective and distributive universal quantifiers

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies languages that use different forms or syntax for collective universal quantification versus distributive universal quantification. This contrasts with languages that use both the same form *and* the same syntactic position for these two types of quantification.
wiki_summary: This feature identifies languages that use different forms or syntax for collective universal quantification versus distributive universal quantification. This contrasts with languages that use both the same form *and* the same syntactic position for these two types of quantification.     Procedure  1. If the language uses different forms for collective universal quantification ('all') and distributive universal quantification ('every'), code 1.  2. If the language uses a single form for both collective and distributive universal quantifiers (i.e. one form means *both* 'all' and 'every'), but they differ in terms of word order/syntactic position when expressing these different meanings, code 1.  3. If the language uses a single form in the same syntactic position to express both collective and distributive universal quantification, code 0.  4. 5. If there is no mention of universal quantifiers at all, code (?).     Examples  Examples are not yet available but will be added shortly.     Further reading  Bach, E. E. Jelinek, A. Kratzer, and B.H. Partee, eds. 1995. *Quantification in Natural Languages*. Studies in Linguistics and Philosophy 54. Dorcrecht: Springer Science+Business Media.     Related Features  GB203: Order of Universal Quantifier and Noun

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. For this feature, we are looking for a verb that expresses predicative possession where the possessor is the subject, the possessum the object and the verb is finite and clearly transitive. The finite element in itself need not be clearly distinct from an existential or locational predicator, the main difference is the argument structure. Transitivity is a language-specific category that needs to be investigated separately to learn whether or not the construction is transitive. In case of languages where transitivity is hard to define it might be beneficial to compare to verbs of hold and grasp. It is very likely that habeo-verb constructions arise from possessive constructions where the possessor is expressed as a topic (see feature 255).

This is known as have-possessive in the work of Stassen.
wiki_summary:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. For this feature, we are looking for a verb that expresses predicative possession where the possessor is the subject, the possessum the object and the verb is finite and clearly transitive. The finite element in itself need not be clearly distinct from an existential or locational predicator, the main difference is the argument structure. Transitivity is a language-specific category that needs to be investigated separately to learn whether or not the construction is transitive. In case of languages where transitivity is hard to define it might be beneficial to compare to verbs of "hold" and "grasp". It is very likely that habeo-verb constructions arise from possessive constructions where the possessor is expressed as a topic (see feature 255). This is known as "have-possessive" in the work of Stassen. Procedure 1. Find section on predicative possession 2. If no such section exists, search for words like "own", "possess" and "have", and see what you find in the descriptive text and in annotated examples 3. If there is no information on how predicative possession is expressed in the language, code as "?". 4. If it is clear that there is a finite transitive verb where the subject is the possessor and the direct object the possessed, code as "1". 5. If there are multiple constructions besides this one, code "1" and go on to the other questions on predicative possession and evaluate if these other constructions fit any of those. Examples **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254) Swedish is a germanic language and predicate possession is expressed with a habeo-verb construction that is cognate with the one in English. Swedish is coded as a (1) for this feature. 
    1)    Andrea    har   en  bil          Andrea have.PRS ART.INDEF car          ‘Andrea has a car’
Further reading * Stassen, Leon. 2001. Predicative Possession. In Martin Haspelmath, Wulf Oesterreicher and Raible, Wolfgang (eds.), 954-960. Berlin and New York: Mouton de Gruyter. * Stassen, Leon. 2013. Predicative Possession. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/117) * Stassen, Leon. 2000. AND-Languages and WITH-Languages. Linguistic Typology 4. 1-54. Related Features * [GB250 Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB250) * [GB252 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB252) * [GB253 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB253) * [GB254 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB254) * [GB256 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB256)

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature is concerned with construction where the possessum is the subject of an existential/locative predicate and the possessor is in an oblique form marked by an element meaning at/in/on (i.e. a car is on me) or there is a locative marker on the verb. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for location, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.

This is known as locational possessive in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, locative
wiki_summary:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature is concerned with construction where the possessum is the subject of an existential/locative predicate and the possessor is in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "at/in/on" (i.e. "a car is on me") or there is a locative marker on the verb. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for location, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant. This is known as "locational possessive" in the work of Stassen. Procedure 1. Find section on predicative possession 2. If no such section exists, search for words like "own", "possess" and "have", and see what you find in the descriptive text and in annotated examples 3. If there is no information on how predicative possession is expressed in the language, code as "?". 4. If it is clear that there is a finite verb where the subject is the possessum and the possessor is coded like a location, code as "1". 5. If there are multiple constructions besides this one, code "1" and go on to the other questions on predicative possession and evaluate if these other constructions fit any of those. Examples **Ket** (ISO 639-3: ket, Glottocode: kett1243) Ket is a language with an extensive case system. The adessive case is used for both location and to mark the possessor in a predicative possessive construction, and the possessive verb is intransitive. Below is an example from Nefedov (2015:169). Ket is coded as 1 for feature GB252. 
    1)   ɔ́ bdaŋt bɔ́ gdɔm úsʲaŋ         ob-da-ŋt bokdom usaŋ         father-M-ADESS rifle be.present          ‘The father has a rifle’
Further reading * Nefedov, Andrey. 2015. Clause linkage in Ket. (Doctoral dissertation, Rijksuniversiteit te Leiden; xviii+287pp.) * Stassen, Leon. 2001. Predicative Possession. In Martin Haspelmath, Wulf Oesterreicher and Raible, Wolfgang (eds.), 954-960. Berlin and New York: Mouton de Gruyter. * Stassen, Leon. 2013. Predicative Possession. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/117) * Stassen, Leon. 2000. AND-Languages and WITH-Languages. Linguistic Typology 4. 1-54. Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject of an existential predicative and the possessor in an oblique form marked by an element meaning to/for (i.e. a car is to me) or dative case. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for dative case, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.

This is known as dative possessive, a subcategory of locational possessive, in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, dative
wiki_summary:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject of an existential predicative and the possessor in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "to/for" (i.e. "a car is to me") or dative case. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for dative case, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant. This is known as "dative possessive", a subcategory of "locational possessive", in the work of Stassen. Procedure 1. Find section on predicative possession 2. If no such section exists, search for words like "own", "possess" and "have", and see what you find in the descriptive text and in annotated examples 3. If there is no information on how predicative possession is expressed in the language, code as "?". 4. If it is clear that there is a finite transitive verb where the subject is the possessum and the possessor is coded like a recipient/dative object/with elements meaning "to/for" , code as "1". 5. If there are multiple constructions besides this one, code "1" and go on to the other questions on predicative possession and evaluate if these other constructions fit any of those. Examples **Russian** (ISO 639-3: rus, Glottocode: russ1263) In Russian, there are possessive constructions where the possessor is in the dative case. Russian is coded as a 1 for this feature. Andrews (2004:38) gives the following example illustrating this construction (glossing by Russian native speaker colleague Anna Alexandrova, not Andrews): 
    1)   Она наступила мне на ногу         Ona nastupi-l-a mne na nog-u         3sg.f.nom step.pfv-pst.f.sg 1sg.dat on foot.f-acc.sg         'She stepped on my foot.'
Further reading * Andrews, Edna. 2004. Russian. SEELRC. 200pp. * Stassen, Leon. 2001. Predicative Possession. In Martin Haspelmath, Wulf Oesterreicher and Raible, Wolfgang (eds.), 954-960. Berlin and New York: Mouton de Gruyter. * Stassen, Leon. 2013. Predicative Possession. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/117) * Stassen, Leon. 2000. AND-Languages and WITH-Languages. Linguistic Typology 4. 1-54. Related Features * [GB250 Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB250) * [GB252 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB252) * [GB253 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB253) * [GB254 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB254) * [GB256 Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB256)

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject and the possessor is not in a separate noun phrase but instead a modifier to the possessum. The possessor is construed as a modifier of the possessum (i.e. my car exists).

This is known as genitive possessive in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, genitive
wiki_summary:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject and the possessor is not in a separate noun phrase but instead a modifier to the possessum. The possessor is construed as a modifier of the possessum (i.e. "my car exists"). This is known as "genitive possessive" in the work of Stassen. Procedure 1. Find section on predicative possession 2. If no such section exists, search for words like "own", "possess" and "have", and see what you find in the descriptive text and in annotated examples 3. If there is no information on how predicative possession is expressed in the language, code as "?". 4. If it is clear that there is a finite transitive verb where the subject is the possessum and the possessor is coded like a adnominal possessor , code as "1". 5. If the possessum is subject, but the possessor is not adnominal modifier, bring it up with the patron and group. 6. If there are multiple constructions besides this one, code "1" and go on to the other questions on predicative possession and evaluate if these other constructions fit any of those. Examples **Rapa Nui** (ISO 639-3: rap, Glottocode: rapa1244) In Rapanui, predicative possession is expressed by the existence of the possessed noun with the possessor as a modifier. Rapanui is coded as 1 for this feature. Here is an example from Kieviet (2017:467), where 'a (glossed as of.A in Kievet 2017) is the inalienable possessive marker that is also found in attributive possession. 
    1)   E ai rō ꞌā te kona ꞌoka mahute ꞌa Kekepuē ko tetu          IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART place plant mulberry of.A Kekepue prom huge         ‘Kekepue had a huge plantation of mulberries.’
Further reading * Kieviet, Paulus. 2017. A grammar of Rapa Nui. Berlin: Language Science Press. xx+643pp. * Stassen, Leon. 2001. Predicative Possession. In Martin Haspelmath, Wulf Oesterreicher and Raible, Wolfgang (eds.), 954-960. Berlin and New York: Mouton de Gruyter. * Stassen, Leon. 2013. Predicative Possession. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/117) * Stassen, Leon. 2000. AND-Languages and WITH-Languages. Linguistic Typology 4. 1-54. Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. This feature concerns a construction where the possessum is coded lika a comitative argument. This kind of construction is also known as conjunctional possessive. The possessor is the subject, the predicate is an existential/locational/copula verb and the possessum is marked by an element marking simultaneity between clauses, or also/too, or subordinating conjunction (when/while), or coordinating particle (and), or a comitative marker {with). The conjugational/comitative/coordination/topical/simultaneity marking need not be phonologically bound to the possessum-NP, but it needs to mark the possessum-NP.

This is known as conjunctional possessive in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, comitative
wiki_summary:
This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. This feature concerns a construction where the possessum is coded lika a comitative argument. This kind of construction is also known as "conjunctional possessive". The possessor is the subject, the predicate is an existential/locational/copula verb and the possessum is marked by an element marking simultaneity between clauses, or "also/too", or subordinating conjunction ("when/while"), or coordinating particle ("and"), or a comitative marker {"with"). The conjugational/comitative/coordination/topical/simultaneity marking need not be phonologically bound to the possessum-NP, but it needs to mark the possessum-NP. This is known as "conjunctional possessive" in the work of Stassen. Procedure 1. Find section on predicative possession 2. If no such section exists, search for words like "own", "possess" and "have", and see what you find in the descriptive text and in annotated examples 3. If there is no information on how predicative possession is expressed in the language, code as "?". 4. If it is clear that there is a finite transitive verb where the subject is the possessor and the possessum is coded as a conjunctional argument (see above for full list of definition) 5. If there are multiple constructions besides this one, code "1" and go on to the other questions on predicative possession and evaluate if these other constructions fit any of those. Examples **Marshallese** (ISO 639-3: mah, Glottocode: mars1254) Marshallese has a marker for commutative, "ippā-", that can be used possessive constructions. This isn't well described in grammars of the language, but language specialist Jonathan Schlossberg was able to confirm to us over personal correspondence that this construction exists and provide the example below. Marshallese is coded as a 1 for this feature. 
    1)   e=pād ippā-m̧          3sg.S=be.located with-3sg.P          "You have it" (lit. "It is with you")
Further reading * Stassen, Leon. 2001. Predicative Possession. In Martin Haspelmath, Wulf Oesterreicher and Raible, Wolfgang (eds.), 954-960. Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Clarifying comments: We are looking for intonation only and no other markers in the clause which signals polar interrogation (such as a polar interrogative particle). Intonation is our focus, and not tone, because tone is a particle and bound to the constituent whereas intonation is not.
wiki_summary: We are looking for intonation only and no other markers in the clause which signals polar interrogation (such as a polar interrogative particle). Intonation is our focus, and not tone, because tone is a particle and bound to the constituent whereas intonation is not.      Procedure    1.  Code 1 if a sentence can become a question by changing the intonation, including pitch and length.  2.  Code 0 if a sentence can become a question by changing tone, and consider feature GB291.      Examples    **Dongxiang (dong1285; Field 1997: 359-360) coded 0:**    'Polar interrogative marked by sentence final negation'  ```  ta     gudz̹i-ʁaŋ  irə   nu ?  2PLNM  fast-INT   come  QM  Will you all come faster?  ```    **Santali (sant1410; Neukom 2001: 48), coded 1:**     "Yes/no - questions are marked by stress on the last syllable of the verb'  ```  am     uni       dal-e-á-m?26  you(s) that(AN) beat-3s0-IND-2sS  'Will you beat him?'  ```     Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Position of Polar Question Particles.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/92)    [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)     Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Clarifying comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative.  There is allowed to be a different intonation from declarative sentences.
wiki_summary: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative.  There is allowed to be a different intonation from declarative sentences.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if interrogative questions can be formed by changing the word order and nothing else (except for intonation).     Examples  **Parecís (pare1272; Brandão 2014:338), coded 1:**    'Generally, in polar questions, the focused questioned argument is fronted and the verb is clause-final'       Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Position of Polar Question Particles.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Feature: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying comments: Is there a particle that occurs at the beginning of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').
wiki_summary: Is there a particle that occurs at the beginning of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').     Procedure    1. Code 1 if polar questions can contain a particle that occurs at the beginning of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions, that is not bound to other words.     Examples  **Cavinena [cavi1250; Guillaume 2008: 105] Coded 1:**  ```  Are    =mi      bakwa=ra   a-wa=ama?  QUEST =2SG(-FM) viper=ERG  affect-PERF=NEG  ‘Isn’t that a viper that bit you?’   ```     Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Position of Polar Question Particles.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/92)    [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)
