Feature: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying comments: Is there a particle that occurs at the end of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').
wiki_summary: Is there a particle that occurs at the end of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').     Procedure    1. Code 1 if polar questions can contain a particle that occurs at the end of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions, that is not bound to other words.  			     Examples  **Awa Pit [awac1239; Curnow 1997: 323] Coded 1:**    "There are two constructions which are used to form polar ( yes/no ) questions in Awa Pit, in different contexts. The simplest polar question form uses a verb suffix -ma, which indicates both the idea of a polar question and the idea of Past tense. The second type of polar question, the most frequent, involves the use of question markers ki or sa.    ```  tilawa    a-n      ki-s?  tomorrow come-INF  Q-LOCUT  'Are you coming tomorrow?  ```    **Bargam [barg1252; Hepner 2006: 119] Coded 0:**    The clause-final interrogative marker is a phonologically bound clitic.    ```  Ni  amun  wol-01-02-e?  you child hit-PA-N1S-INTER  ‘Did you hit the child?’     ```   Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Position of Polar Question Particles.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/92)    [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)       Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Clarifying comments: Is there a particle that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions) that most commonly occurs in the middle of the clause, neither initially nor finally?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').
wiki_summary: Is there a particle that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions) that most commonly occurs in the middle of the clause, neither initially nor finally?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').     Procedure    1. Code 1 if polar questions can contain a particle that occurs in the clause in a place that is neither at the beginning nor the end, that is dedicated to marking questions, and that is not bound to other words.     Examples    **Ainu (ainu1240; Tamura 2000: 140-141) coded 1:**    'The interrogative particle /he/ appears in a clause-medial (pre-verbal) position.’  ```  taanpe      he   ta  ne  a,    tanike    he  ta   ne  a?  this-thing QUES EMPH COP EMPH, this-one QUES EMPH COP EMPH  ‘Is it this one, or this one?’  ```    **Ineseno [ines1240; Applegate 1972: 298-299] coded ?:**    "Author is unsure whether interrogative verbal suffix is actually a particle. Cannot tell if it is phonologically free or not.” "The -ê marking yes-or-no questions may be an independent particle, since it is one of the very few affixes with a low vowel other than /a/ and it is the last element in the verb complex."    ```  /p-toxom-ê/   ‘are you cold?’    /sukʼiku ha-l-qotʼin, ʔneq-ê nakʼu ʔɨhɨy-ʔ / sukʼiku haqotʼin ʔeneqê nakʼu ʔɨhɨyʼ   ‘What was born, girl or boy?'  ```  **Tule-Kaweah [tule1245; Gamble 1978: 114,120] coded 0:**  "The polar interrogative particle is always in the intial position”  ```  hin  naʔ ne.či tuyo.na   QUES  ‘can I eat now?’   ```   Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Position of Polar Question Particles.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/92)    [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)   Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Clarifying comments:
This feature identifies languages that have a comparative construction that involves a form (usually a verb form) meaning 'surpass' or 'exceed'. Typically, the standard of comparison is the direct object, the thing which is being compared to that standard is the subject, and there are two predicates: one expressing 'surpass/exceed', and one carrying relevant lexical information about the property under comparison (e.g. Ronald exceed be-tall Julia).

Though this typical structure is quite common in languages that have a 'surpass/exceed' comparative construction, only the use of a 'surpass/exceed' form is required for this feature; it is not necessary for the standard to occur as a direct object or the thing being compared to serve as the subject in order to trigger a 1 value. The order of these predicates is not relevant for this feature, nor whether the property word is a verb or an adjective. The predicate expressing 'surpass/exceed' must also have functions besides comparison.
wiki_summary: This feature identifies languages that have a comparative construction that involves a form (usually a verb form) meaning 'surpass' or 'exceed'. Typically, the standard of comparison is the direct object, the thing which is being compared to that standard is the subject, and there are two predicates: one expressing 'surpass/exceed', and one carrying relevant lexical information about the property under comparison (e.g. "Ronald exceed be-tall Julia").     Though this typical structure is quite common in languages that have a 'surpass/exceed' comparative construction, only the use of a 'surpass/exceed' form is required for this feature; it is not necessary for the standard to occur as a direct object or the thing being compared to serve as the subject in order to trigger a 1 value. The order of these predicates is not relevant for this feature, nor whether the property word is a verb or an adjective. The predicate expressing 'surpass/exceed' must also have functions besides comparison.     Procedure  1. If the language has a comparative construction involving a form that is also used outside of comparative constructions and has a meaning of 'surpass/exceed', then code 1.  2. If the language does not use a 'surpass/exceed' form, code 0.  3. If the language uses a form that has a meaning of 'surpass' or 'exceed', but that form only occurs in comparative constructions (i.e. is never used without another predicate that contributed lexical information about a property under comparison), code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.    Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.    Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162.       Related Features  GB266: Locational Comparative    GB270: Conjoined Comparative    GB273: Comparative with Non-Locational, Non-Exceed Standard Marker    GB275: Bound Comparative Degree Marker    GB276: Non-Bound Comparative Degree Marker

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies comparative constructions that mark the standard of reference with an element that is otherwise locational or benefactive in meaning. In these constructions the standard NP is invariably constructed with a marker that also has a locational/adverbial function. Please note that benefactive markers are included here, following Stassen's category of locational comparatives. The marker of the property word is irrelevant for this feature (i.e. tall-er).
Function: comparison, predication, argument marking, oblique, locative
wiki_summary: This feature identifies comparative constructions that mark the standard of reference with an element that is otherwise locational or benefactive in meaning. In these constructions the standard NP is invariably constructed with a marker that also has a locational/adverbial function. Please note that benefactive markers are included here, following Stassen's category of locational comparatives. The marker of the property word is irrelevant for this feature (i.e. "tall-er").     Procedure  1. If there is a comparative construction in which the standard of comparison is marked with an element that has a locational meaning in non-comparative contexts, code 1.  2. If there is a comparative construction that uses a standard marker that otherwise has a benefactive meaning, code 1.  3. If there is no comparative construction that uses an element that elsewhere has a locational or benefactive meaning, code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.    Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.    Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162.       Related Features  GB265: 'Surpass/Exceed' Comparative    GB270: Conjoined Comparative    GB273: Comparative with Non-Locational, Non-Exceed Standard Marker    GB275: Bound Comparative Degree Marker    GB276: Non-Bound Comparative Degree Marker

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Clarifying comments: Is there a comparative construction comprised of two conjoined clauses? Specifically, this construction must involve two conjoined clauses, one with the standard-NP and one with the comparee-NP. These NPs have the same function in the clauses. Note that many if not most languages can juxtapose clauses in order to make comparisons (e.g. English She is nice and he is not nice). Here we are focused on languages that have a dedicated comparative construction with this structure.
wiki_summary: Is there a comparative construction comprised of two conjoined clauses? Specifically, this construction must involve two conjoined clauses, one with the standard-NP and one with the comparee-NP. These NPs have the same function in the clauses. Note that many if not most languages can juxtapose clauses in order to make comparisons (e.g. English "She is nice and he is not nice"). Here we are focused on languages that have a dedicated comparative construction with this structure.     Procedure  1. If the language has a dedicated comparative construction that involves two conjoined clauses, with the standard and comparee NPs functioning similarly in separate clauses, code 1.  2. If the language can conjoin clauses in which a comparee and the standard of comparison function in similar roles, but this is not a dedicated comparative construction, code 0.  3. If the language cannot express comparison through the use of two conjoined clauses as described above, code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.  Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.  Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162.     Related Features  GB265: 'Surpass/Exceed' Comparative    GB266: Locational Comparative  GB273: Comparative with Non-Locational, Non-Exceed Standard Marker  GB275: Bound Comparative Degree Marker  GB276: Non-Bound Comparative Degree Marker

Feature: Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Clarifying comments:
This question is focused on comparative constructions that have a dedicated marker for the standard of comparison that does not fall under the umbrella of the locational comparative (GB266) or surpass/exceed comparative (GB255). Note that a language may have multiple comparative constructions, including a non-locational, non-surpass/exceed comparative as well as constructions that are described by those features.

Crucially the dedicated marker in this construction must not elsewhere have a surpass/exceed meaning or a locational meaning. It may, however, have other functions (e.g. temporal adverb or conjunction, among other possibilities). It is irrelevant whether this marker is phonologically free or not or whether it triggers agreement in case, gender, etc.

Historically, comparative constructions with dedicated markers (sometimes called particle comparatives) grammaticalize from constructions of conjoined clauses. An example of a particle comparative would be the Germanic languages, such as English than. Note that the marking of the property word is not relevant here (i.e. tall-er).
Relevant unit(s): verb, auxiliary, particle, clause, adjective, adposition
wiki_summary: This question is focused on comparative constructions that have a dedicated marker for the standard of comparison that does not fall under the umbrella of the locational comparative (GB266) or surpass/exceed comparative (GB255). Note that a language may have multiple comparative constructions, including a non-locational, non-surpass/exceed comparative as well as constructions that are described by those features.    Crucially the dedicated marker in this construction must not elsewhere have a surpass/exceed meaning or a locational meaning. It may, however, have other functions (e.g. temporal adverb or conjunction, among other possibilities). It is irrelevant whether this marker is phonologically free or not or whether it triggers agreement in case, gender, etc.     Historically, comparative constructions with dedicated markers (sometimes called "particle comparatives") grammaticalize from constructions of conjoined clauses. An example of a particle comparative would be the Germanic languages, such as English "than". Note that the marking of the property word is not relevant here (i.e. "tall-er").     Procedure  1. If the language has a comparative construction with a dedicated marker of the standard of comparison that does not elsewhere have a surpass/exceed meaning or a locational meaning, code 1.  2. If the language has comparative constructions with dedicated markers, but only such constructions with markers that elsewhere have surpass/exceed or locational meanings, code 0.  3. If the language has no comparative constructions with dedicated markers to identify the standard of comparison, code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.  Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.  Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162.     Related Features  GB265: 'Surpass/Exceed' Comparative    GB266: Locational Comparative  GB270: Conjoined Comparative  GB275: Bound Comparative Degree Marker  GB276: Non-Bound Comparative Degree Marker

Feature: Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying comments: This feature focuses on the presence of a bound marker of comparative degree on the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. -er in English tall-er). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. Maria is taller than John) but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. Maria is taller). This feature requires the degree marker to be phonologically bound to the property word.
wiki_summary: This feature focuses on the presence of a bound marker of comparative degree on the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. -er in English "tall-er"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. "Maria is taller"). This feature requires the degree marker to be phonologically bound to the property word.     Procedure  1. If there is a degree marker that is bound to the property word in a comparative construction, code 1.  2. If there is a degree marker in comparative constructions, but it is not bound to the property word, code 0.  3. If there is no degree marker in comparative constructions, code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.    Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.    Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162.       Related Features  GB265: 'Surpass/Exceed' Comparative    GB266: Locational Comparative    GB270: Conjoined Comparative    GB273: Comparative with Non-Locational, Non-Exceed Standard Marker    GB276: Non-Bound Comparative Degree Marker

Feature: Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying comments:
This feature focuses on the presence of a phonologically non-bound marker of comparative degree that modifies the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. French plus grand). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. meanings like Maria is taller than John) but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. meanings like Maria is taller). The comparative constructions of interest express superiority (as in the French and English examples above), not inferiority (e.g. meanings like John is less athletic than Maria).

This feature requires that the degree marker modify the property word, but not be phonologically bound.
wiki_summary: This feature focuses on the presence of a phonologically non-bound marker of comparative degree that modifies the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. French "plus grand"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller"). The comparative constructions of interest express superiority (as in the French and English examples above), not inferiority (e.g. meanings like "John is less athletic than Maria").    This feature requires that the degree marker modify the property word, but not be phonologically bound.     Procedure  1. If there is a degree marker in a comparative construction that modifies the property word but is not phonologically bound, code 1.  2. If there is a degree marker in comparative constructions, but it is bound to the property word, code 0.  3. If there is no degree marker in comparative constructions, code 0.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Stassen, L. 1984. The Comparative Compared. *Journal of Semantics* 3: 143-182.    Stassen, L. 1985. *Comparison and Universal Grammar*. Oxford: Blackwell.    Ultan, R. 1972. Some Features of Basic Comparative Constructions. *Working Papers on Language Universals* 9: 117-162. Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Clarifying comments: Is there a polar interrogative construction in the language that consists of a combination of verbal morphology and a particle? This feature is concerned with constructions where these two elements are the only markers of polar interrogation, there should not be any other markers such as V-Not-V etc. Note that even a lack of finiteness can be considered as a marker of polar interrogation. Furthermore, tone (not intonation) is not included under 'particle' here. A special intonation is often present in polar interrogative clauses, if it occurs or doesn't occur in this construction has no effect on the coding.
wiki_summary: Is there a polar interrogative construction in the language that consists of a combination of verbal morphology and a particle? This feature is concerned with constructions where these two elements are the only markers of polar interrogation, there should not be any other markers such as V-Not-V etc. Note that even a lack of finiteness can be considered as a marker of polar interrogation. Furthermore, tone (not intonation) is not included under 'particle' here. A special intonation is often present in polar interrogative clauses, if it occurs or doesn't occur in this construction has no effect on the coding.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if questions can be formed by a construction that has a free-standing word and an additional morpheme (or suppletion) on the verb, which do not have to be entirely dedicated to question marking.  2.  Nothing else may be different between the polar question and the declarative statement, apart from intonation.      Examples    Lak (lakk1252), coded as 1 but not clear whether it should be 1 based on the above procedure: 'An intensifying particle can be added to the suffixed verb.'    **Coahuilteco [coah1252; Troike 1996: 655] Coded 1:**    Past tense truth value (yes/no) questions are usually marked by a verbal enclitic '-(y)am' plus the interrogative particle 'e'.  ```  mamay 'you'+ na·ko 'think'+ (y)am 'past'+ e· 'Q'  mame·yna·koyam e·?   'Have you thought?'  ```  **Gata' [gata1239; Ashirvadam 1992: 260-262] Coded 1:**    Gata can use an interrogative verbal suffix and the interrogative pronoun 'what' to form polar interrogatives.  ```  mae  bole   cagd-e '       mae ?  he    rice  eat-question   what  marker  'Did he eat rice what?'  ```      Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)     Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Clarifying comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative, but intonation may also be different between questions and declarative statements.
wiki_summary: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative, but intonation may also be different between questions and declarative statements.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a polar question can be formed by adding a morpheme that is phonologically bound to the verb (or suppletion).    2.  Nothing else may be different between the polar question and the declarative statement, apart from intonation.      Examples    **Jaqaru [jaqa1244; Hardman 2000: 102] Coded 1:**     '"The yes/no interrogative is done with {-txi}."     ```  m.w.ima-txi  Did I see you?   ```   Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)     Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Clarifying comments: This feature deals with the presence or absence of a construction where the only difference between the interrogative and the declarative is marked by tone. Please note tone (not intonation) is the focus here which is a particle and bound to the constituent.
wiki_summary: This feature deals with the presence or absence of a construction where the only difference between the interrogative and the declarative is marked by tone. Please note tone (not intonation) is the focus here which is a particle and bound to the constituent.      Procedure    1. Code 1 if there is lexical or grammatical tone in the language,  2. And one of the words in a declarative sentence can change its tone to change the sentence into a polar question.     Examples      **Afar [afar1241; Bliese 1977: 148-151] Coded 1:**    Consultative can be derived as a question form of subjunctive in which an underlying o is not raised to u because of the addition of the question length and tone marker.  ```  'ab-u 'that I do it' (subjunctive from ab'aa-o)   a'b-oô 'shall I do it?' (consultative from ab'aa-oô)  ```   Further reading  [Matthew S. Dryer. 2013. Polar Questions.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. ](https://wals.info/chapter/116)     Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB297: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB297)

Feature: Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Clarifying comments: Ideophones are marked words that depict sensory imagery, e.g. 'glimmer', 'twiddle, 'tinkle'. In some languages, ideophones may have different morphosyntactic characteristics from other word classes (e.g. they have different morphology, or they have no morphology at all while other classes do; or they may be extremely free when it comes to word order, in comparison to other words). They may also feature sounds that are not present anywhere else in the language. Every language probably has ideophones, but not every language has a very well defined class of ideophones.
wiki_summary: Ideophones are marked words that depict sensory imagery, e.g. 'glimmer', 'twiddle, 'tinkle'. In some languages, ideophones may have different morphosyntactic characteristics from other word classes (e.g. they have different morphology, or they have no morphology at all while other classes do; or they may be extremely free when it comes to word order, in comparison to other words). They may also feature sounds that are not present anywhere else in the language. Every language probably has ideophones, but not every language has a very well defined class of ideophones.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions ideophone-specific phonological or morphosyntactic characteristics, and gives examples of ideophones indicating imagery beyond sound.  2. Code 1 if a source mentions ideophones (beyond sound) and you can identify morphosyntactic or phonological properties that do not seem to apply to other word classes (e.g. word order, morphology).  3. Code 0 if a source mentions ideophones (beyond sound) but classifies them together with another word class morphosyntactically and does not mention specific phonological characteristics.  4. Code 0 if an otherwise comprehensive description does not mention ideophones.  5. Code 0 if only ideophones depicting auditory imagery are attested.  6. Code ? if you have reason to believe that the sources missed ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound or specific properties of ideophones in the language.     Examples    **Ewe** (ISO 639-3: ewe, Glottolog: ewee1241)    Ideophones in Ewe have (at least) three unusual phonological characteristics (Ameka 1991: 78):    * They can have short or long vowels without any change in meaning.  * Tone may be used sound-symbolically, so tone in ideophones is arguably more fluid.  * Syllables of ideophones may be reversed:    ```  nyadsii - drinyaa 'tough, hard'  kpɔdzɔɔ - dzɔkpɔɔ 'fat, thick'  tsaklii - klitsaa 'rough'  nogoo - gonoo 'round'  ```    **Buwal** (ISO 639-3: bhs, Glottolog: buwa1243)    In Viljoen's (2013: 67-70) grammar of Buwal, six phonologically uncommon characteristics of ideophones are discussed:    1. Changes in pitch, or lack of a clearly associated melody (cf. Ewe), e.g. *jāàȁȁ* 'noise of rain'  2. Long vowels and consonants, which do not occur often elsewhere (cf. Ewe), e.g. *fɐ́ːɾɐ́* 'manner of running slowly', *mbɛ̀ɮːɛ́* 'manner of staring fixedly'  3. Exaggerated aspiration, e.g. *pʰoe̋hʷ* 'noise of sudden entry or exit'  4. In other word classes, palatalized vowels only occur with front vowels, but in ideophones, they can also occur with non-front vowels: *kə̋tʃɐ̋ kə́tʃɐ́ kə̄tʃɐ̄ kə̀tʃɐ̀* 'cry of guinea fowl'  5. In other word classes, rounded vowels are typically found next to labialized velar consonants or labial-velar /w/. In ideophones, they are also found next to other consonants: *bőf* 'come out suddenly', *ɐ̀túl* 'manner of smoke ascending'  6. /ə/ and its allophones don't usually occur in final syllables, but they do in ideophones: *bɪm̋* 'noise of sudden digging', *ɐ̀túl* 'manner of smoke ascending'    One morphosyntactic characteristic of ideophones in Buwal is repetition or reduplication to a greater extent than in other word classes, e.g. *ŋɡɐ̄m ŋɡɐ̀m ŋɡɐ̄m ŋɡɐ̀m* 'noise of grinding'    **Luchazi** (ISO 639-3: lch, Glottolog: luch1239)    For Luchazi, Fleisch (2000: 45) states that ideophones feature consonant clusters and sounds that do not occur in other parts of speech. He does not, however, provide examples, but this statement is enough to warrant a 1 for this feature in Grambank.    **Bangi** (ISO 639-3: bni, Glottolog: bang1354)    Whitehead (1899: 18) discusses a class of sound-symbolic 'indeclinable adjectives' in Bangi (in his words: "they may be traced to an onomatopoetic origin", they are ""colouring" words").    These ideophones are grammatically characterized by a lack of noun class agreement and person indexing, which applies to verbs, other adjectives, and nouns.    Some examples:    ```  ca 'scattered'  kākatanu 'puzzling'  kō-kō 'tied up'  tī 'intent, still, cool'  zölôlô 'whirling'  ```    **Chinook** (ISO 639-3: cch, Glottolog: chin1286)     Similarly to Whitehead for Bangi, Boas (1911: 627) describes a class of words in Chinook of "onomatopoetic origin" that do not require pronominal indexes.     Further reading    Dingemanse, M. (2011). [*The meaning and use of ideophones in Siwu*](http://pubman.mpdl.mpg.de/pubman/item/escidoc:1005623:14/component/escidoc:2079881/Dingemanse_thesis_2011.pdf). PhD Thesis, Radboud University Nijmegen, Nijmegen.     Related Features    * [GB160	Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB160)

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Clarifying comments: This feature concerns polar interrogative constructions where the main verb is repeated, one time in the affirmative form and another in the negated. This is independent of the negation marking system of the language, it may be by suffixes, auxiliaries, suppletion etc. The negated form need not be in second place, it could be first as well.
wiki_summary: This feature concerns polar interrogative constructions where the main verb is repeated, one time in the affirmative form and another in the negated. This is independent of the negation marking system of the language, it may be by suffixes, auxiliaries, suppletion etc. The negated form need not be in second place, it could be first as well.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if there is a construction where the main verb is repeated, one time in the affirmative form and another in the negated, to form a polar question.     Examples    **Mandarin Chinese [mand1415; Wiedenhof 2015: 212-214] Coded 1:**    ```  Tamen lai bu  lai   他们   来  不   来  'Are they coming?'  ```    **Paamese [paam1238; Crowley 1982: 241] Coded 1:**    ```  kǐha          vuō         kirovɔtelʔ  kil+haa       vǔo (o)   kitro + vaa + tel   2sg.dis.go    or          2sg.dis.neg.go.part  Will you go or not?  ```     Further reading  [Hagstrom, P. (2007). A‐not‐A Questions. In The Blackwell Companion to Syntax (eds M. Everaert and H. van Riemsdijk). ](https://www.bu.edu/linguistics/UG/hagstrom/papers/syncom-anota.pdf)     Related Features  * [GB257: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB257)  * [GB260: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB260)  * [GB262: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB262)  * [GB263: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB263)  * [GB264: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB264)  * [GB285: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB285)  * [GB286: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB286)  * [GB291: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB291)

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns negative words that function as auxiliary verbs, in that they inflect as verbs but occur only with other verbs. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as auxiliary verbs in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.

A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking (infinite/connegative mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.
wiki_summary: This question concerns negative words that function as auxiliary verbs, in that they inflect as verbs but occur only with other verbs. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.    A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite"/"connegative" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.     Procedure  1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation.  2. If you do not find any mood markers that inflect, code as (0)  3. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers  4. If not clear that it is a negation marker, code language as (?)  5. If the markers are clearly marking negation and inflecting, code language as (1).  6. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig).  7. If clarity is not reached, code "?" for this feature     Examples  **Finnish** (ISO 639-3: fin, Glottocode: finn1318)    Standard negation in Finnish is accomplished with an inflecting verb and the main verb in a finite form. Below is a paradigm from Karlsson (1999:70). Finnish is coded as 1 for this feature.    | affirmative | negative |   |  ---- |----------- |   | _tulet_ you come | _et tule_ you do not come|    | _luemme_ we read | _emme lue_ we do not read|    | _he lukevat_ they read | _he eivät lue_ they do not read|      Further reading  * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Linguistics 27. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 1-27.  * Dahl, Östen. 1979. Typology of Sentence Negation. Linguistics 17. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 79-106.  * Dahl, Östen. 2010. "Typology of Negation" in Horn (ed) The Expression of Negation. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Negative Morphemes. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/112)  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Position of Negative Morpheme With Respect to Subject, Object, and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/144)  * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Order of Negative Morpheme and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/143)   * Karlsson, Fred. 1999. Finnish: an essential grammar. (Routledge Grammars.) London: Routledge. 279pp. (auf Einband: Essential Grammar).  * Miestamo, Matti. 2013. Symmetric and Asymmetric Standard Negation. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/113)   * Payne, John R. 1985. "Negation". I Timothy Shopen (red), Language Typology and Syntactic Description, vol. 1. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB107	Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB107/)  * [GB137	Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB137)  * [GB138	Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB138)  * [GB139	Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB139)  * [GB140	Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB140)  * [GB298	Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB298)  * [GB299	Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB299)  * [GB400	Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB400)

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns negative words that do not inflect and are not bound to the verb. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as particles in the literature, but are also analysed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking.

This question should be answered yes (1) if negation is marked by a phonologically independent, non-inflected word (particle), regardless of whether any other strategy can also be used to mark negation (e.g. a language that uses double marking of negation through both a particle AND a verbal affix would be coded as yes (1)).
wiki_summary:
This question concerns negative words that do not inflect and are not bound to the verb. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analysed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. This question should be answered yes (1) if negation is marked by a phonologically independent, non-inflected word (particle), regardless of whether any other strategy can also be used to mark negation (e.g. a language that uses double marking of negation through both a particle AND a verbal affix would be coded as yes (1)). Procedure 1. Find the section in the available descriptive literature that deals with negation. 2. If you do not find any mood markers that do not inflect, code as (0) 3. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers 4. If not clear that it is a negation marker, code language as (?) 5. If the markers are clearly marking negation and not inflecting, code language as (1). 6. If there is unclarity, bring it up for discussion in the group and/or with the patron (Hedvig). 7. If clarity is not reached, code "?" for this feature Examples **Swedish** (ISO 639-3: swe, Glottocode: swed1254) Swedish standard negation is marked by the particle _inte_, it doesn't inflect for anything (Skirgård, p.c.). 
    1)  Hon kommer inte hem ikväll        3sg.FEM come NEG home tonight        'She's not coming home tonight'
Further reading * Croft, William. 1991. The Evolution of Negation. Linguistics 27. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 1-27. * Dahl, Östen. 1979. Typology of Sentence Negation. Linguistics 17. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter pp: 79-106. * Dahl, Östen. 2010. "Typology of Negation" in Horn (ed) The Expression of Negation. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Negative Morphemes. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/112) * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. Position of Negative Morpheme With Respect to Subject, Object, and Verb. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/144) * Dryer, Matthew S. 2013. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/143) * Miestamo, Matti. 2013. Symmetric and Asymmetric Standard Negation. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [link](http://wals.info/chapter/113) * Payne, John R. 1985. "Negation". I Timothy Shopen (red), Language Typology and Syntactic Description, vol. 1. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Feature: Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns verb(s) of giving, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English went and go. If you are unsure if a form is enough different to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique
wiki_summary: This question concerns verb(s) of giving, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English went and go. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.     Procedure  1. Look up section on ditransitive verbs  2. If none exist, search for the words "give" and "receive" and look what you find.  3. If the verb paradigm for "give" is not stated, code as "?".  4. If the verb "give" is described as being non-variant in any way, code as "0".  5. If the verb "give" is suppletive anywhere, code as "1".  6. If unsure, bring up for discussion with patron/group     Examples  **Tongan** (ISO 639-3: ton, Glottocode: tong1325)    In Tongan "give" is expressed with words that elsewhere carry the locational meaning of "towards" and "outwards", "mai" and "'atu" respectively (Churchward 1953:20-21). These are very different from each other, and hence count as suppletion and a 1 for this feature.     Further reading  * Churchward, Maxwell C. . 1985 [1953]. Tongan Grammar. London: Tonga: Vava'u Press. xiv+306pp. (Originally Published by Oxford University Press, 1953).  * Dressler, Wolfgang. 1985. Suppletion in Word-Fomation. In Fisiak, J. (ed.), Historical Morphology, 97-112. The Hague: Mouton.  * Veselinova, Ljuba. 2013. Suppletion According to Tense and Aspect.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  [link](http://wals.info/chapter/79)  * Veselinova, Ljuba. 2003. Suppletion in Verb Paradigms: Bits and Pieces of a Puzzle. Stockholm University. Feature: Is there an inclusory construction?
Clarifying comments: Definition: a plural NP that would be expressed in English by an expression of the type ‘Harald and I talked’ or ‘Harald and us talked’ is expressed by a construction of the type [superset: pronoun] [set: noun/Proper noun], e.g. ‘we.two Harald talked’ / ‘we Harald talked’, respectively. Note: In some languages this would be expressed by associative duals/plurals, e.g. Harald-AssDu / AssPl talked’ for ‘[Someone and] Harald talked’, though this tends to be used for non-first-person groups only. It is structurally different in that no part of the associative dual/plural construction refers directly to the superset. Clarification: the element expressing the superset could be either a free pronoun or a bound pronoun. Example (Bininj Gun-wok): Bulanj ngani-wam / [Name] 1duExcl-goPP / ‘Bulanj and I went.’
wiki_summary: Definition: a plural NP that would be expressed in English by an expression of the type ‘Harald and I talked’ or ‘Harald and us talked’ is expressed by a construction of the type [superset: pronoun] [set: noun/Proper noun], e.g. ‘we.two Harald talked’ / ‘we Harald talked’, respectively. Note: In some languages this would be expressed by associative duals/plurals, e.g. Harald-AssDu / AssPl talked’ for ‘[Someone and] Harald talked’, though this tends to be used for non-first-person groups only. It is structurally different in that no part of the associative dual/plural construction refers directly to the superset. Clarification: the element expressing the superset could be either a free pronoun or a bound pronoun. Example (Bininj Gun-wok): Bulanj ngani-wam / [Name] 1duExcl-goPP / ‘Bulanj and I went.’     TODO  Discuss what happens when it is /Harald and Hedvig we.dual talked/, i.e. when there is an explicit conjunction.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if coordination can be denoted by a pronoun in the plural/dual and a noun (or proper name) that is being included in the larger group.     Examples  'Mara:  rna-na garriyi-mar rniri  -rlinithe man(Nom) we(ExDu)-wentThe man and I went  (Heath 1981:302)' (Singer - see below).     Further reading  Ruth Singer, The Inclusory Construction in Australian Languages (https://www.academia.edu/1288553/The_inclusory_construction_in_Australian_languages)     Related Features  [to be added]

Feature: Is there a phonologically free passive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Clarifying comments: Passivization is a valency reducing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking passive clauses.
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: Passivization is a valency reducing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking passive clauses.      Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the use of a phonologically independent morpheme to mark passive clauses. This can be a particle or an auxiliary.      2. Code 1 if there is no information on phonological (in)dependence but the relevant passivizing marker (auxiliary or particle) is not orthographically bound to the verb. Add a comment that your analysis is based on orthography here.  3. Code 1 if you identify a phonologically free passive marker in the examples/texts provided in a source.  4. Code 0 if a source mentions that there is no passive.    5. Code 0 if a source mentions a verb-coded passive (i.e. one that is marked on the verb by a phonologically bound element) or other means of passivization, but not one marked with a particle or auxiliary.    6. Code 0 if a grammar treats other valency changing operations in considerable depth but does not mention passive constructions.  7. Code ? if there are examples that contain a potential passivizing construction but their analysis remains inconclusive.    8. Code ? if there are no sources treating valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.       Examples    **Jamaican** (ISO 639-3: jam, Glottolog: jama1262)    In Jamaican, the particle *get* functions as a passive marker:    ```    Op tu nou dem no nuo ou di fuud get kuk.  up to now 3PL NEG know how DET food PAS cook  'Even now they still don't know how the food was cooked.'  (Farquharson 2013: 86, PAS in gloss is mine)    ```  **Udihe** (ISO 639-3: ude, Glottolog: udih1248)    Udihe passives are formed with a phonologically bound suffix *-u-*, and thus count for 0 coding of this feature:    ```    si min-du gida-si-u-zeŋe-i  you me-DAT spear-V-PAS-FUT-2SG  'You will be killed by me.  (Nikolaeva & Tolskaya 2001:572-582)    ```    **Bongili** (ISO 639-3: bui, Glottolog: bong1284)    Bongili is described by Mangulu (2008: 30) as marking passive through a word order change, and is thus coded as 0 for this feature:    ```  "Le passif est rendu ... par l'antéposition du patient avec ou sans pronominalisation   redondante..." (Mangulu 2008: 30)    Active:    ɓa-bom-ák-á moto yáná  3pl-kill-PAST-DIST man yesterday  'They killed a man yesterday.'  [my simplified segmentation and glosses]    Passive:    moto ɓa-bom-ák-á yáná  man 3pl-kill-PAST-DIST yesterday  'A man was killed yesterday.'  [my simplified segmentation and glosses]    ```    **Kuku-Uwanh** (ISO 639-3: uwa, Glottolog: kuku1280)    For Kuku-Uwanh, Smith & Johnson (2000: 425) explicitly state that there is no grammatical passive. This language is coded as 0:    ```  "Nganhcara lacks passive or antipassive constructions. Free word order   and the optional omission of constituents allows Nganhcara to achieve   the discourse functions of these formations without morphological apparatus."  ```      Further reading    Haspelmath, M. (1990). The Grammaticization of Passive Morphology. *Studies in Language*, 14(1), 25–72.    Keenan, E. L., & Dryer, M. S. (2007). [Passive in the World’s Languages](http://linguistics.ucla.edu/people/keenan/Papers/KeenanDryerPassiveProofs.pdf). In T. Shopen (Ed.), *Language Typology and Syntactic Description, Volume I: Clause Structure* (Second Edition, pp. 325–361). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Siewierska, A. (2013). [Passive Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/107). In M. S. Dryer & M. Haspelmath (Eds.), *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.     Related Features    * [GB147	Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB147)    * [GB148	Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB148)    * [GB303	Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB303)    * [GB304	Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB304)

Feature: Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Clarifying comments: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking antipassive clauses.
Function: antipassive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking antipassive clauses.      Procedure    1. Code 1 if a source mentions the use of a phonologically independent morpheme to mark antipassive clauses. This can be a particle or an auxiliary.      2. Code 1 if there is no information on phonological (in)dependence but the relevant antipassive marker (auxiliary or particle) is not orthographically bound to the verb. Add a comment that your analysis is based on orthography here.  3. Code 1 if you identify a phonologically free antipassive marker in the examples/texts provided in a source.  4. Code 0 if a source mentions that there is no antipassive.    5. Code 0 if a source mentions a verb-coded antipassive (i.e. one that is marked on the verb by a phonologically bound element) or other means of marking antipassives, but not one marked with a particle or auxiliary.    6. Code 0 if a grammar treats other valency changing operations in considerable depth but does not mention antipassive constructions.  7. Code ? if there are examples that contain a potential antipassive construction but their analysis remains inconclusive.    8. Code ? if there are no sources treating valency changing operations in the language or if treatment of them is very limited.       Examples    **Kuku Yalanji** (ISO 639-3: gvn, Glottolog: kuku1273)    Kuku Yalanji is an example of a language with ergative alignment for nouns that features antipassive marking. As shown in the example below, the antipassive is formed with the suffix *-ji*. In the antipassive clause the former ergative argument in the active clause ('the man', A) becomes absolutive (S). The former absolutive argument (O) becomes an oblique, locative argument in the antipassive clause. Because the antipassive marker in Kuku Yalanji is bound, it does not trigger a 1 for this feature.    ```  Active clause:  nyulu dingkar-angka minya nuka-ny  3sg.NOM(A) man-ERG:pt(A) meat.ABS(O) eat-PAST  'The man ate meat.'  (Patz 2002: 152)    Antipassive clause:  nyulu dingkar minya-nga nuka-ji-ny  3sg.NOM(S) man.ABS(S) meat-LOC eat-ANTI-PAST  'The man had a good feed of meat (he wasted nothing.)  (Patz 2002: 152)  ```     Further reading    Cooreman, A. (1994). A Functional typology of Antipassives. In B. A. Fox & P. J. Hopper (Eds.), *Voice: Form and Function* (pp. 49–88). Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing Company.    Janic, K. (2013). [*L’antipassif dans les langues accusatives*](http://theses.univ-lyon2.fr/documents/lyon2/2013/janic_k/pdfAmont/janic_k_these.pdf) (PhD Thesis). Université Lumière Lyon 2, Lyon.    Polinsky, M. (2013). [Antipassive Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/108). In M. S. Dryer & M. Haspelmath (Eds.), *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.    Polinsky, M. (2017). [Antipassive](http://ling.umd.edu/assets/publications/Polinsky-17-Antipassive.pdf). In J. Coon, D. Massam, & L. DeMena Travis (Eds.), *The Oxford Handbook of Ergativity*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
