Feature: Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Clarifying comments: For languages with multiple passive constructions (e.g. 'personal' and 'impersonal' passives) this question should be answered 1 if the agent can be overtly expressed in any of these types of passive clauses.
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
wiki_summary: For languages with multiple passive constructions (e.g. 'personal' and 'impersonal' passives) this question should be answered 1 if the agent can be overtly expressed in any of these types of passive clauses.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if you find an example of a passive clause that has an overtly expressed agent.  2. Code 0 if a grammar explicitly states that agents cannot be overtly expressed in passive clauses.  3. Code 0 if a grammar contains a lot of examples of passive clauses, but no examples where there's an overtly expressed agent.  4. Code 0 if the language does not have a morphosyntactic passive (expressed by means of word order, particles, auxiliaries, affixes, clitics).  5. Code ? if it is unclear whether the language has a morphosyntactic passive.  6. Code ? if you do not have enough data to say that it is impossible to express an agent in a passive clause (e.g. because it is not mentioned or because there are not many examples of passive clauses in the grammar).     Examples    **Zuni** (ISO 639-3: zun, Glottolog: zuni1245)    Zuni does not allow the addition of an agent role to a passive clause (Nichols 1997: 126):    ```  hom nicikya 'uk-na-'kya  1SG.ACC ring give-passive-past  'I was given a ring.'    *tom 'an hom nicikya 'uk-na-'kya  2SG.ACC P 1SG.ACC ring give-passive-past  'I was given a ring by you.'    *tom 'akkya hom nicikya 'uk-na-'kya  2SG.ACC with 1SG.ACC ring give-passive-past  'I was given a ring by you.'  ```    **Liko** (ISO 639-3: lik, Glottolog: lika1243)    de Wit (2015: 410-414) does not recognize a passive construction in his grammar of Liko. He does recognize a morphological neutro-passive, however (2015: 374-375), which, he argues, is distinct from passives in that it does not allow an agent to be expressed. Its function is to detransitivize a verb and to indicate that the subject is the one affected by the action denoted by the verb. Because of this function the neutro-passive does qualify as a passive for the purpose of Grambank, and the fact that the agent cannot occur with the neutro-passive makes Liko an example of a language coded with 0 in Grambank.    Some examples of the neutro-passive derivation, with *-ɩ́k* in Liko:    ```  ká-nʊw-á 'to tear' → ká-nʊw-ɩ́k-á 'to tear, intransitive'  kó-ɓún-ó 'to break' → kó-ɓún-ík-ó 'to break, intransitive'  ```    **Raji** (ISO 639-3: rji, Glottolog: raji1240)    Raji has a passive suffix, *-i*. Passive constructions allow the expression of the agent marked with ablative case (Khatri 2008: 27):    ```  ram -ɦatiŋ bʌtaŋ dza –i –k -a  Ram -ABL rice eat -PASS -SD -PST  'Rice was eaten by Ram.'    ram -ɦatiŋ bʰwa sʌtika  Ram -ABL bird kill -PASS -SD -PST  'The bird was killed by Ram.'  ```     Further reading    Haspelmath, M. (1990). The Grammaticization of Passive Morphology. *Studies in Language*, 14(1), 25–72.    Keenan, E. L., & Dryer, M. S. (2007). [Passive in the World’s Languages](http://linguistics.ucla.edu/people/keenan/Papers/KeenanDryerPassiveProofs.pdf). In T. Shopen (Ed.), *Language Typology and Syntactic Description, Volume I: Clause Structure* (Second Edition, pp. 325–361). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.    Siewierska, A. (2013). [Passive Constructions](http://wals.info/chapter/107). In M. S. Dryer & M. Haspelmath (Eds.), *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.     Related Features    * [GB147	Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB147)    * [GB302	Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB302)

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Any [free](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) form that expresses reflexive meaning counts as a reflexive pronoun. A reflexive pronoun can also be derived from regular independent pronouns with reflexive morphology (e.g. *him-self* in English, *lui-même* in French). If reflexive meaning is expressed with a body part noun, e.g. 'body' or 'head' ('They are scolding their body' to mean 'They are scolding themselves'), this also counts as 1. One reflexive pronoun (e.g. only for a certain person) is enough for 1 here.
wiki_summary: Any [free](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) form that expresses reflexive meaning counts as a reflexive pronoun. A reflexive pronoun can also be derived from regular independent pronouns with reflexive morphology (e.g. *him-self* in English, *lui-même* in French). If reflexive meaning is expressed with a body part noun, e.g. 'body' or 'head' ('They are scolding their body' to mean 'They are scolding themselves'), this also counts as 1. One reflexive pronoun (e.g. only for a certain person) is enough for "1" here.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if the grammar discusses an independent reflexive pronoun in the language or if you find clear examples of independent reflexive pronouns.  2. Code 0 if the grammar discusses reflexive morphology, reciprocal morphology, or reciprocal pronouns, but does not mention an independent reflexive pronoun. Write 'not mentioned' in the comment column.  3. Code 0 if the grammar does not mention an independent reflexive pronoun in the language, but is otherwise comprehensive.  4. Code ? if the grammar does not mention any independent reflexive pronouns, but you think the author may have missed them or for some reason does not discuss them. This includes cases where there are potential examples of reflexive pronouns in texts/sentences but you're not sure whether or not to treat them as such.     Examples    **Hõne** (ISO 639-3: juh, Glottolog: hone1235)    Hõne has reflexive pronouns that are formed from the word for 'body', *dɪ̀rɪ̀*, which occurs as the bound form *dɪ̀r-* in this context, and the possessive pronoun referring to the person performing the reflexive action: themselves becomes *dɪ̀r-bɛ̄ɛ̄* 'body-3PL.POSS'. (Storch 1999: 135-136)    ```  bə̄-gwààn bə́ dɪ̀r-bɛ̄ɛ̄  3PL-kill with body-3PL.POSS  'They killed themselves.'  (Translated and simplified glosses)  ```    **Kumzari** (ISO 639-3: zum, Glottolog: kumz1235)    Kumzari has one reflexive form that is used for all persons and numbers, i.e. *xō* (van der Wal 2015: 62):    ```  gardīd-iš xō tēr-ē  turn.into:REAL-3S REFL bird-a  'He turned herself into a bird.'  ```    **Rapanui** (ISO 639-3: rap, Glottolog: rapa1244)    Rapanui doesn't have a specialized reflexive form, and is coded 0. Semantically reflexive clauses are just expressed with the regular independent pronoun for the person performing the action (Kieviet 2017: 432-433):    ```  ¿Ko haŋa 'ā koe mo hore atu i a koe?  PRF want CONT 2SG for cut away ACC PROP 2SG  'Do you want to cut yourself?'  ```     Further reading    Geniušienė, E. S. (1987). *The typology of reflexives*. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    [Haspelmath, M., & The APiCS Consortium. (2013). Reflexive constructions. In S. M. Michaelis, P. Maurer, M. Haspelmath, & M. Huber (Eds.), *The Atlas of Pidgin and Creole Language Structures* (pp. 346–349). Oxford: Oxford University Press.](https://apics-online.info/parameters/87.chapter.html)    König, E., & Gast, V. (2008). Reciprocity and reflexivity: Description, typology, and theory. In *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 1–31). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.     Related Features    * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)    * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)    * [GB306	Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB306)

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Reciprocal pronouns are bipartite if they can be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers (e.g. each + other; two + two). So this question asks whether there are any [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers that cannot be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers. These markers may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. They need to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized.
wiki_summary: Reciprocal pronouns are bipartite if they can be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers (e.g. each + other; two + two). So this question asks whether there are any [phonologically independent](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers that cannot be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers. These markers may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. They need to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized.     Procedure    1. Code 1 if there is a(t least one) phonologically independent reciprocal marker in the language that is not synchronically recognizable as composed of two quantifiers.  2. Code 0 if there are no phonologically independent (non-bipartite) reciprocal markers in the language.  3. Code 0 if a grammar discusses bipartite reciprocal pronouns, reflexive pronouns, or bound reciprocal markers, but does not mention or contain an example of a non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun. Write 'not mentioned' as the comment.  4. Code 0 if reciprocal pronouns are not mentioned in an otherwise comprehensive grammar of the language.  5. Code ? if you don't have enough information to know whether a reciprocal pronoun can be analyzed as bipartite or not.  6. Code ? if you have reason to believe that the author of the source(s) or grammar(s) you are using overlooked or ignored a non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun that may be present in the language.     Examples    **Kosraean** (ISO 639-3: kos, Glottolog: kosr1238)    Kosraean features a complex reciprocal marker, *sie sin sie*, literally translatable as 'one of one' (Lee 1975: 107). As such, it qualifies as a bipartite reciprocal pronoun and does not trigger a 1 for this feature.    ```  Eltahl luhngse sie sin sie.  they like one of one  'They like each other.'    Kuht etuh sie sin sie.  we know one of one  'We know each other.'  ```    **Western Farsi** (ISO 639-3: pes, Glottolog: west2369)    Western Farsi features both a bipartite reciprocal pronoun, *ye ... digar* (or *yak ... digar*) and a non-bipartite one, *ham* (Windfuhr & Perry 2009: 437), which also means 'same' in other parts of the grammar. The latter triggers a 1 for this feature.    ```  yek-i pas az digar-i  one-INDEF after from other-INDEF  'one after another'    bā ham raft-im  together go.PT-1p  'We went together.'  ```    **Bargam** (ISO 639-3: mlp, Glottolog: barg1252)    Bargam has an independent non-bipartite marker, *an*, that fulfills both reciprocal and reflexive functions (Hepner 2006: 100). It is thus coded 1 for this feature.    ```  on in an tu-bulon yaʔ-ay  women they each.other PFT-speak.to IPF-N1P  'the women were speaking to each other.'    I kab an huser-01-uʔ ha(ʔ)-01-w.  we this-DAT each.other divide-JUS-1P QV-PA-1P  ‘Let’s divide up (ourselves) here.’  ```     Further reading    Evans, N. (2008). Reciprocal Constructions: Towards a Structural Typology. In E. König & V. Gast (Eds.), *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 33–104). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Geniušienė, E. S. (1987). *The typology of reflexives*. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    König, E., & Gast, V. (2008). Reciprocity and reflexivity: Description, typology, and theory. In *Reciprocals and Reflexives: Theoretical and typological explorations* (pp. 1–31). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.    Nedjalkov, V. P. (2007). Overview of the research: Definitions of terms, framework, and related issues. In V. P. Nedjalkov (Ed.), E. S. Geniušienė (Trans.), *Reciprocal Constructions* (pp. 3–114). Amsterdam: John Benjamins. And other chapters of the five-volume collection edited by Nedjalkov, which include chapters on 39 different genealogically diverse languages.     Related Features    * [GB114	Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB114)    * [GB115	Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB115)    * [GB305	Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB305)

Feature: Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Clarifying comments: This question aims at capturing productive marking of tense that makes distinctions into remoteness of time in relation to the point of reference or utterance. The actual marking can tonal, verbal affixation, suppletion or any other means of marking. Beware that it is important to tease out if the distinction is aspectual or modal rather than temporal. For example, present perfect is a kind of aspect that involves current relevance, and may therefore more likely occur in recent time - but it can refer to events further in the past as well.
wiki_summary:
This question aims at capturing productive marking of tense that makes distinctions into remoteness of time in relation to the point of reference or utterance. The actual marking can tonal, verbal affixation, suppletion or any other means of marking. Beware that it is important to tease out if the distinction is aspectual or modal rather than temporal. For example, "present perfect" is a kind of aspect that involves "current relevance", and may therefore more likely occur in recent time - but it can refer to events further in the past as well. Procedure 1. Look up the section(s) in the language description that deals with tense. 2. Check if there are markers of past or future tense at all. 3. If more than one function of future or past tense are described, and marked by separate forms: investigate whether the distinctions are aspectual or modal, or indeed relate to remoteness on the temporal axis. 4. If there is only one form-function mapping for past and future tense (or indeed none at all), code the language as "0". 5. If it is unclear whether the distinction is aspectual/modal or temporal, code the language as "?". 6. If there are several function-form pair described, but with little motivation and few examples to clearly explain what is going on, code the language as "?". 7. If it is clearly stated that the distinction has to do with remoteness of time, code the language as "1". Examples **Sudest** (ISO 639-3: tgo, Glottocode: sude1239) In Sudest, there are distinctions remoteness in both past and future tenses. Anderson & Ross(2002:335-339) outlines this in a paradigm and also gives the examples below. Sudest is coded as 1 for this feature. 
    1)  Va thï=utu        DIST.PAST 3PL=talk        'They talked'      2)  Methï=wa e la-ma nggolo        IMM.PAST:3PL=go PREP POSS-1EXC:PL house        'They went (today or yesterday) to my house.      3) Na ya-wa        IMM.FUT 1SG=go       'They will go (today)'      4) Ne thï=kwaio       FUT 3PL= work       'They will work (after today)'
Below is a helpful excerpt on the typological literature on this phenomena from a PhD thesis by Hayashi on Multiple tenses in Inuktitut. _Cross-linguistically, it is not rare for a language to have multiple past (or future) tenses that cover different temporal domains (Dahl, 1983, 1985, 2008; Comrie, 1985; Mithun, 1999; Dahl and Velupillai, 2005:269)._ _Such languages are especially common in the Bantu family, the Australian Aboriginal languages, and the Native American languages (Comrie, 1985). When a language has two past tenses covering different temporal domains, the cut-off point (boundary) is most commonly placed between ‘today’ and ‘before today’, in which case the tenses can be labeled with Latinate terms as hodiernal past and pre-hodiernal past (Dahl, 1983, 1985, 2008; Comrie, 1985; Dahl and Velupillai, 2005). Another common cut-off point is that between ‘recently’ and ‘longer ago’. When a language has more than two past tenses, additional cut-off points may be placed between ‘yesterday’ and ‘before yesterday’, between ‘a few days ago’ and ‘more than a few days ago’, between ‘this year’ and ‘before this year’, etc._ _Comrie (1985) also points out that tense systems across languages may contrast with one another not only with respect to how they segment the time-line, but also with respect to how rigid the boundaries between the segments are. Haya, for example, has three past tenses covering ‘today’ (the hodiernal past), ‘yesterday’ (the hesternal past), and ‘before yesterday’ (the pre-hesternal past). Their boundaries are rigid, in the sense that the hodiernal past can never be used to describe a situation in a time prior to the day of utterance. Sotho, in contrast, has the opposition of ‘recently’ vs. ‘not recently’, where the boundary is fluid in the sense that what counts as recent is left to the speaker’s subjective impression; it is possible, thus, to describe an event that took place several years or decades ago with a recent past form, as long as the speaker intends to emphasize the subjective recency._ [Hayashi 2011](http://www.semanticsarchive.net/Archive/GE1YzI1Y/Hayashi_phdthesis_2011.pdf) Further reading Anderson, Mike and Malcolm Ross. 2002. Sudest. In John Lynch and Malcolm Ross and Terry Crowley (eds.), The Oceanic Languages, 322-346. Richmond: Curzon. [Bybee, Joan L. and Östen Dahl. 1989. The creation of tense and aspect systems in the languages of the world. Studies in Language 13. 51-103.](https://www.unm.edu/~jbybee/downloads/BybeeDahl1989TenseAspectSystems.pdf) [Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell.](http://www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf) [Midori Hayashi. 2011. The Structure of Multiple Tenses in Inuktitut. University of Toronto. 201pp. (Doctoral dissertation).](http://www.semanticsarchive.net/Archive/GE1YzI1Y/Hayashi_phdthesis_2011.pdf) Related Features These are the currently active features that are related. There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here. * [GB082 Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082) * [GB083 Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB083) * [GB084 Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB084) * [GB086 Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB086) * [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Clarifying comments:
This question is concerned with bound marking on the verb root that denotes grammatical mood. This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically bound elements.

While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.
wiki_summary:
This question is concerned with bound marking on the verb root that denotes grammatical mood. This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically bound elements. While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature. Procedure 1. Code 1 if there is an affix, suppletion, tonal marking or reduplication used to mark mood on either the main verb or an auxiliary verb. 2. If not sure if mood, or aspect or tense, bring up for discussion! Examples **Martuyhunira** (ISO 639-3: vma, Glottocode: mart1255) Martuyhunira has a suffix that denotes unrealised events, also known as "irrealis". Dench (1994:151) gives the below example. Martuyhunira is coded as a 1 for this feature. 
    1)  Ngawu, ngayu puni-lha nyina-lu ngurrinyu-tha, kurnta-yaangu        Yes, 1SG.NOM go-PAST sit-PURPss swag-LOC shame-UNREAL       ’Yes I went to sit on that swag, [I] ought to have felt shame’
Further reading * Bybee, Joan; Perkins, Revere; and Pagliuca, William. The Evolution of Grammar, Univ. of Chicago Press, 1994. * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Martuthunira: A Language of the Pilbara Region of Western Australia. (Pacific Linguistics: Series C, 125.) Canberra: Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University. xvii+372pp Related Features These are the currently active features that are related. Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Clarifying comments:
This feature identifies phonologically independent possessive pronouns that are not formed by the application of regular possessive marking to more general pronominal forms. Instead, languages that qualify for a (1) code for this feature will form at least some possessive pronouns through some process other than the usual possessive marking, or, frequently, with suppletive forms. Note that special adnominal possessive pronouns are most commonly found in the 1st and 2nd person.

To qualify as 'special adnominal possessive pronouns', the possessive pronouns must not be identical to the pronominal forms used for core arguments. It is not necessary for the possessive pronouns to be dedicated solely to the function of possession, provided that the process through which it is formed is not a regular possession marking process in the language.
wiki_summary: This feature identifies phonologically independent possessive pronouns that are not formed by the application of regular possessive marking to more general pronominal forms. Instead, languages that qualify for a (1) code for this feature will form at least some possessive pronouns through some process other than the usual possessive marking, or, frequently, with suppletive forms. Note that special adnominal possessive pronouns are most commonly found in the 1st and 2nd person.    To qualify as 'special adnominal possessive pronouns', the possessive pronouns must not be identical to the pronominal forms used for core arguments. It is not necessary for the possessive pronouns to be dedicated solely to the function of possession, provided that the process through which it is formed is not a regular possession marking process in the language.     Procedure  1. Identify the regular possessive construction(s) of the language, including all possessive constructions used with full noun possessors (e.g. English X's Y, and Y of X).  2. Identify the construction(s) for possession with a pronominal possessor.  3. If the pronominal possessors in the constructions identified in 2 are regular formations of some type in step 1, code 0. If they are different, code 1.  4. If no phonologically independent possessive pronouns exist, code 0.  5. If the phonologically independent pronouns used in adnominal possession are unmarked (bare), are identical to pronominal forms used for core (S/A/P) arguments, and are used in simple juxtaposition with the possessum nominal, code 0.  6. If the possessive pronouns that have triggered a 'yes' (1) code are not entirely dedicated to the function of possession, please indicate in the comments any other functions these forms have.     Examples  **English** (ISO: eng, Glottolog: stan1293)    _Possession with nominal possessor:_    * John's book  * a friend of John's    _Possession with pronominal possessor (1st person):_    * my book (* I's book)  * a friend of mine (*a friend of I's)     Further reading       Related Features  * [GB430: Adnominal possession marked by prefix on possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB430)  * [GB432: Adnominal possession marked by suffix on possessor](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB432)

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Can augmentative function (i.e. larger size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.
wiki_summary: Can augmentative function (i.e. larger size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.     Procedure    1.  Code 1 if there are morphemes in the sentence which vary depend depending on the noun used, and these morphemes are a closed class of under about 30 (our definition of a gender system),  2.  And one of these morphemes can be used to change the meaning of a noun by adding the meaning 'big'.      Examples  [to be added, as there are no examples in the data that have comments]     Further reading  [to be added]     Related Features  [to be added]

Feature: Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Can diminutive function (i.e. smaller size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.
wiki_summary: Can diminutive function (i.e. smaller size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.     Procedure    1.  Code 1 if there are morphemes in the sentence which vary depend depending on the noun used, and these morphemes are a closed class of under about 30 (our definition of a gender system),  2.  And one of these morphemes can be used to change the meaning of a noun by adding the meaning 'small'.     Examples    Kachama-Ganjule (kach1284), coded as 1: 'The use of the feminine definite suffix on masculine nouns conveys diminutive meaning.'     Further reading  [to be added]     Related Features  [to be added]

Feature: Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns regular marking of singular number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.
wiki_summary: This question concerns regular marking of singular number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or noun phrases  2. If the author describes an overt free-standing marker of singular number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the grammar describes singular number as not marked productively or as bound to the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Samoan** (ISO 639-3: smo, Glottocode: samo1305)    Number in Samoan is regularly expressed by a free-standing element that fuses specificity and number - labeled "article". Here are articles of Samoan illustrated with the word for house - _fale_. Samoan is an example of 1-coding for GB316.    (Mosel & Hovdhaugen 1992:90)    | | singular | plural |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- |   |specific| _le fale_ | _fale_ |   |non-specific| _se fale_ | _ni fale_ |        Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Mosel, Ulrike and Even Hovdhaugen. 1992. _Samoan Reference Grammar_. (Instituttet for sammenlignende kulturforskning 85.) Feature: Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB043	Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB043) which focusses on the bound marking of dual number.

Feature: Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns regular marking of plural number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB044 Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB044) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity (articles) or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

(For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity (articles) or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or noun phrases  2. If the author describes an overt free-standing marker of plural number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the grammar describes plural number as not marked productively or as bound to the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Kare** (ISO 639-3:kbn , Glottocode: kare1338)    In Kare plural number of nouns is marked by a free-standing marker that follows the noun, as can be seen in the example. Kare is an example of a coding 1 for GB318.    Lim (1997:209)  ```  ɓàì fǒn wíe má váà rì   à_cause_de jeune femme mère chien PL  because_of young woman mother dog PL  ‘à cause de la jeune femme, la mère des chiens’  ‘because of the young woman, mother of dogs’  ```     Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Lim, François. 1997. Description linguistique du Kare (phonologie-syntaxe). Paris: Univ. (Doctoral dissertation, Université de la Sorbonne Nouvelle (Paris 3); 405pp.)     Related Features  * [GB041	Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for Feature: Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns regular marking of trial number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB165	Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB165) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

This feature is in contrast to [GB165	Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB165) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').     Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.      Procedure  1. Consider the section in the grammar that deals with number or noun phrases  2. If the author describes an overt free-standing marker of trial number that occurs regularly, code 1  3. If the grammar describes trial number as not marked productively or as bound to the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Futuna-Aniwa** (ISO 639-3:fut , Glottocode: futu1245)    Trial marking is not common, and since a similar enough meaning can often be expressed with a plural marker trial is rarely (if ever) described as being obligatory. Futuna-Aniwa makes regular use of articles, and there are separate articles for trial (and dual) number. This marker is different from the numeral three (_tolu_) and triggers 1 for GB319.    Dougherty (1983:23):  _The trial article is taka. taka can occur with any substantive in a nominal phrase. Indication of the trial number in the specific article is rare in natural conver  sation. Either the singular or plural articles may be substituted for taka. Examples of the use of taka include taka fare three houses and taka pepa three books._     Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Janet W. D. Dougherty. 1983. West Futuna-Aniwa: An Introduction to a Polynesian Outlier Language. (University of California publications in linguistics, 102.) Berkeley: University of California Press. 713pp. (A treatise on Futuna-Aniwa language. Includes index. Bibliography: p. 682-687.) Feature: Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns regular marking of paucal number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB166 Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB166)) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').

Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

If the grammar describes paucal number as not marked productively or as bound to the noun, code as 0  5. If the grammar does not describe number marking at all, code ?  6. If the grammar doesn't describe number marking, but examples indicate that there may be regular marking - contact patron through GitHub-issues  7. If the number marker is fused with another marker and there is uncertainty - contact patron through GitHub-issues     Examples  **Iaai** (ISO 639-3: iai, Glottocode: iaai1238)    In Iaai, number is marked on articles and there is a paucal distinction. Iaai is coded as 1 for GB320.    Lynch (2000:870)    _Articles mark the following contrasts_ [..] _specific number: singular (zero), dual (li), paucal/plural (jee)_ [..]    | | SG | DL | PC | PL |   |-------- | ---- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |   | definite |  | _li_ |_jee_|_ta_, _ta jee_|   | indefinite | _ke_ | _ke li_| _ke jee_ | _ke ta jee_ |      Further reading  * Corbett, Greville 2000. Number. Cambridge University Press [link](https://www.academia.edu/746871/Number)  * Lynch, John. 2002. A grammar sketch of Iaai. In Lynch, J. and Ross, M. and Crowley, T. (eds.), _The Oceanic Languages_, 776-791. Feature: Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. This feature asks whether there is a large or open class of nouns whose gender/noun class assignment is not predictable based on phonology or semantics. In other words, such a class will appear to be assigned arbitrarily.
wiki_summary: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. This feature asks whether there is a large or open class of nouns whose gender/noun class assignment is not predictable based on phonology or semantics. In other words, such a class will appear to be assigned arbitrarily.     Procedure  1. If there is a large set of nouns that forms a single gender/noun class and whose members are not obviously related by their semantic or phonological properties, code 1.  2. If there is an open class of nouns that forms a single gender/noun class and whose members are not obviously related by semantic or phonological properties, code 1.  3. If there are no genders/noun classes whose members are not obviously related by their semantic or phonological properties, code 0.  4. If the only genders/noun classes whose members are not obviously related by their semantic or phonological properties are small and not open, code 0.  5. If there are no genders/noun classes, code 0.    Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Corbett, Greville G. 1991. *Gender*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.     Related Features  * [GB051: Sex and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB051)  * [GB052: Shape and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB052)  * [GB053: Animacy and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB053)  * [GB054: Plant status and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB054)  * [GB192: Phonological properties and gender assignment](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB192)

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's direct sensory evidence for some event or action. Visual evidence is frequently encoded with a direct evidential, however this type of evidentiality may also include auditory or other non-visual categories of sensory evidence. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential meaning, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning by the use of adverbs (e.g. John apparently ate the cake) or lexical verbs in multi-clausal constructions (e.g. I saw that John had eaten the cake). This question should be answered yes (1) if the language has a single direct evidential or any number of sensory evidentials.
wiki_summary: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's direct sensory evidence for some event or action. Visual evidence is frequently encoded with a direct evidential, however this type of evidentiality may also include auditory or other non-visual categories of sensory evidence. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential meaning, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning by the use of adverbs (e.g. "John apparently ate the cake") or lexical verbs in multi-clausal constructions (e.g. "I saw that John had eaten the cake"). This question should be answered yes (1) if the language has a single direct evidential or any number of sensory evidentials.     Procedure  1. If the language has one or more grammatical marker(s) (affixes, other morphological markers, particles, auxiliaries) that is dedicated to expressing that the speaker has direct sensory evidence (e.g. visual) of an event or action, code 1.  2. If the language does not use a grammatical marker to indicate that the speaker has direct sensory evidence of an event or action, code 0.  3. If the language expresses direct evidence of an event or action only through the use of adverbs or lexical verbs, code 0.     Examples  **Eastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: peb, Glottocode: east2545)    "[-ink'e] The non-visual evidential indicates that the basis for the statement made is evidence arrived at through the speaker's personal perception using a sense other than sight" (McLendon 1975: 98).    /c'éc'enk'e/  'I feel something sticking me'    /ki·yá·t'a Ɂéčink'e/  'Who sneezed?' (i.e., the speaker heard the sneeze, but doesn't know who did the sneezing)  (McLendon 1975: 99)    Eastern Pomo is coded as '1' for feature GB322.     Further reading  Chafe, W. and J. Nichols, eds. 1986. *Evidentiality: The linguistic encoding of epistemology*. New York: Ablex Publishing.    Aikhenvald, A. 2004. *Evidentiality*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.     Related Features  GB323: Indirect evidentiality

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's indirect, non-sensory evidence for some event or action. Indirect evidentiality usually involves inference from physical evidence or second-hand knowledge such as hearsay. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential menaing, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning through the use of adverbs (e.g. John reportedly ate the cake) or lexical verbs in multi-clause constructions (e.g. They say that John ate the cake). This question should be answered yes (1) if there is a single category of indirect evidentiality or any number of inferential or reportative evidential categories.
wiki_summary: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's indirect, non-sensory evidence for some event or action. Indirect evidentiality usually involves inference from physical evidence or second-hand knowledge such as hearsay. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential menaing, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning through the use of adverbs (e.g. "John reportedly ate the cake") or lexical verbs in multi-clause constructions (e.g. "They say that John ate the cake"). This question should be answered yes (1) if there is a single category of indirect evidentiality or any number of inferential or reportative evidential categories.     Procedure  1. If the language has one or more grammatical marker(s) (affixes, other morphology, particles auxiliaries) that is dedicated to expressing that the speaker has indirect evidence (e.g. hearsay, inference) of an event or action, code 1.  2. If the language does not use a grammatical marker to indicate that the speaker has indirect evidence of an event or action, code 0.  3. If the language expresses indirect evidence of an event or action only through the use of adverbs or lexical verbs in some periphrastic construction, code 0.     Examples  **Eastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: peb, Glottocode: east2545)    '[-·le] The hearsay evidential suffix indicates that the speaker's information comes not from direct observation or experience, but rather from someone else's recounting of the events described. The hearsay evidential is generally not translated, but occasionally, for greater clarity, I have translated it with the phrase 'they say'. The hearsay evidential suffix always co-occurs with the hearsay evidential particle /xa/ which may be preposed to the verb suffixed with [-·le] or which may occur as a separate word at the beginning of a clause of which the verb suffixed with [-·le] is the head' (McLendon 1975: 99).    /ša·qá·xdàyawal xa šó·llà·yówal wádu·kè·le/ 'Quail-Young lady' 'hearsay evidential' 'eastwards-under the sun' 'went,(hearsay evidential)' (McLendon 1975: 100)    Eastern Pomo is coded as '1' for GB323.     Further reading  Chafe, W. and J. Nichols, eds. 1986. *Evidentiality: The linguistic encoding of epistemology*. New York: Ablex Publishing.    Aikhenvald, A. 2004. *Evidentiality*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.     Related Features  GB322: Direct evidentiality

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Clarifying comments: Interrogative verbs are verbs that include a semantic wh-element. In other words, the semantic content of interrogative verb roots includes an element equivalent to a content question (also called a wh-element), e.g., meaning 'to do what' or 'to be who'. The wh-element needs to behave like a verb in the language, e.g., if the language is English, it should take verbal morphology, appearing, e.g., as in 'you what-ed yesterday?' (to mean 'you did what yesterday?'). The feature does not include verbs of asking or interrogative forms created through affixation of interrogative markers to non-interrogative verb roots.
wiki_summary: Interrogative verbs are verbs that include a semantic wh-element. In other words, the semantic content of interrogative verb roots includes an element equivalent to a content question (also called a wh-element), e.g., meaning 'to do what' or 'to be who'. The wh-element needs to behave like a verb in the language, e.g., if the language is English, it should take verbal morphology, appearing, e.g., as in 'you what-ed yesterday?' (to mean 'you did what yesterday?'). The feature does not include verbs of asking or interrogative forms created through affixation of interrogative markers to non-interrogative verb roots.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples  Tiri-Mea (cir) has the following content interrogatives:  * ne 'what', anròi 'how many', jaa 'who', anr 'what time', (â)e 'where', unròi 'how many times': these are not verbs  * trò 'what is the matter with' is a verb asking about the subject's problematic situation; hwasââwe 'how to know, on what evidence' is either a verb or a posthead modifier, asking about the evidentiality of information supplied by the addressee.  For instance:     ```  nrâ   trò      â   rroto  3SG   matter   SM  car  'What is the matter with the car?'  ```    Even though there are only two contents interrogatives and the more common and more general interrogatives are not verbs, the language is coded as having interrogative verb for content interrogatives ("1")   Further reading    Idiatov, Dmitry. 2007. A Typology of Non-Selective Interrogative Pronominals.   Universiteit Antwerpen Doctoral Dissertation.     Related Features    - GB325: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?  - GB326: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Clarifying comments: For example, English contrasts 'how many' versus 'how much'.
wiki_summary: For example, English contrasts 'how many' versus 'how much'.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples     Further reading  Gil (1982) is not about interrogatives, but does discuss the count/mass  distinction in language(s).    Gil, David. (1982) Distributive Numerals. University of California, Los Angeles doctoral dissertation.     Related Features    - GB324: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?  - GB326: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Clarifying comments: In situ means the normal position for a non-interrogative NP in the same participant role. This question is concerned with the use of in-situ content interrogative nominals as a general question construction. This question should be answered yes (1) if questions formed with in-situ interrogatives are pragmatically unmarked and are used commonly (e.g. not only in restrictive contexts such as echo questions or constructions with multiple interrogatives).
wiki_summary: In situ means the normal position for a non-interrogative NP in the same participant role. This question is concerned with the use of in-situ content interrogative nominals as a general question construction. This question should be answered yes (1) if questions formed with in-situ interrogatives are pragmatically unmarked and are used commonly (e.g. not only in restrictive contexts such as echo questions or constructions with multiple interrogatives). Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Clarifying comments: Is the position of a non-correlative relative clause that modifies a noun immediately after its noun? E.g., '[The woman who has a green hat] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. The relative clause must immediately follow the noun and not require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause (= be a correlative relative clause).

E.g., '[The woman who has a green hat] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. The relative clause must immediately follow the noun and not require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause (= be a correlative relative clause). Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Clarifying comments: Is the position of a non-correlative relative clause that modifies a noun immediately before its noun? E.g., '[Who has a green hat the woman] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. The relative clause must immediately precede the noun and not require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause.

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Clarifying comments:
Is the noun modified by a relative clause inside a non-correlative relative clause? E.g., '[A green hat the woman has] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required. Doubly headed
relative clauses are not sufficient for a yes here.
wiki_summary: Is the noun modified by a relative clause inside a non-correlative relative clause? E.g., '[A green hat the woman has] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required. Doubly headed  relative clauses are not sufficient for a yes here. Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Clarifying comments:
Is a pronoun required in the main clause that is anaphoric
to the noun modified by a relative clause. For example, the pattern
'[The woman who has a green hat] she is tall' counts (only) as
correlative (GB330), no matter where in the relative clause the
erstwhile (now replaced by an anaphoric pronoun) head noun occurs. An
obligatory anaphoric pronoun in the main clause is the crucial
characteristic.
wiki_summary: Is a pronoun required in the main clause that is anaphoric  to the noun modified by a relative clause. For example, the pattern  '[The woman who has a green hat] she is tall' counts (only) as  correlative (GB330), no matter where in the relative clause the  erstwhile (now replaced by an anaphoric pronoun) head noun occurs. An  obligatory anaphoric pronoun in the main clause is the crucial  characteristic.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples     Further reading  See the special section on the Grambank wiki on [relative clauses](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/Relative-Clauses).     Related Features  The other relative clause features:    - GB327: Can the relative clause follow the noun?  - GB328: Can the relative clause precede the noun?  - GB329: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?  - GB331: Are there adjoined relative clauses?

Feature: Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Clarifying comments: Is there a non-correlative relative clause that is not adjacent to its modified noun. For example, in 'the woman is tall [who has a green hat]', the noun (woman) is not adjacent to its modifying relative clause (who has a green hat) and so it is an example of an adjoined relative clause. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required.
wiki_summary: Is there a non-correlative relative clause that is not adjacent to its modified noun. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required. Feature: Is there a decimal numeral system?
Clarifying comments:
Are expressions for 30 formed as 3x10, 40=4x10, 50=5x10, .., 90=9x10, or, if 30, 40, .., 90 are monomorphemic, are the expressions for 20-30; 30-40; 50-60; etc formed as 20+E(1), 20+E(2), .., 20+E(9); 30+E(1), 30+E(2), .., 30+E(9). Where E(X) means whatever the expression for X is in the language, not necessarily simplex/monomorphemic expression.

The coding should reflect the earliest attested (i.e. not merely inferred) stage so if a pre-borrowing stage is attested, this should be coded.
wiki_summary: Are expressions for 30 formed as 3x10, 40=4x10, 50=5x10, .., 90=9x10, or, if 30, 40, .., 90 are monomorphemic, are the expressions for 20-30; 30-40; 50-60; etc formed as 20+E(1), 20+E(2), .., 20+E(9); 30+E(1), 30+E(2), .., 30+E(9). Where E(X) means whatever the expression for X is in the language, not necessarily simplex/monomorphemic expression.    The coding should reflect the earliest attested (i.e. not merely inferred) stage so if a pre-borrowing stage is attested, this should be coded.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples     Further reading    Hammarström, Harald. (2010) Rarities in Numeral Systems. In Jan Wohlgemuth & Michael Cysouw (eds.), Rethinking Universals: How rarities affect linguistic theory (Empirical Approaches to Language Typology 45), 11-60. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Where E(X) means whatever the expression for X is in the language, not necessarily simplex/monomorphemic expression.

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Clarifying comments: A body-part tally system is where counting starts from one hand tallying parts of the body along the arm up to the head and continues with symmetric tally points down the other side of the body. A body-tally system is distinct from other counting systems that make use of the body at least by the property that body-tally systems make use of other parts of the body apart from hand/feet/fingers/toes.

Feature: Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns languages with obligatory indexing of the person of the argument somewhere in the clause (i.e. either on the verb or by clitics). The question asks whether the markers are deleted under certain circumstances. In order for there to be neutralization, there needs to be something to neutralize to begin with, i.e. languages without marking of person anywhere in the clause should be coded 0 for this feature. For this question do not consider independent pronouns.
Function: person, valency change, TAM, passive, antipassive, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments
wiki_summary: This question concerns languages with obligatory indexing of the person of the argument somewhere in the clause (i.e. either on the verb or by clitics). The question asks whether the markers are deleted under certain circumstances. In order for there to be neutralization, there needs to be something to "neutralize" to begin with, i.e. languages without marking of person anywhere in the clause should be coded "0" for this feature. For this question do not consider independent pronouns.     Procedure  1. Investigate if the person of arguments is indexed in the language at all.  2. If not, code "0".  3. If they are indexed, check if there are any mentions in the sections on TAM, voice or negation of these markers being deleted under these circumstances. (Ignore imperative clauses and consider only independent clauses.)  4. If yes, code "1" and add a comment on conditions.  5. If no, code "0".     Examples  In English Simple present the verb indexes person via the opposition between the suffix _-s_ vs. zero marking. Also there is person indexing in all sorts of tenses analytically built with the help of the auxiliary _to be_. In Simple past, however, there is no person indexing whatsoever and we can speak of neutralization of person categories. -> Code as "1".     Further reading     Related Features  These are the currently active features that are related. There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here.   * [GB082	Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082)  * [GB083	Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB083)  * Feature: Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Clarifying comments:
This quote from [Kulikov and Lavidas (2008)](http://www.fabula.org/actualites/typology-of-labile-verbs-focus-on-diachrony_27119.php) serves as a very good clarification. For this question we are only interested in P-labile verbs, not A-labile verbs.

_The term ‘labileʼ refers to verbs or verbal forms which can show valency alternation, i.e. changes in syntactic pattern, with no formal change in the verb. Very often (but not always) the term ‘labileʼ is only employed to refer to verbs (or verbal forms) which can be employed both transitively and intransitively, as in (1-2); some scholars use other, less widely accepted terms in this sense, such as ‘ambitransitiveʼ (R. M. W. Dixon 1994) or ‘optionally transitive' (J. G. Miller 1993):_

(1) English
```
a. John broke the vase.
b. The vase broke.
````
(2) Greek
```
a. O         Janis      efage   mesimeriano.
the:NOM   Janis:NOM  ate:3SG lunch:ACC
'Janis ate lunch.'

b. O        Janis      efage.
the:NOM  Janis:NOM  ate:3SG
'Janis ate.'
```

(1) exemplifies patient-preserving lability (P-lability), while (2) illustrates an agent-preserving lability (A-lability), which is not relevant for this question.
wiki_summary: This quote from [Kulikov and Lavidas (2008)](http://www.fabula.org/actualites/typology-of-labile-verbs-focus-on-diachrony_27119.php) serves as a very good clarification. For this question we are only interested in P-labile verbs, not A-labile verbs.    _The term ‘labileʼ refers to verbs or verbal forms which can show valency alternation, i.e. changes in syntactic pattern, with no formal change in the verb. Very often (but not always) the term ‘labileʼ is only employed to refer to verbs (or verbal forms) which can be employed both transitively and intransitively, as in (1-2); some scholars use other, less widely accepted terms in this sense, such as ‘ambitransitiveʼ (R. M. W. Dixon 1994) or ‘optionally transitive' (J. G. Miller 1993):_    (1) English  ```  a. John broke the vase.  b. The vase broke.  ````  (2) Greek  ```  a. O         Janis      efage   mesimeriano.     the:NOM   Janis:NOM  ate:3SG lunch:ACC     'Janis ate lunch.'    b. O        Janis      efage.     the:NOM  Janis:NOM  ate:3SG     'Janis ate.'  ```    (1) exemplifies patient-preserving lability (P-lability), while (2) illustrates an agent-preserving lability (A-lability), which is not relevant for this question.       Procedure  1. Look up the section on valency in the description  2. If none exists, search for examples containing such terms such as "burn", "melt" and "break"/"broke" and consider the relevant examples.  3. Consider if you can find support for a set of P-labile verbs, according to the definition above (i.e. same verb can be used without morphological change for a transitive clause where the theme is the object, and an intransitive where the theme is the subject). If you find examples for at least two verbs, code as "1".  4. If you cannot find enough information, code as "?".  5. If unclear, bring up for discussion     Examples  No example has been provided yet, contact patron if needed. Please consider the examples provided in the recommended literature.     Further reading  * Kulikov, Leonid and Nikolaos Lavidas. 2014. _Linguistics_ (Special Issue: Typology of Labile Verbs:  Focus on Diachrony.) 52(4):871–877.     Related Features

Feature: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments:
This question concerns verb(s) of seeing/watching/looking, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is enough different to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.

Please note that we are not interested in words that are translated to look for, seek etc. This feature is concerned with the transitive verb of the acting fo seeing, not metaphorical extensions such as seek up.
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique
wiki_summary: This question concerns verb(s) of seeing/watching/looking, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.    Please note that we are not interested in words that are translated to "look for", "seek" etc. This feature is concerned with the transitive verb of the acting fo seeing, not metaphorical extensions such as "seek up".     Procedure  1. Look up section on verbs of seeing  2. If none exist, search for the words "see", "look" and "watch" and look what you find.  3. If the verb paradigm for "see" is not stated, code as "?".  4. If the verb "see" is described as being non-variant in any way, code as "0".  5. If the verb "see" is suppletive anywhere, code as "1".  6. If unsure, bring up for discussion with patron/group     Examples  **Polish** (ISO 639-3: pol, Glottocode: poli1260)   In Polish, there is suppletion for the verb 'to see' in regards to aspect (Swan 2002:289). These stems are different enough to count as suppletion.    | Imperfective| Perfective |  | ---- |  ---- |  |widzieć| zobaczyć |         Further reading  * Dressler, Wolfgang. 1985. Suppletion in Word-Fomation. In Fisiak, J. (ed.), Historical Morphology, 97-112. The Hague: Mouton.  * Swan, Oscar E. 2002. A grammar of contemporary Polish. Bloomington: Bloomington: Slavica. 496pp.  * Veselinova, Ljuba. 2013. Suppletion According to Tense and Aspect.  In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.)  The World Atlas of Language Structures Online.  Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology.  [link](http://wals.info/chapter/79)  * Veselinova, Ljuba. 2003. Suppletion in Verb Paradigms: Bits and Pieces of a Puzzle. Stockholm University.       Related Features  * [GB300	Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB300)  * [GB402	Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB402)  * [GB403	Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB403)

Feature: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns verb(s) of coming, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is enough different to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique
wiki_summary: This question concerns verb(s) of coming, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.     Procedure  1. Look up section on verbs of coming  2. If none exist, search for the words "come" and "arrive" and look what you find.  3. If the verb paradigm for "come" is not stated, code as "?".  4. If the verb "come" is described as being non-variant in any way, code as "0".  5. If the verb "come" is suppletive anywhere, code as "1".  6. If unsure, bring up for discussion with patron/group     Examples  **Samoan** (ISO 639-3: smo, Glottocode: samo1305)     Samoan has suppletion for "come" for S/A-number (Milner 1966:202).
