Feature: Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments:
Do S, A, and P arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with 1 if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. only nouns or only pronouns, or a particular tense or person) shows accusative alignment.

Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that Dyirbal is an ergative language), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.

Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includes what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).

Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.
wiki_summary: Do S, A, and P arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. only nouns or only pronouns, or a particular tense or person) shows accusative alignment.    Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.    Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includes what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).    Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.     Procedure  1. Do not consider indexing. Check whether any of the S, A and P arguments are flagged in any context. Consider only the major/default predicate class, ignore any verbs with non-canonical/special flagging (e.g. the so-called "dative-subject" or experiencer verbs). Consider only independent clauses.  2. If there is flagging, consider which of the three arguments S, A, and P are marked identically and which differently.   3. Code 1 if the P argument is marked differently from the S argument. It does not matter whether the differences are between two overt markers or an overt marker and a zero.  4. Be aware of the differences in marking conditioned by pronoun vs. noun distinction, person, animacy, etc. Code 1 even if only some Ps (e.g. only some pronouns or only definite Ps) are coded differently from the S argument. If, a small class of nouns does not take a particular flagging for phonological or morphological reasons, ignore this class.  5. Code 0 if the P argument is always marked identically to the S argument.  6. The so-called tripartite flagging pattern receives 1 for both GB408 and GB409.  7. If in a language a particular argument role is never filled with an independent pronoun (so there is a gap for flagging on pronouns in a particular argument role), whereas other roles can be expressed with a pronoun, this should be considered as a difference in indexing and coded appropriately.     Examples  **Code 1: Imonda** (imn/imon1245, Border)  Imonda marks only animate P arguments with a special marker glossed as -GL, asin (c).   Inanimate Ps are unmarked, as in (d).   This is sufficient to code Imonda as having accusative alignment of flagging, though this alignment type is restricted to animate arguments.    ```  a. aia-l      agõ-l-i       e-uagl-ual-n     father-NOM woman-NOM-CO  DL-go-DL-PST     ‘His father and his wife went away.’ (Seiler 1985: 180)    b. ti   ed  he-li-f     tree PX  CL-lie-PRS     ‘The tree lies over there.’ (Seiler 1985: 159)       c. aia-l       edel-m    ue-ne-uõl  fe-f     father-NOM  human-GL  CL-eat-PL  dp-PRS     ‘Her father habitually eats humans.’ (Seiler 1985: 165)          d. ti    he-ual-n     three cut-DL-PST     ‘He chopped down two trees.’ (Seiler 1985: 81)  ```     Further reading  [Bernard Comrie. 2013. Alignment of Case Marking of Full Noun Phrases. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: MPI EVA.](http://wals.info/chapter/98)    [Haspelmath, Martin. 2005. Argument Marking in Ditransitive Alignment Types. *Linguistic Discovery* 3:1](http://journals.dartmouth.edu/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Journals.woa/xmlpage/1/article/280)     Related Features  Other alignment of flagging questions:    [GB409 Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)    [GB410 Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)    General questions about case marking:    [GB070 Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB070)    [GB071 Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB071)    [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095)

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments:
Do S, P, and A arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with 1 if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows ergative alignment.

Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that Dyirbal is an ergative language), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.

Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).

Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.
wiki_summary: Do S, P, and A arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows ergative alignment.    Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.    Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).    Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.     Procedure  1. Do not consider indexing. Check whether any of the S, A, and P arguments are flagged in any context. Consider only the major/default predicate class, ignore any verbs with non-canonical/special flagging (e.g. the so-called "dative-subject" or experiencer verbs). Consider only independent clauses.  2. If there is flagging, consider which of the three arguments S, A, and P are marked identically and which differently. Code 1 if the A argument is marked differently from the S argument. It does not matter whether the observed differences are between two overt markers or an overt marker and a zero on any of the two arguments.  3. Code 0 if the A argument is always marked identically to the S argument.  4. If there are differences in flagging conditioned by TAM, consider the distribution in individual TAM contexts. Code 1 if S, A, and P are flagged identically only in some TAM.   5. If there are differences in flagging conditioned by such semantic categories as animacy or humanness, code both patterns. If, however, a small random class of nouns does not take a particular flagging for phonological or morphological reasons, ignore this class.  6. The so-called tripartite flagging pattern receives 1 for both GB408 and GB409.     Examples     Further reading  [Bernard Comrie. 2013. Alignment of Case Marking of Full Noun Phrases. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: MPI EVA.](http://wals.info/chapter/98)    [Haspelmath, Martin. 2005. Argument Marking in Ditransitive Alignment Types. *Linguistic Discovery* 3:1](http://journals.dartmouth.edu/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Journals.woa/xmlpage/1/article/280)     Related Features  Other alignment of flagging questions:    [GB408 Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408)    [GB410 Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB410)    General questions about case marking:    [GB070 Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB070)    [GB071 Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB071)    [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095)

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments:
Are S, A, and P arguments flagged identically? In case of split systems, reply with 1 if any of the subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows neutral alignment. Reply with 1 if none of the three arguments is overtly flagged (i.e. if all three arguments are zero-marked).

Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that Dyirbal is an ergative language), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.

Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).

Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.
wiki_summary: Are S, A, and P arguments flagged identically? In case of split systems, reply with "1" if any of the subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows neutral alignment. Reply with "1" if none of the three arguments is overtly flagged (i.e. if all three arguments are zero-marked).    Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.    Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).    Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.     Procedure  1. Do not consider indexing. Check whether any of the S, A and P arguments are flagged in any context. Consider only the major/default predicate class, ignore any verbs with non-canonical/special flagging (e.g. the so-called "dative-subject" or experiencer verbs). Consider only independent clauses.  2. Code 1 if there is never an overt marking on all of the three arguments S, A, and P.  3. If there is a special marking for A or P, check whether it is used in all contexts. In partucular, be aware of the differences in marking conditioned by pronoun vs. noun distinction, person, animacy, etc. Code 1 even if only some  pronouns or only nouns are identically coded in all the three argument roles. If, however, a small random class of nouns does not take a particular flagging for phonological or morphological reasons, ignore this class.  4. If there are differences in flagging conditioned by TAM, consider the distribution in individual TAM contexts. Code 1 if S, A, and P are flagged identically only in some TAM.   5. Code 0 if either A or P or both are always marked differently than S.     Examples  **Code 1: Imonda** (imn/imon1245, Border)  Imonda marks animate P arguments with a special marker glossed as -GL (cf. c). However, when one considers inanimate arguments, S, A, and P are unmarked and thus show neutral alignment (cf. c and d).    ```  a. aia-l      agõ-l-i       e-uagl-ual-n     father-NOM woman-NOM-CO  DL-go-DL-PST     ‘His father and his wife went away.’ (Seiler 1985: 180)    b. ti   ed  he-li-f     tree PX  CL-lie-PRS     ‘The tree lies over there.’ (Seiler 1985: 159)       c. aia-l       edel-m    ue-ne-uõl  fe-f     father-NOM  human-GL  CL-eat-PL  dp-PRS     ‘Her father habitually eats humans.’ (Seiler 1985: 165)          d. ti    he-ual-n     three cut-DL-PST     ‘He chopped down two trees.’ (Seiler 1985: 81)  ```     Further reading  [Bernard Comrie. 2013. Alignment of Case Marking of Full Noun Phrases. In: Dryer, Matthew S. & Haspelmath, Martin (eds.) *The World Atlas of Language Structures Online*. Leipzig: MPI EVA.](http://wals.info/chapter/98)    [Haspelmath, Martin. 2005. Argument Marking in Ditransitive Alignment Types. *Linguistic Discovery* 3:1](http://journals.dartmouth.edu/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Journals.woa/xmlpage/1/article/280)     Related Features  Other alignment of flagging questions:    [GB408 Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB408)    [GB409 Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB409)    General questions about case marking:    [GB070 Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB070)    [GB071 Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB071)    [GB095 Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB095)

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether there are different 2nd person pronoun forms that are used based on the level of respect accorded by the speaker to the addressee. In some cases polite pronouns are used to indicate a level of formality or unfamiliarity between speaker and addressee. In other cases politeness distinctions are used according to very specific social relationships between speaker and addressee, such as relative age, social status, or kinship. If multiple 2nd person pronoun forms exist in a single number category, and their use is patterned according to the level of intimacy or hierarchy of social relationship between speaker and addressee, this will suffice for a (1) code.
wiki_summary: This feature asks whether there are different 2nd person pronoun forms that are used based on the level of respect accorded by the speaker to the addressee. In some cases polite pronouns are used to indicate a level of formality or unfamiliarity between speaker and addressee. In other cases politeness distinctions are used according to very specific social relationships between speaker and addressee, such as relative age, social status, or kinship. If multiple 2nd person pronoun forms exist in a single number category, and their use is patterned according to the level of intimacy or hierarchy of social relationship between speaker and addressee, this will suffice for a (1) code.     Procedure  1. If there exists, for any number category, multiple 2nd person pronoun forms ...  2. And if those pronoun forms are used to indicate respect or intimacy, or are used according to social relationships between the speaker and the addressee, code 1.  3. If multiple 2nd person pronoun forms exist for any number category but their usage does not reflect social relationships, intimacy, respect, then code 0.  4. If there are not multiple 2nd person pronoun forms for any number category, code 0.  5. If there are multiple pronominal forms that are used for 2nd person meanings that express a distinction in politeness, but these forms are used to express other distinctions in the paradigm, this is sufficient to code 1.     Examples  Examples are not yet available, but will be inserted shortly.     Further reading  Brown, P. and S.C. Levinson. 1987. *Politeness*. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.    Brown, R. and A. Gilman. 1960. The Pronouns of Power and Solidarity. In T.A. Sebeok, (ed.), *Style in Language*. 253-276. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.     Related Features  GB196: Male/Female distinction in 2nd person pronouns

Feature: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying comments: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer preposed to the complement? For example, English has a preposed complementizer 'that' ('I know that the hat is blue' / 'I think that the hat is blue'). The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.
wiki_summary: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer preposed to the complement? For example, English has a preposed complementizer 'that' ('I know that the hat is blue' / 'I think that the hat is blue'). The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples     Further reading    Bashir, Elena. (1996) Mosaic of Tongues: Quotatives and Complementizers in Northwest Indo-Aryan, Burushaski, and Balti. In William L. Hanaway & Wilma Heston (eds.), Studies in Pakistani popular culture, 187-286. Lahore: Sang-e-Meel.     Related Features    GB422: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying comments: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer postposed to the complement? For example, Japanese has postposed complementizer 'to'. The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.
wiki_summary: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer postposed to the complement? For example, Japanese has postposed complementizer 'to'. The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.     Procedure     Available standardised comments  * Not mentioned	      Examples  (1) Japanese has postposed complementizer _to_.  ```  Boku-wa  [[ Bill-ga tensai-da]  to]   omotta.  I-TOP       NOM     genius-is   COMP  thought  I thought that Bill was a genius. (Namai 1999: 158)  ```   Further reading    Bashir, Elena. (1996) Mosaic of Tongues: Quotatives and Complementizers in Northwest Indo-Aryan, Burushaski, and Balti. In William L. Hanaway & Wilma Heston (eds.), Studies in Pakistani popular culture, 187-286. Lahore: Sang-e-Meel.     Related Features    [GB421: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB421)

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a prefix or proclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive prefix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of prefixes or proclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.
wiki_summary: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a prefix or proclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive prefix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of prefixes or proclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is at least one element which according to the author is bound phonologically to the possessor noun/pronoun, and which precedes that noun/pronoun.         Examples    **Zulu** (ISO 639-3: zul, Glottolog: zulu1248)    'The possessor noun is usually preceded by a prefix that shows agreement with the  possessee, called possessive agreement.' (de Dreu 2008: 44)    ukhezo lomfazi    u- khezo lwa- u- mfazi    AUG- 11.spoon POSS11- AUG- woman    “the spoon of a woman”    (de Dreu 2008: 44, ex. 1a)    i- ngane ya- mi    AUG- 9.child POSS9-PN1S    "child of mine"    (de Dreu 2008: 45, ex. 3)    Zulu would be coded 1, because the possessive agreement morpheme is phonologically dependent on the possessor noun or pronoun and it occurs to the left of that noun/pronoun. The relative order of possessor and possessum is not important to this feature, nor is the exact nature of the possessive-flagging prefix (here it marks possession and agreement with the possessum; in other languages it could be a genitive marker).       Further reading    Aikhenvald, Alexandra Y. and R. M. W. Dixon, eds. 2013. *Possession and Ownership: A cross-linguistic typology*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Baron, Irène, Michael Herslund, and Finn Sørensen, eds. 2001. *Dimensions of Possession*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  * GB065: Order of possessor and possessed  * GB431: Possession marked by a prefix on possessed noun  * GB432: Possession marked by a suffix on possessor  * GB433: Possession marked by a suffix on possessed noun

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a prefix or proclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the morpheme that marks possession indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to that possessed noun.
wiki_summary: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a prefix or proclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the morpheme that marks possession indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to that possessed noun.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is at least one element which according to the author is bound phonologically to the possessed noun, and which precedes that noun.       Examples    **Nanti** (ISO 639-3: cox, Glottolog: nant1250)    i- banko    3msg- house    *his house*    i- banko Ihonira    3msg- house pers.name    *Ihonira's house*    irashi i- banko    3msg.poss 3msg- house    *his house*    i- gemari -te    3msg- tapir -ALN.POSS    *his tapir*    Inalienable possession in Nanti is expressed by a prefix on the possessed noun, which indicates the person, number, gender of the possessor. A nominal possessor or possessive pronoun may also be included in the phrase. Nominal possessors follow the possessed noun in unmarked constructions, but may appear to the left of the possessum when they are in contrastive focus. Pronominal possessors occur to the left of possessed nouns. Alienable possession uses the same prefixes as inalienable possession, but also includes an alienable possession suffix on the possessed noun. Nanti would be coded 1 for this feature because it has a possessive construction that uses a prefix on the possessed noun to mark the possession relationship.    (Michael 2012: 151-152)       Further reading    Aikhenvald, Alexandra Y. and R. M. W. Dixon, eds. 2013. *Possession and Ownership: A cross-linguistic typology*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Baron, Irène, Michael Herslund, and Finn Sørensen, eds. 2001. *Dimensions of Possession*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  * GB065: Order of possessor and possessed  * GB430: Possession marked by a prefix on possessor  * GB432: Possession marked by a suffix on possessor  * GB433: Possession marked by a suffix on possessed noun

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a suffix or enclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive suffix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of suffixes or enclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that follows and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.
wiki_summary: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a suffix or enclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive suffix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of suffixes or enclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that follows and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is at least one element which according to the author is bound phonologically to the possessor noun phrase or pronoun, and which follows that noun/pronoun.       Examples    **Southeastern Pomo** (ISO 639-3: pom, Glottolog: sout2982)    Possession is marked by a suffix -it on the possessor, and in the case of alienable possession an additional suffix -baq, which indicates that the relationship between possessor and possessum is alienable.    hayut xin    hayu-it xin    dog-POSS name    *the dog's name*    bt&803;edit xal    bt&803;ed-it xal    woman-POSS arm    *the woman's arm*    hayutbaq ca    hayu-it-baq ca    dog-POSS-ALIEN house    *the dog's house*    &577;uyitbaq ca    &577;uyi-it-baq ca    3s-POSS-ALIEN house    *his house*    (Moshinsky 1974: 95)    Southeastern Pomo would be coded 1.    **Wappo** (ISO 639-3: wao, Glottolog: wapp1239)    Wappo expresses alienable possession by marking the possessor noun or pronoun with a genitive suffix. The possessor precedes the possessed noun in unmarked constructions.    me-me&577; chipe tu:niku&577;    2SG-GEN red dress    *your red dress*    (Thompson et al. 2014: 9, ex. 7)    k'ew-me&577; k'e&353;u    man-GEN meat    *the man's meat*    (Thompson et al. 2014: 14, ex. 36)    Wappo would be coded 1 because this genitive suffix marks possessive relationships and is phonologically bound to the right of the possessor noun.     Further reading    Aikhenvald, Alexandra Y. and R. M. W. Dixon, eds. 2013. *Possession and Ownership: A cross-linguistic typology*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Baron, Irène, Michael Herslund, and Finn Sørensen, eds. 2001. *Dimensions of Possession*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  * GB065: Order of possessor and possessed  * GB430: Possession marked by a prefix on possessor  * GB431: Possession marked by a prefix on possessed noun  * GB433: Possession marked by a suffix on possessed noun

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a suffix or enclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the possessive suffix indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by a phonologically bound element that follows and is phonologically dependent on the possessed noun.
wiki_summary: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a suffix or enclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the possessive suffix indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by a phonologically bound element that follows and is phonologically dependent on the possessed noun.     Procedure  1. Code 1 if there is at least one element which according to the author is bound phonologically to the possessed noun, and which occurs to the right of that noun.       Examples    **Nganasan** (ISO 639-3: nio, Glottolog: ngan1291)    'The relationship between the modifier (the possessor) and the head (the possessed noun) is encoded by possessive suffixes on the head and/or a Genitive case suffix appearing on the possessor.' (Wagner-Nagy 2014: 76)    (m&601;n&601;) d'es&616;-m&601;    (1SG) father-1SG.PX    *my father*    (t&601;n&601;) d'es&616;-t&601; ban-tu    (2SG) father-GEN.2SG.PX dog-3SG.PX    *your father's dog*    d'ed'i ban-tu    father.GEN dog-3SG.PX    *father's dog*    (Wagner-Nagy 2014: 77, ex. 1-3)    Nganasan would be coded 1 for this feature, because a common strategy for marking possession involves possessive suffixes on the possessed noun. It does not matter for this feature that when the possessor is specified with a noun or pronoun it must be in genitive case (but the availability of a strategy for marking posssession on the possessor with a genitive suffix in this language would also trigger a 1 for GB432).     Further reading    Aikhenvald, Alexandra Y. and R. M. W. Dixon, eds. 2013. *Possession and Ownership: A cross-linguistic typology*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.    Baron, Irène, Michael Herslund, and Finn Sørensen, eds. 2001. *Dimensions of Possession*. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.     Related Features  * GB065: Order of possessor and possessed  * GB430: Possession marked by a prefix on possessor  * GB431: Possession marked by a prefix on possessed noun  * GB432: Possession marked by a suffix on possessor

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments:
This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and reality and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as particles in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.

While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.
wiki_summary: This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and "reality" and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.    While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.     Procedure  1. Look up section on mood marking in the grammatical description  2. Consider all marking of mood, i.e. not only conditional.  3. If you do not find any mood markers that do not inflect, code as (0)  4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers  5. If not clear that it is a mood marker, code language as (?)  6. If the markers are clearly marking mood, code language as (1).     Examples  No example has been provided yet, contact patron if needed. Please consider the examples provided in the further reading.     Further reading  * Bybee, Joan; Perkins, Revere; and Pagliuca, William. The Evolution of Grammar, Univ. of Chicago Press, 1994.  * Dahl, Östen. 1985. Tense and aspect systems. Oxford: Blackwell [PDF here](www2.ling.su.se/staff/oesten/recycled/Tense&aspectsystems.pdf)  * Palmer, F. R., Mood and Modality, Cambridge Univ. Press, 1986 (second edition 2001).     Related Features  These are the currently active features that are related. There are also a number of non-active tense features, they are not listed here.   * [GB082	Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082)  * [GB083	Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB083)  * Feature: Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments:
This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such).  These markers are often described as particles in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as pronouns that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.

A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking (infinite mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.
wiki_summary:
This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for. A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together. Procedure 1. Look up section on aspect marking in the grammatical description 2. Consider all marking of aspect, i.e. not only perfective 3. If you do not find any aspect markers that do not inflect, code as (0) 4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers 5. If not clear that it is a aspect marker, code language as (?) 6. If the markers are clearly marking aspect, code language as (1). Examples **Samoan** (ISO 639-3: smo, Glottocode: samo1305) Samoan has two different particles for past tense that differ in terms of aspect. _Sā_ is the more general marker, and _na_ denotes punctual events. Samoan is coded as a 1 for this feature. The examples below are taken from Mosel & Chu-Ling So'o (1997:21), with glossing by Skirgård. 
    1)  Sā nofo le fafine i Apia        PST stay DEF woman in Apia        The woman stayed in Apia      2)  Na pā le pa'u        PST.PERF explore DEF tyre        The tyre exploded

Feature: Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments:
This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do no inflect (i.e. do not change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as particles in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. This means that words such as tomorrow and yesterday do not qualify as productively marking future and hodiernal past. If there are any questions regarding this, please do bring it up with the group.

A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking (infinite mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.
wiki_summary:
This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do no inflect (i.e. do not change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. This means that words such as "tomorrow" and "yesterday" do not qualify as productively marking future and hodiernal past. If there are any questions regarding this, please do bring it up with the group. A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together. Procedure 1. Look up section on tense marking in the grammatical description 2. Consider all marking of tense, i.e. not only past. 3. If you do not find any tense markers that do not inflect, code as (0) 4. Look through examples, if available, and investigate if there are any restrictions in the use of markers 5. If not clear that it is a tense marker, code language as (?) 6. If the markers are clearly marking tense, code language as (1). Examples Examples **Samoan** (ISO 639-3: smo, Glottocode: samo1305) Samoan has particles for tense and aspect. They distinguish present, past and future tense, as well as aspectual distintion. Samoan is coded as a 1 for this feature. The examples below are taken from Mosel & Chu-Ling So'o (1997:21), with glossing by Skirgård. 
    1)  Sā siva le teine        PST dance DEF girl       'The girl danced      2) 'Ole'ā siva le teine       INCHOATIVE dance DEF girl      'The girl is going to dance'      3) 'Olo'o siva le teine       PROG dance DEF girl      'The girl is dancing      4) 'Ua alu le teine       PERF go DEF girl      'The girl has gone

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Clarifying comments:
This feature identifies languages that do not require a phonologically overt S or A argument expressed by a noun phrase or independent pronoun when the referent can be inferred from context. These languages are often called 'pro-drop' languages, and the phenomenon is generally referred to as 'null anaphora' or 'zero anaphora'.

Here 'omitted' means phonologically unexpressed (we do not intend for this feature to make any distinctions regarding the theoretical status of a null anaphor). To count as (1), pro-drop should occur where the S or A argument might otherwise be expressed by an independent pronoun or full noun phrase. Specifically, pro-drop should occur in simple, declarative main clauses.

Pro-drop is not mutually exclusive with indexing of the S or A argument on the verb. If, in the absence of an independent pronoun or nominal S or A, there is indexing of this argument on the verb, you may still code 1.
wiki_summary: This feature identifies languages that do not require a phonologically overt S or A argument expressed by a noun phrase or independent pronoun when the referent can be inferred from context. These languages are often called 'pro-drop' languages, and the phenomenon is generally referred to as 'null anaphora' or 'zero anaphora'.     Here 'omitted' means phonologically unexpressed (we do not intend for this feature to make any distinctions regarding the theoretical status of a null anaphor). To count as (1), pro-drop should occur where the S or A argument might otherwise be expressed by an independent pronoun or full noun phrase. Specifically, pro-drop should occur in simple, declarative main clauses.     Pro-drop is not mutually exclusive with indexing of the S or A argument on the verb. If, in the absence of an independent pronoun or nominal S or A, there is indexing of this argument on the verb, you may still code 1.     Procedure  1. If the S or A argument may be omitted when its referent can be inferred from context, code 1.  2. If the S or A argument is always phonologically expressed, code 0.       Examples  **Czech** (ISO 639-3: ces, Glottolog: czec1258)    Czech allows S and A arguments to be expressed by pronouns when the referent is understood from context, but it also allows these subject arguments to be phonologically unexpressed.    Jan v&269;era nav&353;t&237;v-il     Name yesterday visit-Past.Masc     Jan visited yesterday.      (on) &345;&237;d-il auto    (3S.Masc) drive-Past.Masc car    He drove a car.      (on) m-&283;l t&345;i kufr-y    (3S.Masc) have-Past.Masc three suitcase-Pl    He had three suitcases.      The pronouns in parenthesis in the examples above can be omitted, and in fact would be in most natural contexts. The resulting constructions with no phonologically overt subjects where a pronoun would otherwise occur would lead to a (1) code for Czech.       Further reading  Chomsky, N. 1981. *Lectures on Government and Binding: The Pisa Lectures*. Holland: Foris Publications.    Gilligan, G.M. 1987. *A Cross-Linguistic Approach to the Pro-Drop Parameter*. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of Southern California.         Related Features  GB089: S argument indexed by suffix/enclitic  GB090: S argument indexed by prefix/proclitic  GB091: A argument indexed by suffix/enclitic  GB092: A argument indexed by prefix/proclitic
